     109             : /*
     110             :  * ON COMMIT action list
     111             :  */
     112             : typedef struct OnCommitItem
     113             : {
     114             :     Oid         relid;          /* relid of relation */
     115             :     OnCommitAction oncommit;    /* what to do at end of xact */
     116             : 
     117             :     /*
     118             :      * If this entry was created during the current transaction,
     119             :      * creating_subid is the ID of the creating subxact; if created in a prior
     120             :      * transaction, creating_subid is zero.  If deleted during the current
     121             :      * transaction, deleting_subid is the ID of the deleting subxact; if no
     122             :      * deletion request is pending, deleting_subid is zero.
     123             :      */
     124             :     SubTransactionId creating_subid;
     125             :     SubTransactionId deleting_subid;
     126             : } OnCommitItem;
     127             : 
     128             : static List *on_commits = NIL;
     129             : 
     130             : 
     131             : /*
     132             :  * State information for ALTER TABLE
     133             :  *
     134             :  * The pending-work queue for an ALTER TABLE is a List of AlteredTableInfo
     135             :  * structs, one for each table modified by the operation (the named table
     136             :  * plus any child tables that are affected).  We save lists of subcommands
     137             :  * to apply to this table (possibly modified by parse transformation steps);
     138             :  * these lists will be executed in Phase 2.  If a Phase 3 step is needed,
     139             :  * necessary information is stored in the constraints and newvals lists.
     140             :  *
     141             :  * Phase 2 is divided into multiple passes; subcommands are executed in
     142             :  * a pass determined by subcommand type.
     143             :  */
     144             : 
     145             : typedef enum AlterTablePass
     146             : {
     147             :     AT_PASS_UNSET = -1,         /* UNSET will cause ERROR */
     148             :     AT_PASS_DROP,               /* DROP (all flavors) */
     149             :     AT_PASS_ALTER_TYPE,         /* ALTER COLUMN TYPE */
     150             :     AT_PASS_ADD_COL,            /* ADD COLUMN */
     151             :     AT_PASS_SET_EXPRESSION,     /* ALTER SET EXPRESSION */
     152             :     AT_PASS_OLD_INDEX,          /* re-add existing indexes */
     153             :     AT_PASS_OLD_CONSTR,         /* re-add existing constraints */
     154             :     /* We could support a RENAME COLUMN pass here, but not currently used */
     155             :     AT_PASS_ADD_CONSTR,         /* ADD constraints (initial examination) */
     156             :     AT_PASS_COL_ATTRS,          /* set column attributes, eg NOT NULL */
     157             :     AT_PASS_ADD_INDEXCONSTR,    /* ADD index-based constraints */
     158             :     AT_PASS_ADD_INDEX,          /* ADD indexes */
     159             :     AT_PASS_ADD_OTHERCONSTR,    /* ADD other constraints, defaults */
     160             :     AT_PASS_MISC,               /* other stuff */
     161             : } AlterTablePass;
     162             : 
     163             : #define AT_NUM_PASSES           (AT_PASS_MISC + 1)
     164             : 
     165             : typedef struct AlteredTableInfo
     166             : {
     167             :     /* Information saved before any work commences: */
     168             :     Oid         relid;          /* Relation to work on */
     169             :     char        relkind;        /* Its relkind */
     170             :     TupleDesc   oldDesc;        /* Pre-modification tuple descriptor */
     171             : 
     172             :     /*
     173             :      * Transiently set during Phase 2, normally set to NULL.
     174             :      *
     175             :      * ATRewriteCatalogs sets this when it starts, and closes when ATExecCmd
     176             :      * returns control.  This can be exploited by ATExecCmd subroutines to
     177             :      * close/reopen across transaction boundaries.
     178             :      */
     179             :     Relation    rel;
     180             : 
     181             :     /* Information saved by Phase 1 for Phase 2: */
     182             :     List       *subcmds[AT_NUM_PASSES]; /* Lists of AlterTableCmd */
     183             :     /* Information saved by Phases 1/2 for Phase 3: */
     184             :     List       *constraints;    /* List of NewConstraint */
     185             :     List       *newvals;        /* List of NewColumnValue */
     186             :     List       *afterStmts;     /* List of utility command parsetrees */
     187             :     bool        verify_new_notnull; /* T if we should recheck NOT NULL */
     188             :     int         rewrite;        /* Reason for forced rewrite, if any */
     189             :     Oid         newAccessMethod;    /* new access method; 0 means no change */
     190             :     Oid         newTableSpace;  /* new tablespace; 0 means no change */
     191             :     bool        chgPersistence; /* T if SET LOGGED/UNLOGGED is used */
     192             :     char        newrelpersistence;  /* if above is true */
     193             :     Expr       *partition_constraint;   /* for attach partition validation */
     194             :     /* true, if validating default due to some other attach/detach */
     195             :     bool        validate_default;
     196             :     /* Objects to rebuild after completing ALTER TYPE operations */
     197             :     List       *changedConstraintOids;  /* OIDs of constraints to rebuild */
     198             :     List       *changedConstraintDefs;  /* string definitions of same */
     199             :     List       *changedIndexOids;   /* OIDs of indexes to rebuild */
     200             :     List       *changedIndexDefs;   /* string definitions of same */
     201             :     char       *replicaIdentityIndex;   /* index to reset as REPLICA IDENTITY */
     202             :     char       *clusterOnIndex; /* index to use for CLUSTER */
     203             :     List       *changedStatisticsOids;  /* OIDs of statistics to rebuild */
     204             :     List       *changedStatisticsDefs;  /* string definitions of same */
     205             : } AlteredTableInfo;
     206             : 
     207             : /* Struct describing one new constraint to check in Phase 3 scan */
     208             : /* Note: new not-null constraints are handled elsewhere */
     209             : typedef struct NewConstraint
     210             : {
     211             :     char       *name;           /* Constraint name, or NULL if none */
     212             :     ConstrType  contype;        /* CHECK or FOREIGN */
     213             :     Oid         refrelid;       /* PK rel, if FOREIGN */
     214             :     Oid         refindid;       /* OID of PK's index, if FOREIGN */
     215             :     Oid         conid;          /* OID of pg_constraint entry, if FOREIGN */
     216             :     Node       *qual;           /* Check expr or CONSTR_FOREIGN Constraint */
     217             :     ExprState  *qualstate;      /* Execution state for CHECK expr */
     218             : } NewConstraint;
     219             : 
     220             : /*
     221             :  * Struct describing one new column value that needs to be computed during
     222             :  * Phase 3 copy (this could be either a new column with a non-null default, or
     223             :  * a column that we're changing the type of).  Columns without such an entry
     224             :  * are just copied from the old table during ATRewriteTable.  Note that the
     225             :  * expr is an expression over *old* table values, except when is_generated
     226             :  * is true; then it is an expression over columns of the *new* tuple.
     227             :  */
     228             : typedef struct NewColumnValue
     229             : {
     230             :     AttrNumber  attnum;         /* which column */
     231             :     Expr       *expr;           /* expression to compute */
     232             :     ExprState  *exprstate;      /* execution state */
     233             :     bool        is_generated;   /* is it a GENERATED expression? */
     234             : } NewColumnValue;
     235             : 
     236             : /*
     237             :  * Error-reporting support for RemoveRelations
     238             :  */
     239             : struct dropmsgstrings
     240             : {
     241             :     char        kind;
     242             :     int         nonexistent_code;
     243             :     const char *nonexistent_msg;
     244             :     const char *skipping_msg;
     245             :     const char *nota_msg;
     246             :     const char *drophint_msg;
     247             : };
     248             : 
     249             : static const struct dropmsgstrings dropmsgstringarray[] = {
     250             :     {RELKIND_RELATION,
     251             :         ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_TABLE,
     252             :         gettext_noop("table \"%s\" does not exist"),
     253             :         gettext_noop("table \"%s\" does not exist, skipping"),
     254             :         gettext_noop("\"%s\" is not a table"),
     255             :     gettext_noop("Use DROP TABLE to remove a table.")},
     256             :     {RELKIND_SEQUENCE,

     259             :         gettext_noop("sequence \"%s\" does not exist, skipping"),
     260             :         gettext_noop("\"%s\" is not a sequence"),
     261             :     gettext_noop("Use DROP SEQUENCE to remove a sequence.")},
     262             :     {RELKIND_VIEW,

     274             :     {RELKIND_INDEX,
     275             :         ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_OBJECT,
     276             :         gettext_noop("index \"%s\" does not exist"),
     277             :         gettext_noop("index \"%s\" does not exist, skipping"),
     278             :         gettext_noop("\"%s\" is not an index"),
     279             :     gettext_noop("Use DROP INDEX to remove an index.")},
     280             :     {RELKIND_COMPOSITE_TYPE,
     281             :         ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_OBJECT,
     282             :         gettext_noop("type \"%s\" does not exist"),
     283             :         gettext_noop("type \"%s\" does not exist, skipping"),
     284             :         gettext_noop("\"%s\" is not a type"),
     285             :     gettext_noop("Use DROP TYPE to remove a type.")},
     286             :     {RELKIND_FOREIGN_TABLE,

     288             :         gettext_noop("foreign table \"%s\" does not exist"),
     289             :         gettext_noop("foreign table \"%s\" does not exist, skipping"),
     290             :         gettext_noop("\"%s\" is not a foreign table"),
     291             :     gettext_noop("Use DROP FOREIGN TABLE to remove a foreign table.")},
     292             :     {RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE,
     293             :         ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_TABLE,
     294             :         gettext_noop("table \"%s\" does not exist"),
     295             :         gettext_noop("table \"%s\" does not exist, skipping"),
     296             :         gettext_noop("\"%s\" is not a table"),
     297             :     gettext_noop("Use DROP TABLE to remove a table.")},
     298             :     {RELKIND_PARTITIONED_INDEX,
     299             :         ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_OBJECT,
     300             :         gettext_noop("index \"%s\" does not exist"),
     301             :         gettext_noop("index \"%s\" does not exist, skipping"),
     302             :         gettext_noop("\"%s\" is not an index"),
     303             :     gettext_noop("Use DROP INDEX to remove an index.")},
     304             :     {'\0', 0, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL}
     305             : };
     306             : 
     307             : /* communication between RemoveRelations and RangeVarCallbackForDropRelation */
     308             : struct DropRelationCallbackState
     309             : {
     310             :     /* These fields are set by RemoveRelations: */
     311             :     char        expected_relkind;
     312             :     LOCKMODE    heap_lockmode;
     313             :     /* These fields are state to track which subsidiary locks are held: */
     314             :     Oid         heapOid;
     315             :     Oid         partParentOid;
     316             :     /* These fields are passed back by RangeVarCallbackForDropRelation: */
     317             :     char        actual_relkind;
     318             :     char        actual_relpersistence;
     319             : };
     320             : 
     321             : /* Alter table target-type flags for ATSimplePermissions */
     322             : #define     ATT_TABLE               0x0001
     323             : #define     ATT_VIEW                0x0002
     324             : #define     ATT_MATVIEW             0x0004
     325             : #define     ATT_INDEX               0x0008
     326             : #define     ATT_COMPOSITE_TYPE      0x0010
     327             : #define     ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE       0x0020
     328             : #define     ATT_PARTITIONED_INDEX   0x0040
     329             : #define     ATT_SEQUENCE            0x0080
     330             : 
     331             : /*
     332             :  * ForeignTruncateInfo
     333             :  *
     334             :  * Information related to truncation of foreign tables.  This is used for
     335             :  * the elements in a hash table. It uses the server OID as lookup key,
     336             :  * and includes a per-server list of all foreign tables involved in the
     337             :  * truncation.
     338             :  */
     339             : typedef struct ForeignTruncateInfo
     340             : {
     341             :     Oid         serverid;
     342             :     List       *rels;
     343             : } ForeignTruncateInfo;
     344             : 
     345             : /*
     346             :  * Partition tables are expected to be dropped when the parent partitioned
     347             :  * table gets dropped. Hence for partitioning we use AUTO dependency.
     348             :  * Otherwise, for regular inheritance use NORMAL dependency.
     349             :  */
     350             : #define child_dependency_type(child_is_partition)   \
     351             :     ((child_is_partition) ? DEPENDENCY_AUTO : DEPENDENCY_NORMAL)
     352             :

     662             : static char GetAttributeCompression(Oid atttypid, const char *compression);
     663             : static char GetAttributeStorage(Oid atttypid, const char *storagemode);
     664             : 
     665             : 
     666             : /* ----------------------------------------------------------------
     667             :  *      DefineRelation
     668             :  *              Creates a new relation.
     669             :  *
     670             :  * stmt carries parsetree information from an ordinary CREATE TABLE statement.
     671             :  * The other arguments are used to extend the behavior for other cases:
     672             :  * relkind: relkind to assign to the new relation
     673             :  * ownerId: if not InvalidOid, use this as the new relation's owner.
     674             :  * typaddress: if not null, it's set to the pg_type entry's address.
     675             :  * queryString: for error reporting
     676             :  *
     677             :  * Note that permissions checks are done against current user regardless of
     678             :  * ownerId.  A nonzero ownerId is used when someone is creating a relation
     679             :  * "on behalf of" someone else, so we still want to see that the current user
     680             :  * has permissions to do it.
     681             :  *
     682             :  * If successful, returns the address of the new relation.
     683             :  * ----------------------------------------------------------------
     684             :  */
     685             : ObjectAddress
     686       48348 : DefineRelation(CreateStmt *stmt, char relkind, Oid ownerId,
     687             :                ObjectAddress *typaddress, const char *queryString)
     688             : {
     689             :     char        relname[NAMEDATALEN];
     690             :     Oid         namespaceId;
     691             :     Oid         relationId;
     692             :     Oid         tablespaceId;
     693             :     Relation    rel;
     694             :     TupleDesc   descriptor;
     695             :     List       *inheritOids;
     696             :     List       *old_constraints;
     697             :     List       *old_notnulls;
     698             :     List       *rawDefaults;
     699             :     List       *cookedDefaults;
     700             :     List       *nncols;
     701             :     Datum       reloptions;
     702             :     ListCell   *listptr;
     703             :     AttrNumber  attnum;
     704             :     bool        partitioned;
     705             :     static char *validnsps[] = HEAP_RELOPT_NAMESPACES;
     706             :     Oid         ofTypeId;
     707             :     ObjectAddress address;
     708             :     LOCKMODE    parentLockmode;
     709       48348 :     const char *accessMethod = NULL;
     710       48348 :     Oid         accessMethodId = InvalidOid;
     711             : 
     712             :     /*
     713             :      * Truncate relname to appropriate length (probably a waste of time, as
     714             :      * parser should have done this already).
     715             :      */
     716       48348 :     strlcpy(relname, stmt->relation->relname, NAMEDATALEN);
     717             : 
     718             :     /*
     719             :      * Check consistency of arguments
     720             :      */
     721       48348 :     if (stmt->oncommit != ONCOMMIT_NOOP
     722         178 :         && stmt->relation->relpersistence != RELPERSISTENCE_TEMP)
     723          12 :         ereport(ERROR,
     724             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_TABLE_DEFINITION),
     725             :                  errmsg("ON COMMIT can only be used on temporary tables")));
     726             : 
     727       48336 :     if (stmt->partspec != NULL)
     728             :     {
     729        4582 :         if (relkind != RELKIND_RELATION)
     730           0 :             elog(ERROR, "unexpected relkind: %d", (int) relkind);
     731             : 
     732        4582 :         relkind = RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE;
     733        4582 :         partitioned = true;
     734             :     }
     735             :     else
     736       43754 :         partitioned = false;
     737             : 
     738             :     /*
     739             :      * Look up the namespace in which we are supposed to create the relation,
     740             :      * check we have permission to create there, lock it against concurrent
     741             :      * drop, and mark stmt->relation as RELPERSISTENCE_TEMP if a temporary
     742             :      * namespace is selected.
     743             :      */
     744             :     namespaceId =
     745       48336 :         RangeVarGetAndCheckCreationNamespace(stmt->relation, NoLock, NULL);
     746             : 
     747             :     /*
     748             :      * Security check: disallow creating temp tables from security-restricted
     749             :      * code.  This is needed because calling code might not expect untrusted
     750             :      * tables to appear in pg_temp at the front of its search path.
     751             :      */
     752       48336 :     if (stmt->relation->relpersistence == RELPERSISTENCE_TEMP
     753        2922 :         && InSecurityRestrictedOperation())
     754           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
     755             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INSUFFICIENT_PRIVILEGE),
     756             :                  errmsg("cannot create temporary table within security-restricted operation")));
     757             : 
     758             :     /*
     759             :      * Determine the lockmode to use when scanning parents.  A self-exclusive
     760             :      * lock is needed here.
     761             :      *
     762             :      * For regular inheritance, if two backends attempt to add children to the
     763             :      * same parent simultaneously, and that parent has no pre-existing
     764             :      * children, then both will attempt to update the parent's relhassubclass
     765             :      * field, leading to a "tuple concurrently updated" error.  Also, this
     766             :      * interlocks against a concurrent ANALYZE on the parent table, which
     767             :      * might otherwise be attempting to clear the parent's relhassubclass
     768             :      * field, if its previous children were recently dropped.
     769             :      *
     770             :      * If the child table is a partition, then we instead grab an exclusive
     771             :      * lock on the parent because its partition descriptor will be changed by
     772             :      * addition of the new partition.
     773             :      */
     774       48336 :     parentLockmode = (stmt->partbound != NULL ? AccessExclusiveLock :
     775             :                       ShareUpdateExclusiveLock);
     776             : 
     777             :     /* Determine the list of OIDs of the parents. */
     778       48336 :     inheritOids = NIL;
     779       57824 :     foreach(listptr, stmt->inhRelations)
     780             :     {
     781        9500 :         RangeVar   *rv = (RangeVar *) lfirst(listptr);
     782             :         Oid         parentOid;
     783             : 
     784        9500 :         parentOid = RangeVarGetRelid(rv, parentLockmode, false);
     785             : 
     786             :         /*
     787             :          * Reject duplications in the list of parents.
     788             :          */
     789        9488 :         if (list_member_oid(inheritOids, parentOid))
     790           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
     791             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_DUPLICATE_TABLE),
     792             :                      errmsg("relation \"%s\" would be inherited from more than once",
     793             :                             get_rel_name(parentOid))));
     794             : 
     795        9488 :         inheritOids = lappend_oid(inheritOids, parentOid);
     796             :     }
     797             : 
     798             :     /*
     799             :      * Select tablespace to use: an explicitly indicated one, or (in the case
     800             :      * of a partitioned table) the parent's, if it has one.
     801             :      */
     802       48324 :     if (stmt->tablespacename)
     803             :     {
     804         110 :         tablespaceId = get_tablespace_oid(stmt->tablespacename, false);
     805             : 
     806         104 :         if (partitioned && tablespaceId == MyDatabaseTableSpace)
     807           6 :             ereport(ERROR,
     808             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
     809             :                      errmsg("cannot specify default tablespace for partitioned relations")));
     810             :     }
     811       48214 :     else if (stmt->partbound)
     812             :     {
     813             :         /*
     814             :          * For partitions, when no other tablespace is specified, we default
     815             :          * the tablespace to the parent partitioned table's.
     816             :          */
     817        7458 :         Assert(list_length(inheritOids) == 1);
     818        7458 :         tablespaceId = get_rel_tablespace(linitial_oid(inheritOids));
     819             :     }
     820             :     else
     821       40756 :         tablespaceId = InvalidOid;
     822             : 
     823             :     /* still nothing? use the default */
     824       48312 :     if (!OidIsValid(tablespaceId))
     825       48192 :         tablespaceId = GetDefaultTablespace(stmt->relation->relpersistence,
     826             :                                             partitioned);
     827             : 
     828             :     /* Check permissions except when using database's default */
     829       48306 :     if (OidIsValid(tablespaceId) && tablespaceId != MyDatabaseTableSpace)
     830             :     {
     831             :         AclResult   aclresult;
     832             : 
     833         138 :         aclresult = object_aclcheck(TableSpaceRelationId, tablespaceId, GetUserId(),
     834             :                                     ACL_CREATE);
     835         138 :         if (aclresult != ACLCHECK_OK)
     836           6 :             aclcheck_error(aclresult, OBJECT_TABLESPACE,
     837           6 :                            get_tablespace_name(tablespaceId));
     838             :     }
     839             : 
     840             :     /* In all cases disallow placing user relations in pg_global */
     841       48300 :     if (tablespaceId == GLOBALTABLESPACE_OID)
     842          18 :         ereport(ERROR,
     843             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_PARAMETER_VALUE),
     844             :                  errmsg("only shared relations can be placed in pg_global tablespace")));
     845             : 
     846             :     /* Identify user ID that will own the table */
     847       48282 :     if (!OidIsValid(ownerId))
     848       48060 :         ownerId = GetUserId();
     849             : 
     850             :     /*
     851             :      * Parse and validate reloptions, if any.
     852             :      */
     853       48282 :     reloptions = transformRelOptions((Datum) 0, stmt->options, NULL, validnsps,
     854             :                                      true, false);
     855             : 
     856       48264 :     switch (relkind)
     857             :     {
     858       11044 :         case RELKIND_VIEW:
     859       11044 :             (void) view_reloptions(reloptions, true);
     860       11026 :             break;
     861        4564 :         case RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE:
     862        4564 :             (void) partitioned_table_reloptions(reloptions, true);
     863        4558 :             break;
     864       32656 :         default:
     865       32656 :             (void) heap_reloptions(relkind, reloptions, true);
     866             :     }
     867             : 
     868       48144 :     if (stmt->ofTypename)
     869             :     {
     870             :         AclResult   aclresult;
     871             : 
     872          86 :         ofTypeId = typenameTypeId(NULL, stmt->ofTypename);
     873             : 
     874          86 :         aclresult = object_aclcheck(TypeRelationId, ofTypeId, GetUserId(), ACL_USAGE);
     875          86 :         if (aclresult != ACLCHECK_OK)
     876           6 :             aclcheck_error_type(aclresult, ofTypeId);
     877             :     }
     878             :     else
     879       48058 :         ofTypeId = InvalidOid;
     880             : 
     881             :     /*

    1010             : 
    1011             :     /*
    1012             :      * Open the new relation and acquire exclusive lock on it.  This isn't
    1013             :      * really necessary for locking out other backends (since they can't see
    1014             :      * the new rel anyway until we commit), but it keeps the lock manager from
    1015             :      * complaining about deadlock risks.
    1016             :      */
    1017       47868 :     rel = relation_open(relationId, AccessExclusiveLock);
    1018             : 
    1019             :     /*
    1020             :      * Now add any newly specified column default and generation expressions
    1021             :      * to the new relation.  These are passed to us in the form of raw
    1022             :      * parsetrees; we need to transform them to executable expression trees
    1023             :      * before they can be added. The most convenient way to do that is to
    1024             :      * apply the parser's transformExpr routine, but transformExpr doesn't
    1025             :      * work unless we have a pre-existing relation. So, the transformation has
    1026             :      * to be postponed to this final step of CREATE TABLE.
    1027             :      *
    1028             :      * This needs to be before processing the partitioning clauses because
    1029             :      * those could refer to generated columns.
    1030             :      */
    1031       47868 :     if (rawDefaults)

    1033             :                                   true, true, false, queryString);
    1034             : 
    1035             :     /*
    1036             :      * Make column generation expressions visible for use by partitioning.
    1037             :      */
    1038       47766 :     CommandCounterIncrement();
    1039             : 
    1040             :     /* Process and store partition bound, if any. */
    1041       47766 :     if (stmt->partbound)
    1042             :     {
    1043             :         PartitionBoundSpec *bound;
    1044             :         ParseState *pstate;
    1045        7404 :         Oid         parentId = linitial_oid(inheritOids),
    1046             :                     defaultPartOid;
    1047             :         Relation    parent,
    1048        7404 :                     defaultRel = NULL;

    1051             :         /* Already have strong enough lock on the parent */
    1052        7404 :         parent = table_open(parentId, NoLock);
    1053             : 
    1054             :         /*
    1055             :          * We are going to try to validate the partition bound specification
    1056             :          * against the partition key of parentRel, so it better have one.
    1057             :          */
    1058        7404 :         if (parent->rd_rel->relkind != RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE)
    1059          12 :             ereport(ERROR,
    1060             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_OBJECT_DEFINITION),
    1061             :                      errmsg("\"%s\" is not partitioned",
    1062             :                             RelationGetRelationName(parent))));
    1063             : 
    1064             :         /*
    1065             :          * The partition constraint of the default partition depends on the
    1066             :          * partition bounds of every other partition. It is possible that
    1067             :          * another backend might be about to execute a query on the default
    1068             :          * partition table, and that the query relies on previously cached
    1069             :          * default partition constraints. We must therefore take a table lock
    1070             :          * strong enough to prevent all queries on the default partition from
    1071             :          * proceeding until we commit and send out a shared-cache-inval notice
    1072             :          * that will make them update their index lists.
    1073             :          *
    1074             :          * Order of locking: The relation being added won't be visible to
    1075             :          * other backends until it is committed, hence here in
    1076             :          * DefineRelation() the order of locking the default partition and the
    1077             :          * relation being added does not matter. But at all other places we
    1078             :          * need to lock the default relation before we lock the relation being
    1079             :          * added or removed i.e. we should take the lock in same order at all
    1080             :          * the places such that lock parent, lock default partition and then
    1081             :          * lock the partition so as to avoid a deadlock.
    1082             :          */
    1083             :         defaultPartOid =
    1084        7392 :             get_default_oid_from_partdesc(RelationGetPartitionDesc(parent,

    1288             : /*
    1289             :  * BuildDescForRelation
    1290             :  *

    1292             :  *

    1295             : TupleDesc
    1296       50638 : BuildDescForRelation(const List *columns)
    1297             : {

    1392             : 
    1393             : /*

    1467             : /*
    1468             :  * RemoveRelations

    1473       15496 : RemoveRelations(DropStmt *drop)
    1474             : {
    1475             :     ObjectAddresses *objects;
    1476             :     char        relkind;

    1478       15496 :     int         flags = 0;
    1479       15496 :     LOCKMODE    lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;

    1481             :     /* DROP CONCURRENTLY uses a weaker lock, and has some restrictions */
    1482       15496 :     if (drop->concurrent)
    1483             :     {
    1484             :         /*
    1485             :          * Note that for temporary relations this lock may get upgraded later
    1486             :          * on, but as no other session can access a temporary relation, this
    1487             :          * is actually fine.
    1488             :          */
    1489         142 :         lockmode = ShareUpdateExclusiveLock;

    1605             :         /*
    1606             :          * If we're told to drop a partitioned index, we must acquire lock on
    1607             :          * all the children of its parent partitioned table before proceeding.

    1630             : /*
    1631             :  * Before acquiring a table lock, check whether we have sufficient rights.
    1632             :  * In the case of DROP INDEX, also try to lock the table before the index.
    1633             :  * Also, if the table to be dropped is a partition, we try to lock the parent
    1634             :  * first.
    1635             :  */
    1636             : static void
    1637       19406 : RangeVarCallbackForDropRelation(const RangeVar *rel, Oid relOid, Oid oldRelOid,
    1638             :                                 void *arg)
    1639             : {
    1640             :     HeapTuple   tuple;

    1646       19406 :     bool        invalid_system_index = false;
    1647             : 
    1648       19406 :     state = (struct DropRelationCallbackState *) arg;
    1649       19406 :     heap_lockmode = state->heap_lockmode;
    1650             : 
    1651             :     /*
    1652             :      * If we previously locked some other index's heap, and the name we're
    1653             :      * looking up no longer refers to that relation, release the now-useless

    1679           0 :         return;                 /* concurrently dropped, so nothing to do */

    1750             :     /*
    1751             :      * In DROP INDEX, attempt to acquire lock on the parent table before
    1752             :      * locking the index.  index_drop() will need this anyway, and since
    1753             :      * regular queries lock tables before their indexes, we risk deadlock if
    1754             :      * we do it the other way around.  No error if we don't find a pg_index
    1755             :      * entry, though --- the relation may have been dropped.  Note that this
    1756             :      * code will execute for either plain or partitioned indexes.
    1757             :      */

    1764             :     }
    1765             : 
    1766             :     /*
    1767             :      * Similarly, if the relation is a partition, we must acquire lock on its
    1768             :      * parent before locking the partition.  That's because queries lock the
    1769             :      * parent before its partitions, so we risk deadlock if we do it the other
    1770             :      * way around.
    1771             :      */
    1772       18328 :     if (is_partition && relOid != oldRelOid)
    1773             :     {

    1776         588 :             LockRelationOid(state->partParentOid, AccessExclusiveLock);
    1777             :     }
    1778             : }
    1779             : 
    1780             : /*
    1781             :  * ExecuteTruncate
    1782             :  *      Executes a TRUNCATE command.
    1783             :  *
    1784             :  * This is a multi-relation truncate.  We first open and grab exclusive
    1785             :  * lock on all relations involved, checking permissions and otherwise
    1786             :  * verifying that the relation is OK for truncation.  Note that if relations
    1787             :  * are foreign tables, at this stage, we have not yet checked that their
    1788             :  * foreign data in external data sources are OK for truncation.  These are
    1789             :  * checked when foreign data are actually truncated later.  In CASCADE mode,
    1790             :  * relations having FK references to the targeted relations are automatically
    1791             :  * added to the group; in RESTRICT mode, we check that all FK references are
    1792             :  * internal to the group that's being truncated.  Finally all the relations
    1793             :  * are truncated and reindexed.
    1794             :  */
    1795             : void
    1796        1304 : ExecuteTruncate(TruncateStmt *stmt)
    1797             : {
    1798        1304 :     List       *rels = NIL;
    1799        1304 :     List       *relids = NIL;
    1800        1304 :     List       *relids_logged = NIL;
    1801             :     ListCell   *cell;
    1802             : 
    1803             :     /*
    1804             :      * Open, exclusive-lock, and check all the explicitly-specified relations
    1805             :      */
    1806        2762 :     foreach(cell, stmt->relations)
    1807             :     {
    1808        1506 :         RangeVar   *rv = lfirst(cell);
    1809             :         Relation    rel;
    1810        1506 :         bool        recurse = rv->inh;
    1811             :         Oid         myrelid;
    1812        1506 :         LOCKMODE    lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;
    1813             : 
    1814        1506 :         myrelid = RangeVarGetRelidExtended(rv, lockmode,
    1815             :                                            0, RangeVarCallbackForTruncate,
    1816             :                                            NULL);
    1817             : 
    1818             :         /* don't throw error for "TRUNCATE foo, foo" */
    1819        1470 :         if (list_member_oid(relids, myrelid))
    1820           2 :             continue;
    1821             : 
    1822             :         /* open the relation, we already hold a lock on it */
    1823        1468 :         rel = table_open(myrelid, NoLock);
    1824             : 
    1825             :         /*
    1826             :          * RangeVarGetRelidExtended() has done most checks with its callback,
    1827             :          * but other checks with the now-opened Relation remain.
    1828             :          */
    1829        1468 :         truncate_check_activity(rel);
    1830             : 
    1831        1468 :         rels = lappend(rels, rel);
    1832        1468 :         relids = lappend_oid(relids, myrelid);
    1833             : 
    1834             :         /* Log this relation only if needed for logical decoding */
    1835        1468 :         if (RelationIsLogicallyLogged(rel))
    1836          62 :             relids_logged = lappend_oid(relids_logged, myrelid);

    1846             :             {

    1849        3042 :                 if (list_member_oid(relids, childrelid))
    1850        1406 :                     continue;
    1851             : 
    1852             :                 /* find_all_inheritors already got lock */
    1853        1636 :                 rel = table_open(childrelid, NoLock);
    1854             : 
    1855             :                 /*
    1856             :                  * It is possible that the parent table has children that are
    1857             :                  * temp tables of other backends.  We cannot safely access
    1858             :                  * such tables (because of buffering issues), and the best
    1859             :                  * thing to do is to silently ignore them.  Note that this
    1860             :                  * check is the same as one of the checks done in
    1861             :                  * truncate_check_activity() called below, still it is kept
    1862             :                  * here for simplicity.
    1863             :                  */
    1864        1636 :                 if (RELATION_IS_OTHER_TEMP(rel))
    1865             :                 {
    1866           8 :                     table_close(rel, lockmode);
    1867           8 :                     continue;
    1868             :                 }
    1869             : 
    1870             :                 /*
    1871             :                  * Inherited TRUNCATE commands perform access permission
    1872             :                  * checks on the parent table only. So we skip checking the
    1873             :                  * children's permissions and don't call
    1874             :                  * truncate_check_perms() here.
    1875             :                  */
    1876        1628 :                 truncate_check_rel(RelationGetRelid(rel), rel->rd_rel);
    1877        1628 :                 truncate_check_activity(rel);
    1878             : 
    1879        1628 :                 rels = lappend(rels, rel);
    1880        1628 :                 relids = lappend_oid(relids, childrelid);

    1883        1628 :                 if (RelationIsLogicallyLogged(rel))
    1884          22 :                     relids_logged = lappend_oid(relids_logged, childrelid);
    1885             :             }
    1886             :         }

    1888          12 :             ereport(ERROR,
    1889             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
    1890             :                      errmsg("cannot truncate only a partitioned table"),
    1891             :                      errhint("Do not specify the ONLY keyword, or use TRUNCATE ONLY on the partitions directly.")));
    1892             :     }
    1893             : 
    1894        1256 :     ExecuteTruncateGuts(rels, relids, relids_logged,
    1895        1256 :                         stmt->behavior, stmt->restart_seqs, false);
    1896             : 
    1897             :     /* And close the rels */
    1898        4104 :     foreach(cell, rels)
    1899             :     {
    1900        2930 :         Relation    rel = (Relation) lfirst(cell);
    1901             : 
    1902        2930 :         table_close(rel, NoLock);
    1903             :     }
    1904        1174 : }
    1905             : 
    1906             : /*
    1907             :  * ExecuteTruncateGuts
    1908             :  *
    1909             :  * Internal implementation of TRUNCATE.  This is called by the actual TRUNCATE
    1910             :  * command (see above) as well as replication subscribers that execute a
    1911             :  * replicated TRUNCATE action.
    1912             :  *
    1913             :  * explicit_rels is the list of Relations to truncate that the command
    1914             :  * specified.  relids is the list of Oids corresponding to explicit_rels.
    1915             :  * relids_logged is the list of Oids (a subset of relids) that require
    1916             :  * WAL-logging.  This is all a bit redundant, but the existing callers have
    1917             :  * this information handy in this form.
    1918             :  */
    1919             : void
    1920        1290 : ExecuteTruncateGuts(List *explicit_rels,
    1921             :                     List *relids,
    1922             :                     List *relids_logged,
    1923             :                     DropBehavior behavior, bool restart_seqs,
    1924             :                     bool run_as_table_owner)
    1925             : {
    1926             :     List       *rels;
    1927        1290 :     List       *seq_relids = NIL;
    1928        1290 :     HTAB       *ft_htab = NULL;
    1929             :     EState     *estate;
    1930             :     ResultRelInfo *resultRelInfos;
    1931             :     ResultRelInfo *resultRelInfo;
    1932             :     SubTransactionId mySubid;
    1933             :     ListCell   *cell;
    1934             :     Oid        *logrelids;
    1935             : 
    1936             :     /*
    1937             :      * Check the explicitly-specified relations.
    1938             :      *
    1939             :      * In CASCADE mode, suck in all referencing relations as well.  This
    1940             :      * requires multiple iterations to find indirectly-dependent relations. At
    1941             :      * each phase, we need to exclusive-lock new rels before looking for their
    1942             :      * dependencies, else we might miss something.  Also, we check each rel as
    1943             :      * soon as we open it, to avoid a faux pas such as holding lock for a long
    1944             :      * time on a rel we have no permissions for.
    1945             :      */
    1946        1290 :     rels = list_copy(explicit_rels);
    1947        1290 :     if (behavior == DROP_CASCADE)
    1948             :     {
    1949             :         for (;;)
    1950          40 :         {
    1951             :             List       *newrelids;
    1952             : 
    1953          80 :             newrelids = heap_truncate_find_FKs(relids);
    1954          80 :             if (newrelids == NIL)
    1955          40 :                 break;          /* nothing else to add */
    1956             : 
    1957         134 :             foreach(cell, newrelids)
    1958             :             {
    1959          94 :                 Oid         relid = lfirst_oid(cell);
    1960             :                 Relation    rel;
    1961             : 
    1962          94 :                 rel = table_open(relid, AccessExclusiveLock);
    1963          94 :                 ereport(NOTICE,
    1964             :                         (errmsg("truncate cascades to table \"%s\"",
    1965             :                                 RelationGetRelationName(rel))));
    1966          94 :                 truncate_check_rel(relid, rel->rd_rel);
    1967          94 :                 truncate_check_perms(relid, rel->rd_rel);
    1968          94 :                 truncate_check_activity(rel);
    1969          94 :                 rels = lappend(rels, rel);
    1970          94 :                 relids = lappend_oid(relids, relid);
    1971             : 
    1972             :                 /* Log this relation only if needed for logical decoding */
    1973          94 :                 if (RelationIsLogicallyLogged(rel))
    1974           0 :                     relids_logged = lappend_oid(relids_logged, relid);
    1975             :             }
    1976             :         }
    1977             :     }
    1978             : 
    1979             :     /*
    1980             :      * Check foreign key references.  In CASCADE mode, this should be
    1981             :      * unnecessary since we just pulled in all the references; but as a
    1982             :      * cross-check, do it anyway if in an Assert-enabled build.
    1983             :      */

    1987             :     if (behavior == DROP_RESTRICT)

    1989             : #endif

    1991             :     /*

    1994             :      * We want to do this early since it's pointless to do all the truncation

    2021             :         }
    2022             :     }
    2023             : 
    2024             :     /* Prepare to catch AFTER triggers. */
    2025        1216 :     AfterTriggerBeginQuery();
    2026             : 
    2027             :     /*
    2028             :      * To fire triggers, we'll need an EState as well as a ResultRelInfo for

    2030             :      *

    2302             : /*
    2303             :  * Check that a given relation is safe to truncate.  Subroutine for
    2304             :  * ExecuteTruncate() and RangeVarCallbackForTruncate().
    2305             :  */
    2306             : static void
    2307        3364 : truncate_check_rel(Oid relid, Form_pg_class reltuple)
    2308             : {
    2309        3364 :     char       *relname = NameStr(reltuple->relname);
    2310             : 
    2311             :     /*
    2312             :      * Only allow truncate on regular tables, foreign tables using foreign
    2313             :      * data wrappers supporting TRUNCATE and partitioned tables (although, the
    2314             :      * latter are only being included here for the following checks; no
    2315             :      * physical truncation will occur in their case.).
    2316             :      */
    2317        3364 :     if (reltuple->relkind == RELKIND_FOREIGN_TABLE)
    2318             :     {
    2319          36 :         Oid         serverid = GetForeignServerIdByRelId(relid);
    2320          36 :         FdwRoutine *fdwroutine = GetFdwRoutineByServerId(serverid);
    2321             : 
    2322          36 :         if (!fdwroutine->ExecForeignTruncate)
    2323           2 :             ereport(ERROR,
    2324             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
    2325             :                      errmsg("cannot truncate foreign table \"%s\"",
    2326             :                             relname)));
    2327             :     }
    2328        3328 :     else if (reltuple->relkind != RELKIND_RELATION &&
    2329         660 :              reltuple->relkind != RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE)
    2330           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    2331             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
    2332             :                  errmsg("\"%s\" is not a table", relname)));
    2333             : 
    2334             :     /*
    2335             :      * Most system catalogs can't be truncated at all, or at least not unless
    2336             :      * allow_system_table_mods=on. As an exception, however, we allow
    2337             :      * pg_largeobject to be truncated as part of pg_upgrade, because we need
    2338             :      * to change its relfilenode to match the old cluster, and allowing a
    2339             :      * TRUNCATE command to be executed is the easiest way of doing that.

    2351             : /*
    2352             :  * Check that current user has the permission to truncate given relation.

    2354             : static void
    2355        1732 : truncate_check_perms(Oid relid, Form_pg_class reltuple)

    2366             : 
    2367             : /*
    2368             :  * Set of extra sanity checks to check if a given relation is safe to

    2372             : static void
    2373        3190 : truncate_check_activity(Relation rel)

    2376             :      * Don't allow truncate on temp tables of other backends ... their local
    2377             :      * buffer manager is not going to cope.
    2378             :      */

    2380           0 :         ereport(ERROR,

    2383             :

    2385             :      * Also check for active uses of the relation in the current transaction,
    2386             :      * including open scans and pending AFTER trigger events.
    2387             :      */

    2390             : 
    2391             : /*
    2392             :  * storage_name
    2393             :  *    returns the name corresponding to a typstorage/attstorage enum value
    2394             :  */
    2395             : static const char *
    2396          24 : storage_name(char c)
    2397             : {
    2398          24 :     switch (c)
    2399             :     {
    2400           0 :         case TYPSTORAGE_PLAIN:
    2401           0 :             return "PLAIN";
    2402           0 :         case TYPSTORAGE_EXTERNAL:
    2403           0 :             return "EXTERNAL";
    2404          12 :         case TYPSTORAGE_EXTENDED:
    2405          12 :             return "EXTENDED";
    2406          12 :         case TYPSTORAGE_MAIN:
    2407          12 :             return "MAIN";
    2408           0 :         default:
    2409           0 :             return "???";
    2410             :     }
    2411             : }
    2412             : 
    2413             : /*----------
    2414             :  * MergeAttributes
    2415             :  *      Returns new schema given initial schema and superclasses.
    2416             :  *
    2417             :  * Input arguments:
    2418             :  * 'columns' is the column/attribute definition for the table. (It's a list
    2419             :  *      of ColumnDef's.) It is destructively changed.
    2420             :  * 'supers' is a list of OIDs of parent relations, already locked by caller.
    2421             :  * 'relpersistence' is the persistence type of the table.
    2422             :  * 'is_partition' tells if the table is a partition.
    2423             :  *
    2424             :  * Output arguments:
    2425             :  * 'supconstr' receives a list of constraints belonging to the parents,
    2426             :  *      updated as necessary to be valid for the child.
    2427             :  * 'supnotnulls' receives a list of CookedConstraints that corresponds to
    2428             :  *      constraints coming from inheritance parents.
    2429             :  *
    2430             :  * Return value:
    2431             :  * Completed schema list.
    2432             :  *
    2433             :  * Notes:
    2434             :  *    The order in which the attributes are inherited is very important.
    2435             :  *    Intuitively, the inherited attributes should come first. If a table
    2436             :  *    inherits from multiple parents, the order of those attributes are
    2437             :  *    according to the order of the parents specified in CREATE TABLE.
    2438             :  *
    2439             :  *    Here's an example:
    2440             :  *
    2441             :  *      create table person (name text, age int4, location point);
    2442             :  *      create table emp (salary int4, manager text) inherits(person);
    2443             :  *      create table student (gpa float8) inherits (person);
    2444             :  *      create table stud_emp (percent int4) inherits (emp, student);
    2445             :  *
    2446             :  *    The order of the attributes of stud_emp is:
    2447             :  *
    2448             :  *                          person {1:name, 2:age, 3:location}
    2449             :  *                          /    \
    2450             :  *             {6:gpa}  student   emp {4:salary, 5:manager}
    2451             :  *                          \    /
    2452             :  *                         stud_emp {7:percent}
    2453             :  *
    2454             :  *     If the same attribute name appears multiple times, then it appears
    2455             :  *     in the result table in the proper location for its first appearance.
    2456             :  *
    2457             :  *     Constraints (including not-null constraints) for the child table
    2458             :  *     are the union of all relevant constraints, from both the child schema
    2459             :  *     and parent tables.  In addition, in legacy inheritance, each column that
    2460             :  *     appears in a primary key in any of the parents also gets a NOT NULL
    2461             :  *     constraint (partitioning doesn't need this, because the PK itself gets
    2462             :  *     inherited.)
    2463             :  *
    2464             :  *     The default value for a child column is defined as:
    2465             :  *      (1) If the child schema specifies a default, that value is used.
    2466             :  *      (2) If neither the child nor any parent specifies a default, then
    2467             :  *          the column will not have a default.
    2468             :  *      (3) If conflicting defaults are inherited from different parents
    2469             :  *          (and not overridden by the child), an error is raised.
    2470             :  *      (4) Otherwise the inherited default is used.
    2471             :  *
    2472             :  *      Note that the default-value infrastructure is used for generated
    2473             :  *      columns' expressions too, so most of the preceding paragraph applies
    2474             :  *      to generation expressions too.  We insist that a child column be
    2475             :  *      generated if and only if its parent(s) are, but it need not have
    2476             :  *      the same generation expression.
    2477             :  *----------
    2478             :  */
    2479             : static List *
    2480       48138 : MergeAttributes(List *columns, const List *supers, char relpersistence,
    2481             :                 bool is_partition, List **supconstr, List **supnotnulls)
    2482             : {
    2483       48138 :     List       *inh_columns = NIL;
    2484       48138 :     List       *constraints = NIL;
    2485       48138 :     List       *nnconstraints = NIL;
    2486       48138 :     bool        have_bogus_defaults = false;
    2487             :     int         child_attno;
    2488             :     static Node bogus_marker = {0}; /* marks conflicting defaults */
    2489       48138 :     List       *saved_columns = NIL;
    2490             :     ListCell   *lc;
    2491             : 
    2492             :     /*
    2493             :      * Check for and reject tables with too many columns. We perform this
    2494             :      * check relatively early for two reasons: (a) we don't run the risk of
    2495             :      * overflowing an AttrNumber in subsequent code (b) an O(n^2) algorithm is
    2496             :      * okay if we're processing <= 1600 columns, but could take minutes to
    2497             :      * execute if the user attempts to create a table with hundreds of
    2498             :      * thousands of columns.
    2499             :      *
    2500             :      * Note that we also need to check that we do not exceed this figure after
    2501             :      * including columns from inherited relations.
    2502             :      */
    2503       48138 :     if (list_length(columns) > MaxHeapAttributeNumber)
    2504           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    2505             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_TOO_MANY_COLUMNS),
    2506             :                  errmsg("tables can have at most %d columns",
    2507             :                         MaxHeapAttributeNumber)));
    2508             : 
    2509             :     /*
    2510             :      * Check for duplicate names in the explicit list of attributes.
    2511             :      *
    2512             :      * Although we might consider merging such entries in the same way that we
    2513             :      * handle name conflicts for inherited attributes, it seems to make more
    2514             :      * sense to assume such conflicts are errors.
    2515             :      *
    2516             :      * We don't use foreach() here because we have two nested loops over the
    2517             :      * columns list, with possible element deletions in the inner one.  If we
    2518             :      * used foreach_delete_current() it could only fix up the state of one of
    2519             :      * the loops, so it seems cleaner to use looping over list indexes for
    2520             :      * both loops.  Note that any deletion will happen beyond where the outer
    2521             :      * loop is, so its index never needs adjustment.
    2522             :      */
    2523      213692 :     for (int coldefpos = 0; coldefpos < list_length(columns); coldefpos++)
    2524             :     {
    2525      165578 :         ColumnDef  *coldef = list_nth_node(ColumnDef, columns, coldefpos);
    2526             : 
    2527      165578 :         if (!is_partition && coldef->typeName == NULL)
    2528             :         {
    2529             :             /*
    2530             :              * Typed table column option that does not belong to a column from
    2531             :              * the type.  This works because the columns from the type come
    2532             :              * first in the list.  (We omit this check for partition column
    2533             :              * lists; those are processed separately below.)
    2534             :              */
    2535           6 :             ereport(ERROR,
    2536             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_COLUMN),
    2537             :                      errmsg("column \"%s\" does not exist",
    2538             :                             coldef->colname)));
    2539             :         }
    2540             : 
    2541             :         /* restpos scans all entries beyond coldef; incr is in loop body */
    2542     5922042 :         for (int restpos = coldefpos + 1; restpos < list_length(columns);)
    2543             :         {
    2544     5756488 :             ColumnDef  *restdef = list_nth_node(ColumnDef, columns, restpos);
    2545             : 
    2546     5756488 :             if (strcmp(coldef->colname, restdef->colname) == 0)
    2547             :             {
    2548          50 :                 if (coldef->is_from_type)
    2549             :                 {
    2550             :                     /*
    2551             :                      * merge the column options into the column from the type
    2552             :                      */
    2553          32 :                     coldef->is_not_null = restdef->is_not_null;
    2554          32 :                     coldef->raw_default = restdef->raw_default;
    2555          32 :                     coldef->cooked_default = restdef->cooked_default;
    2556          32 :                     coldef->constraints = restdef->constraints;
    2557          32 :                     coldef->is_from_type = false;
    2558          32 :                     columns = list_delete_nth_cell(columns, restpos);
    2559             :                 }
    2560             :                 else
    2561          18 :                     ereport(ERROR,
    2562             :                             (errcode(ERRCODE_DUPLICATE_COLUMN),
    2563             :                              errmsg("column \"%s\" specified more than once",
    2564             :                                     coldef->colname)));
    2565             :             }
    2566             :             else
    2567     5756438 :                 restpos++;
    2568             :         }
    2569             :     }
    2570             : 
    2571             :     /*
    2572             :      * In case of a partition, there are no new column definitions, only dummy
    2573             :      * ColumnDefs created for column constraints.  Set them aside for now and
    2574             :      * process them at the end.
    2575             :      */
    2576       48114 :     if (is_partition)
    2577             :     {
    2578        7446 :         saved_columns = columns;
    2579        7446 :         columns = NIL;
    2580             :     }
    2581             : 
    2582             :     /*
    2583             :      * Scan the parents left-to-right, and merge their attributes to form a
    2584             :      * list of inherited columns (inh_columns).
    2585             :      */
    2586       48114 :     child_attno = 0;
    2587       57506 :     foreach(lc, supers)
    2588             :     {
    2589        9458 :         Oid         parent = lfirst_oid(lc);
    2590             :         Relation    relation;
    2591             :         TupleDesc   tupleDesc;

    2598             :         ListCell   *lc2;

    2600        9458 :         Bitmapset  *nncols = NULL;
    2601             :

    2604             :

    2674             : 
    2675        9410 :         tupleDesc = RelationGetDescr(relation);

    2684             :

    2698       10162 :         foreach(lc1, nnconstrs)

    2700         752 :                                     ((CookedConstraint *) lfirst(lc1))->attnum);
    2701             : 
    2702       28408 :         for (AttrNumber parent_attno = 1; parent_attno <= tupleDesc->natts;

    2706             :                                                         parent_attno - 1);

    2857             :

    2861             :              * column as having a bogus default.  Below, we will complain if
    2862             :              * the bogus default isn't overridden by the child columns.

    2868             :             {
    2869          24 :                 def->cooked_default = &bogus_marker;
    2870          24 :                 have_bogus_defaults = true;

    2872             :         }
    2873             : 
    2874             :         /*
    2875             :          * Now copy the CHECK constraints of this parent, adjusting attnos
    2876             :          * using the completed newattmap map.  Identically named constraints
    2877             :          * are merged if possible, else we throw error.
    2878             :          */
    2879        9392 :         if (constr && constr->num_check > 0)
    2880             :         {
    2881         286 :             ConstrCheck *check = constr->check;
    2882             : 
    2883         602 :             for (int i = 0; i < constr->num_check; i++)
    2884             :             {

    3112             : 
    3113             : 
    3114             : /*
    3115             :  * MergeCheckConstraint
    3116             :  *      Try to merge an inherited CHECK constraint with previous ones
    3117             :  *
    3118             :  * If we inherit identically-named constraints from multiple parents, we must
    3119             :  * merge them, or throw an error if they don't have identical definitions.
    3120             :  *
    3121             :  * constraints is a list of CookedConstraint structs for previous constraints.
    3122             :  *
    3123             :  * If the new constraint matches an existing one, then the existing
    3124             :  * constraint's inheritance count is updated.  If there is a conflict (same
    3125             :  * name but different expression), throw an error.  If the constraint neither
    3126             :  * matches nor conflicts with an existing one, a new constraint is appended to
    3127             :  * the list.
    3128             :  */
    3129             : static List *
    3130         268 : MergeCheckConstraint(List *constraints, const char *name, Node *expr)
    3131             : {
    3132             :     ListCell   *lc;
    3133             :     CookedConstraint *newcon;
    3134             : 
    3135         298 :     foreach(lc, constraints)
    3136             :     {
    3137          72 :         CookedConstraint *ccon = (CookedConstraint *) lfirst(lc);
    3138             : 
    3139          72 :         Assert(ccon->contype == CONSTR_CHECK);
    3140             : 
    3141             :         /* Non-matching names never conflict */
    3142          72 :         if (strcmp(ccon->name, name) != 0)
    3143          30 :             continue;
    3144             : 
    3145          42 :         if (equal(expr, ccon->expr))
    3146             :         {
    3147             :             /* OK to merge constraint with existing */
    3148          42 :             ccon->inhcount++;
    3149          42 :             if (ccon->inhcount < 0)
    3150           0 :                 ereport(ERROR,
    3151             :                         errcode(ERRCODE_PROGRAM_LIMIT_EXCEEDED),
    3152             :                         errmsg("too many inheritance parents"));
    3153          42 :             return constraints;
    3154             :         }
    3155             : 
    3156           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    3157             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_DUPLICATE_OBJECT),
    3158             :                  errmsg("check constraint name \"%s\" appears multiple times but with different expressions",
    3159             :                         name)));
    3160             :     }
    3161             : 
    3162             :     /*
    3163             :      * Constraint couldn't be merged with an existing one and also didn't
    3164             :      * conflict with an existing one, so add it as a new one to the list.
    3165             :      */
    3166         226 :     newcon = palloc0_object(CookedConstraint);
    3167         226 :     newcon->contype = CONSTR_CHECK;
    3168         226 :     newcon->name = pstrdup(name);
    3169         226 :     newcon->expr = expr;
    3170         226 :     newcon->inhcount = 1;
    3171         226 :     return lappend(constraints, newcon);
    3172             : }
    3173             : 
    3174             : /*
    3175             :  * MergeChildAttribute
    3176             :  *      Merge given child attribute definition into given inherited attribute.
    3177             :  *
    3178             :  * Input arguments:
    3179             :  * 'inh_columns' is the list of inherited ColumnDefs.
    3180             :  * 'exist_attno' is the number of the inherited attribute in inh_columns
    3181             :  * 'newcol_attno' is the attribute number in child table's schema definition
    3182             :  * 'newdef' is the column/attribute definition from the child table.
    3183             :  *
    3184             :  * The ColumnDef in 'inh_columns' list is modified.  The child attribute's
    3185             :  * ColumnDef remains unchanged.
    3186             :  *
    3187             :  * Notes:
    3188             :  * - The attribute is merged according to the rules laid out in the prologue
    3189             :  *   of MergeAttributes().
    3190             :  * - If matching inherited attribute exists but the child attribute can not be
    3191             :  *   merged into it, the function throws respective errors.
    3192             :  * - A partition can not have its own column definitions. Hence this function
    3193             :  *   is applicable only to a regular inheritance child.
    3194             :  */
    3195             : static void
    3196         268 : MergeChildAttribute(List *inh_columns, int exist_attno, int newcol_attno, const ColumnDef *newdef)
    3197             : {
    3198         268 :     char       *attributeName = newdef->colname;
    3199             :     ColumnDef  *inhdef;
    3200             :     Oid         inhtypeid,
    3201             :                 newtypeid;
    3202             :     int32       inhtypmod,
    3203             :                 newtypmod;
    3204             :     Oid         inhcollid,
    3205             :                 newcollid;
    3206             : 
    3207         268 :     if (exist_attno == newcol_attno)
    3208         240 :         ereport(NOTICE,
    3209             :                 (errmsg("merging column \"%s\" with inherited definition",
    3210             :                         attributeName)));
    3211             :     else
    3212          28 :         ereport(NOTICE,
    3213             :                 (errmsg("moving and merging column \"%s\" with inherited definition", attributeName),

    3218             :     /*

    3222         268 :     typenameTypeIdAndMod(NULL, newdef->typeName, &newtypeid, &newtypmod);

    3224          12 :         ereport(ERROR,

    3281             :     /*
    3282             :      * Merge of not-null constraints = OR 'em together

    3284         238 :     inhdef->is_not_null |= newdef->is_not_null;
    3285             : 
    3286             :     /*
    3287             :      * Check for conflicts related to generated columns.
    3288             :      *
    3289             :      * If the parent column is generated, the child column will be made a
    3290             :      * generated column if it isn't already.  If it is a generated column,
    3291             :      * we'll take its generation expression in preference to the parent's.  We
    3292             :      * must check that the child column doesn't specify a default value or
    3293             :      * identity, which matches the rules for a single column in
    3294             :      * parse_utilcmd.c.
    3295             :      *
    3296             :      * Conversely, if the parent column is not generated, the child column
    3297             :      * can't be either.  (We used to allow that, but it results in being able
    3298             :      * to override the generation expression via UPDATEs through the parent.)
    3299             :      */
    3300         238 :     if (inhdef->generated)
    3301             :     {
    3302          26 :         if (newdef->raw_default && !newdef->generated)
    3303           6 :             ereport(ERROR,
    3304             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_COLUMN_DEFINITION),
    3305             :                      errmsg("column \"%s\" inherits from generated column but specifies default",
    3306             :                             inhdef->colname)));
    3307          20 :         if (newdef->identity)
    3308           6 :             ereport(ERROR,
    3309             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_COLUMN_DEFINITION),
    3310             :                      errmsg("column \"%s\" inherits from generated column but specifies identity",
    3311             :                             inhdef->colname)));
    3312             :     }
    3313             :     else
    3314             :     {
    3315         212 :         if (newdef->generated)
    3316           6 :             ereport(ERROR,
    3317             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_COLUMN_DEFINITION),
    3318             :                      errmsg("child column \"%s\" specifies generation expression",
    3319             :                             inhdef->colname),
    3320             :                      errhint("A child table column cannot be generated unless its parent column is.")));
    3321             :     }
    3322             : 
    3323             :     /*
    3324             :      * If new def has a default, override previous default
    3325             :      */

    3327             :     {
    3328          18 :         inhdef->raw_default = newdef->raw_default;
    3329          18 :         inhdef->cooked_default = newdef->cooked_default;

    3331             : 
    3332             :     /* Mark the column as locally defined */
    3333         220 :     inhdef->is_local = true;
