    3335             : 
    3336             : /*
    3337             :  * MergeInheritedAttribute
    3338             :  *      Merge given parent attribute definition into specified attribute
    3339             :  *      inherited from the previous parents.
    3340             :  *
    3341             :  * Input arguments:
    3342             :  * 'inh_columns' is the list of previously inherited ColumnDefs.
    3343             :  * 'exist_attno' is the number the existing matching attribute in inh_columns.
    3344             :  * 'newdef' is the new parent column/attribute definition to be merged.
    3345             :  *
    3346             :  * The matching ColumnDef in 'inh_columns' list is modified and returned.
    3347             :  *
    3348             :  * Notes:
    3349             :  * - The attribute is merged according to the rules laid out in the prologue
    3350             :  *   of MergeAttributes().
    3351             :  * - If matching inherited attribute exists but the new attribute can not be
    3352             :  *   merged into it, the function throws respective errors.
    3353             :  * - A partition inherits from only a single parent. Hence this function is
    3354             :  *   applicable only to a regular inheritance.
    3355             :  */
    3356             : static ColumnDef *
    3357         290 : MergeInheritedAttribute(List *inh_columns,
    3358             :                         int exist_attno,
    3359             :                         const ColumnDef *newdef)
    3360             : {
    3361         290 :     char       *attributeName = newdef->colname;
    3362             :     ColumnDef  *prevdef;
    3363             :     Oid         prevtypeid,
    3364             :                 newtypeid;
    3365             :     int32       prevtypmod,
    3366             :                 newtypmod;
    3367             :     Oid         prevcollid,
    3368             :                 newcollid;
    3369             : 
    3370         290 :     ereport(NOTICE,
    3371             :             (errmsg("merging multiple inherited definitions of column \"%s\"",
    3372             :                     attributeName)));
    3373         290 :     prevdef = list_nth_node(ColumnDef, inh_columns, exist_attno - 1);
    3374             : 
    3375             :     /*
    3376             :      * Must have the same type and typmod
    3377             :      */
    3378         290 :     typenameTypeIdAndMod(NULL, prevdef->typeName, &prevtypeid, &prevtypmod);
    3379         290 :     typenameTypeIdAndMod(NULL, newdef->typeName, &newtypeid, &newtypmod);
    3380         290 :     if (prevtypeid != newtypeid || prevtypmod != newtypmod)
    3381           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    3382             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_DATATYPE_MISMATCH),
    3383             :                  errmsg("inherited column \"%s\" has a type conflict",
    3384             :                         attributeName),
    3385             :                  errdetail("%s versus %s",
    3386             :                            format_type_with_typemod(prevtypeid, prevtypmod),
    3387             :                            format_type_with_typemod(newtypeid, newtypmod))));
    3388             : 
    3389             :     /*
    3390             :      * Must have the same collation
    3391             :      */
    3392         290 :     prevcollid = GetColumnDefCollation(NULL, prevdef, prevtypeid);
    3393         290 :     newcollid = GetColumnDefCollation(NULL, newdef, newtypeid);
    3394         290 :     if (prevcollid != newcollid)
    3395           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    3396             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_COLLATION_MISMATCH),
    3397             :                  errmsg("inherited column \"%s\" has a collation conflict",

    3563             : /*
    3564             :  * SetRelationHasSubclass
    3565             :  *      Set the value of the relation's relhassubclass field in pg_class.
    3566             :  *
    3567             :  * NOTE: caller must be holding an appropriate lock on the relation.
    3568             :  * ShareUpdateExclusiveLock is sufficient.
    3569             :  *
    3570             :  * NOTE: an important side-effect of this operation is that an SI invalidation
    3571             :  * message is sent out to all backends --- including me --- causing plans
    3572             :  * referencing the relation to be rebuilt with the new list of children.
    3573             :  * This must happen even if we find that no change is needed in the pg_class
    3574             :  * row.
    3575             :  */
    3576             : void
    3577       13778 : SetRelationHasSubclass(Oid relationId, bool relhassubclass)

    3585             :      */

    3587       13778 :     tuple = SearchSysCacheCopy1(RELOID, ObjectIdGetDatum(relationId));

    3589           0 :         elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for relation %u", relationId);

    3591             : 
    3592       13778 :     if (classtuple->relhassubclass != relhassubclass)
    3593             :     {

    3596             :     }

    3598             :     {
    3599             :         /* no need to change tuple, but force relcache rebuild anyway */

    3607             : /*
    3608             :  * CheckRelationTableSpaceMove
    3609             :  *      Check if relation can be moved to new tablespace.
    3610             :  *
    3611             :  * NOTE: The caller must hold AccessExclusiveLock on the relation.
    3612             :  *
    3613             :  * Returns true if the relation can be moved to the new tablespace; raises
    3614             :  * an error if it is not possible to do the move; returns false if the move
    3615             :  * would have no effect.
    3616             :  */
    3617             : bool

    3619             : {

    3633             :      * (In particular this eliminates all shared catalogs.)

    3659             : /*

    3713             : /*
    3714             :  *      renameatt_check         - basic sanity checks before attribute rename

    3727             :      * Renaming the columns of sequences or toast tables doesn't actually
    3728             :      * break anything from the system's point of view, since internal
    3729             :      * references are by attnum.  But it doesn't seem right to allow users to
    3730             :      * change names that are hardcoded into the system, hence the following
    3731             :      * restriction.

    3760             : /*
    3761             :  *      renameatt_internal      - workhorse for renameatt
    3762             :  *
    3763             :  * Return value is the attribute number in the 'myrelid' relation.
    3764             :  */
    3765             : static AttrNumber
    3766         540 : renameatt_internal(Oid myrelid,
    3767             :                    const char *oldattname,
    3768             :                    const char *newattname,
    3769             :                    bool recurse,
    3770             :                    bool recursing,
    3771             :                    int expected_parents,
    3772             :                    DropBehavior behavior)
    3773             : {
    3774             :     Relation    targetrelation;
    3775             :     Relation    attrelation;
    3776             :     HeapTuple   atttup;
    3777             :     Form_pg_attribute attform;
    3778             :     AttrNumber  attnum;
    3779             : 
    3780             :     /*
    3781             :      * Grab an exclusive lock on the target table, which we will NOT release
    3782             :      * until end of transaction.
    3783             :      */
    3784         540 :     targetrelation = relation_open(myrelid, AccessExclusiveLock);
    3785         540 :     renameatt_check(myrelid, RelationGetForm(targetrelation), recursing);
    3786             : 
    3787             :     /*
    3788             :      * if the 'recurse' flag is set then we are supposed to rename this
    3789             :      * attribute in all classes that inherit from 'relname' (as well as in
    3790             :      * 'relname').
    3791             :      *
    3792             :      * any permissions or problems with duplicate attributes will cause the
    3793             :      * whole transaction to abort, which is what we want -- all or nothing.
    3794             :      */
    3795         540 :     if (recurse)
    3796             :     {
    3797             :         List       *child_oids,
    3798             :                    *child_numparents;
    3799             :         ListCell   *lo,
    3800             :                    *li;
    3801             : 
    3802             :         /*
    3803             :          * we need the number of parents for each child so that the recursive
    3804             :          * calls to renameatt() can determine whether there are any parents
    3805             :          * outside the inheritance hierarchy being processed.
    3806             :          */
    3807         236 :         child_oids = find_all_inheritors(myrelid, AccessExclusiveLock,
    3808             :                                          &child_numparents);
    3809             : 
    3810             :         /*
    3811             :          * find_all_inheritors does the recursive search of the inheritance
    3812             :          * hierarchy, so all we have to do is process all of the relids in the
    3813             :          * list that it returns.
    3814             :          */
    3815         710 :         forboth(lo, child_oids, li, child_numparents)
    3816             :         {
    3817         504 :             Oid         childrelid = lfirst_oid(lo);
    3818         504 :             int         numparents = lfirst_int(li);
    3819             : 
    3820         504 :             if (childrelid == myrelid)
    3821         236 :                 continue;
    3822             :             /* note we need not recurse again */
    3823         268 :             renameatt_internal(childrelid, oldattname, newattname, false, true, numparents, behavior);
    3824             :         }
    3825             :     }
    3826             :     else
    3827             :     {
    3828             :         /*
    3829             :          * If we are told not to recurse, there had better not be any child
    3830             :          * tables; else the rename would put them out of step.
    3831             :          *
    3832             :          * expected_parents will only be 0 if we are not already recursing.
    3833             :          */
    3834         340 :         if (expected_parents == 0 &&
    3835          36 :             find_inheritance_children(myrelid, NoLock) != NIL)
    3836          12 :             ereport(ERROR,
    3837             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_TABLE_DEFINITION),

    3839             :                             oldattname)));
    3840             :     }
    3841             :

    3850             :                                                    behavior);
    3851             : 
    3852          24 :         foreach(lo, child_oids)
    3853           6 :             renameatt_internal(lfirst_oid(lo), oldattname, newattname, true, true, 0, behavior);
    3854             :     }
    3855             : 
    3856         492 :     attrelation = table_open(AttributeRelationId, RowExclusiveLock);

    3859         492 :     if (!HeapTupleIsValid(atttup))
    3860          24 :         ereport(ERROR,
    3861             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_COLUMN),
    3862             :                  errmsg("column \"%s\" does not exist",
    3863             :                         oldattname)));
    3864         468 :     attform = (Form_pg_attribute) GETSTRUCT(atttup);
    3865             : 
    3866         468 :     attnum = attform->attnum;
    3867         468 :     if (attnum <= 0)
    3868           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    3869             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
    3870             :                  errmsg("cannot rename system column \"%s\"",
    3871             :                         oldattname)));
    3872             : 
    3873             :     /*
    3874             :      * if the attribute is inherited, forbid the renaming.  if this is a
    3875             :      * top-level call to renameatt(), then expected_parents will be 0, so the
    3876             :      * effect of this code will be to prohibit the renaming if the attribute
    3877             :      * is inherited at all.  if this is a recursive call to renameatt(),
    3878             :      * expected_parents will be the number of parents the current relation has
    3879             :      * within the inheritance hierarchy being processed, so we'll prohibit the
    3880             :      * renaming only if there are additional parents from elsewhere.
    3881             :      */
    3882         468 :     if (attform->attinhcount > expected_parents)
    3883          30 :         ereport(ERROR,
    3884             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_TABLE_DEFINITION),
    3885             :                  errmsg("cannot rename inherited column \"%s\"",
    3886             :                         oldattname)));
    3887             : 
    3888             :     /* new name should not already exist */
    3889         438 :     (void) check_for_column_name_collision(targetrelation, newattname, false);
    3890             : 
    3891             :     /* apply the update */
    3892         426 :     namestrcpy(&(attform->attname), newattname);
    3893             : 
    3894         426 :     CatalogTupleUpdate(attrelation, &atttup->t_self, atttup);
    3895             : 
    3896         426 :     InvokeObjectPostAlterHook(RelationRelationId, myrelid, attnum);
    3897             : 
    3898         426 :     heap_freetuple(atttup);
    3899             : 
    3900         426 :     table_close(attrelation, RowExclusiveLock);
    3901             : 
    3902         426 :     relation_close(targetrelation, NoLock); /* close rel but keep lock */
    3903             : 
    3904         426 :     return attnum;
    3905             : }
    3906             : 
    3907             : /*

    4122             : 
    4123             : /*
    4124             :  * Execute ALTER TABLE/INDEX/SEQUENCE/VIEW/MATERIALIZED VIEW/FOREIGN TABLE
    4125             :  * RENAME
    4126             :  */
    4127             : ObjectAddress
    4128         510 : RenameRelation(RenameStmt *stmt)
    4129             : {
    4130         510 :     bool        is_index_stmt = stmt->renameType == OBJECT_INDEX;
    4131             :     Oid         relid;
    4132             :     ObjectAddress address;
    4133             : 
    4134             :     /*
    4135             :      * Grab an exclusive lock on the target table, index, sequence, view,
    4136             :      * materialized view, or foreign table, which we will NOT release until
    4137             :      * end of transaction.
    4138             :      *
    4139             :      * Lock level used here should match RenameRelationInternal, to avoid lock
    4140             :      * escalation.  However, because ALTER INDEX can be used with any relation
    4141             :      * type, we mustn't believe without verification.
    4142             :      */
    4143             :     for (;;)
    4144          12 :     {
    4145             :         LOCKMODE    lockmode;
    4146             :         char        relkind;
    4147             :         bool        obj_is_index;

    4150             :

    4152         522 :                                          stmt->missing_ok ? RVR_MISSING_OK : 0,

    4162             :         }

    4187             : 
    4188             : /*
    4189             :  *      RenameRelationInternal - change the name of a relation
    4190             :  */
    4191             : void
    4192        1264 : RenameRelationInternal(Oid myrelid, const char *newrelname, bool is_internal, bool is_index)
    4193             : {
    4194             :     Relation    targetrelation;
    4195             :     Relation    relrelation;    /* for RELATION relation */
    4196             :     HeapTuple   reltup;
    4197             :     Form_pg_class relform;
    4198             :     Oid         namespaceId;
    4199             : 
    4200             :     /*
    4201             :      * Grab a lock on the target relation, which we will NOT release until end
    4202             :      * of transaction.  We need at least a self-exclusive lock so that
    4203             :      * concurrent DDL doesn't overwrite the rename if they start updating
    4204             :      * while still seeing the old version.  The lock also guards against
    4205             :      * triggering relcache reloads in concurrent sessions, which might not
    4206             :      * handle this information changing under them.  For indexes, we can use a
    4207             :      * reduced lock level because RelationReloadIndexInfo() handles indexes
    4208             :      * specially.
    4209             :      */
    4210        1264 :     targetrelation = relation_open(myrelid, is_index ? ShareUpdateExclusiveLock : AccessExclusiveLock);
    4211        1264 :     namespaceId = RelationGetNamespace(targetrelation);
    4212             : 
    4213             :     /*
    4214             :      * Find relation's pg_class tuple, and make sure newrelname isn't in use.
    4215             :      */

    4217             :

    4225             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_DUPLICATE_TABLE),

    4252             :

    4277             : 
    4278             : /*
    4279             :  *      ResetRelRewrite - reset relrewrite
    4280             :  */
    4281             : void
    4282         394 : ResetRelRewrite(Oid myrelid)
    4283             : {
    4284             :     Relation    relrelation;    /* for RELATION relation */
    4285             :     HeapTuple   reltup;
    4286             :     Form_pg_class relform;
    4287             : 
    4288             :     /*
    4289             :      * Find relation's pg_class tuple.
    4290             :      */
    4291         394 :     relrelation = table_open(RelationRelationId, RowExclusiveLock);
    4292             : 
    4293         394 :     reltup = SearchSysCacheCopy1(RELOID, ObjectIdGetDatum(myrelid));
    4294         394 :     if (!HeapTupleIsValid(reltup))  /* shouldn't happen */
    4295           0 :         elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for relation %u", myrelid);
    4296         394 :     relform = (Form_pg_class) GETSTRUCT(reltup);
    4297             : 
    4298             :     /*
    4299             :      * Update pg_class tuple.
    4300             :      */
    4301         394 :     relform->relrewrite = InvalidOid;
    4302             : 
    4303         394 :     CatalogTupleUpdate(relrelation, &reltup->t_self, reltup);
    4304             : 
    4305         394 :     heap_freetuple(reltup);
    4306         394 :     table_close(relrelation, RowExclusiveLock);
    4307         394 : }
    4308             : 
    4309             : /*
    4310             :  * Disallow ALTER TABLE (and similar commands) when the current backend has
    4311             :  * any open reference to the target table besides the one just acquired by
    4312             :  * the calling command; this implies there's an open cursor or active plan.
    4313             :  * We need this check because our lock doesn't protect us against stomping
    4314             :  * on our own foot, only other people's feet!
    4315             :  *
    4316             :  * For ALTER TABLE, the only case known to cause serious trouble is ALTER
    4317             :  * COLUMN TYPE, and some changes are obviously pretty benign, so this could
    4318             :  * possibly be relaxed to only error out for certain types of alterations.
    4319             :  * But the use-case for allowing any of these things is not obvious, so we
    4320             :  * won't work hard at it for now.
    4321             :  *
    4322             :  * We also reject these commands if there are any pending AFTER trigger events
    4323             :  * for the rel.  This is certainly necessary for the rewriting variants of
    4324             :  * ALTER TABLE, because they don't preserve tuple TIDs and so the pending
    4325             :  * events would try to fetch the wrong tuples.  It might be overly cautious
    4326             :  * in other cases, but again it seems better to err on the side of paranoia.
    4327             :  *
    4328             :  * REINDEX calls this with "rel" referencing the index to be rebuilt; here
    4329             :  * we are worried about active indexscans on the index.  The trigger-event
    4330             :  * check can be skipped, since we are doing no damage to the parent table.
    4331             :  *
    4332             :  * The statement name (eg, "ALTER TABLE") is passed for use in error messages.
    4333             :  */
    4334             : void
    4335      124852 : CheckTableNotInUse(Relation rel, const char *stmt)
    4336             : {
    4337             :     int         expected_refcnt;
    4338             : 
    4339      124852 :     expected_refcnt = rel->rd_isnailed ? 2 : 1;
    4340      124852 :     if (rel->rd_refcnt != expected_refcnt)
    4341          24 :         ereport(ERROR,
    4342             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_IN_USE),
    4343             :         /* translator: first %s is a SQL command, eg ALTER TABLE */
    4344             :                  errmsg("cannot %s \"%s\" because it is being used by active queries in this session",
    4345             :                         stmt, RelationGetRelationName(rel))));
    4346             : 
    4347      124828 :     if (rel->rd_rel->relkind != RELKIND_INDEX &&
    4348      197416 :         rel->rd_rel->relkind != RELKIND_PARTITIONED_INDEX &&
    4349       97734 :         AfterTriggerPendingOnRel(RelationGetRelid(rel)))
    4350          18 :         ereport(ERROR,
    4351             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_IN_USE),
    4352             :         /* translator: first %s is a SQL command, eg ALTER TABLE */
    4353             :                  errmsg("cannot %s \"%s\" because it has pending trigger events",
    4354             :                         stmt, RelationGetRelationName(rel))));
    4355      124810 : }
    4356             : 
    4357             : /*
    4358             :  * AlterTableLookupRelation
    4359             :  *      Look up, and lock, the OID for the relation named by an alter table
    4360             :  *      statement.
    4361             :  */
    4362             : Oid
    4363       31002 : AlterTableLookupRelation(AlterTableStmt *stmt, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    4364             : {
    4365       61902 :     return RangeVarGetRelidExtended(stmt->relation, lockmode,
    4366       31002 :                                     stmt->missing_ok ? RVR_MISSING_OK : 0,
    4367             :                                     RangeVarCallbackForAlterRelation,
    4368             :                                     (void *) stmt);
    4369             : }
    4370             : 
    4371             : /*
    4372             :  * AlterTable
    4373             :  *      Execute ALTER TABLE, which can be a list of subcommands
    4374             :  *
    4375             :  * ALTER TABLE is performed in three phases:
    4376             :  *      1. Examine subcommands and perform pre-transformation checking.
    4377             :  *      2. Validate and transform subcommands, and update system catalogs.
    4378             :  *      3. Scan table(s) to check new constraints, and optionally recopy
    4379             :  *         the data into new table(s).
    4380             :  * Phase 3 is not performed unless one or more of the subcommands requires
    4381             :  * it.  The intention of this design is to allow multiple independent
    4382             :  * updates of the table schema to be performed with only one pass over the
    4383             :  * data.
    4384             :  *
    4385             :  * ATPrepCmd performs phase 1.  A "work queue" entry is created for
    4386             :  * each table to be affected (there may be multiple affected tables if the
    4387             :  * commands traverse a table inheritance hierarchy).  Also we do preliminary
    4388             :  * validation of the subcommands.  Because earlier subcommands may change
    4389             :  * the catalog state seen by later commands, there are limits to what can
    4390             :  * be done in this phase.  Generally, this phase acquires table locks,
    4391             :  * checks permissions and relkind, and recurses to find child tables.
    4392             :  *
    4393             :  * ATRewriteCatalogs performs phase 2 for each affected table.
    4394             :  * Certain subcommands need to be performed before others to avoid
    4395             :  * unnecessary conflicts; for example, DROP COLUMN should come before
    4396             :  * ADD COLUMN.  Therefore phase 1 divides the subcommands into multiple
    4397             :  * lists, one for each logical "pass" of phase 2.
    4398             :  *
    4399             :  * ATRewriteTables performs phase 3 for those tables that need it.
    4400             :  *
    4401             :  * For most subcommand types, phases 2 and 3 do no explicit recursion,
    4402             :  * since phase 1 already does it.  However, for certain subcommand types
    4403             :  * it is only possible to determine how to recurse at phase 2 time; for
    4404             :  * those cases, phase 1 sets the cmd->recurse flag.
    4405             :  *
    4406             :  * Thanks to the magic of MVCC, an error anywhere along the way rolls back
    4407             :  * the whole operation; we don't have to do anything special to clean up.
    4408             :  *
    4409             :  * The caller must lock the relation, with an appropriate lock level
    4410             :  * for the subcommands requested, using AlterTableGetLockLevel(stmt->cmds)
    4411             :  * or higher. We pass the lock level down
    4412             :  * so that we can apply it recursively to inherited tables. Note that the
    4413             :  * lock level we want as we recurse might well be higher than required for
    4414             :  * that specific subcommand. So we pass down the overall lock requirement,
    4415             :  * rather than reassess it at lower levels.
    4416             :  *
    4417             :  * The caller also provides a "context" which is to be passed back to
    4418             :  * utility.c when we need to execute a subcommand such as CREATE INDEX.
    4419             :  * Some of the fields therein, such as the relid, are used here as well.
    4420             :  */
    4421             : void
    4422       30762 : AlterTable(AlterTableStmt *stmt, LOCKMODE lockmode,
    4423             :            AlterTableUtilityContext *context)
    4424             : {
    4425             :     Relation    rel;
    4426             : 
    4427             :     /* Caller is required to provide an adequate lock. */
    4428       30762 :     rel = relation_open(context->relid, NoLock);
    4429             : 
    4430       30762 :     CheckTableNotInUse(rel, "ALTER TABLE");
    4431             : 
    4432       30744 :     ATController(stmt, rel, stmt->cmds, stmt->relation->inh, lockmode, context);
    4433       27890 : }
    4434             : 
    4435             : /*
    4436             :  * AlterTableInternal
    4437             :  *
    4438             :  * ALTER TABLE with target specified by OID
    4439             :  *
    4440             :  * We do not reject if the relation is already open, because it's quite
    4441             :  * likely that one or more layers of caller have it open.  That means it
    4442             :  * is unsafe to use this entry point for alterations that could break
    4443             :  * existing query plans.  On the assumption it's not used for such, we
    4444             :  * don't have to reject pending AFTER triggers, either.
    4445             :  *
    4446             :  * Also, since we don't have an AlterTableUtilityContext, this cannot be
    4447             :  * used for any subcommand types that require parse transformation or
    4448             :  * could generate subcommands that have to be passed to ProcessUtility.
    4449             :  */
    4450             : void
    4451         278 : AlterTableInternal(Oid relid, List *cmds, bool recurse)
    4452             : {
    4453             :     Relation    rel;
    4454         278 :     LOCKMODE    lockmode = AlterTableGetLockLevel(cmds);
    4455             : 
    4456         278 :     rel = relation_open(relid, lockmode);
    4457             : 
    4458         278 :     EventTriggerAlterTableRelid(relid);
    4459             : 
    4460         278 :     ATController(NULL, rel, cmds, recurse, lockmode, NULL);
    4461         278 : }
    4462             : 
    4463             : /*
    4464             :  * AlterTableGetLockLevel
    4465             :  *
    4466             :  * Sets the overall lock level required for the supplied list of subcommands.
    4467             :  * Policy for doing this set according to needs of AlterTable(), see
    4468             :  * comments there for overall explanation.
    4469             :  *
    4470             :  * Function is called before and after parsing, so it must give same
    4471             :  * answer each time it is called. Some subcommands are transformed
    4472             :  * into other subcommand types, so the transform must never be made to a
    4473             :  * lower lock level than previously assigned. All transforms are noted below.
    4474             :  *
    4475             :  * Since this is called before we lock the table we cannot use table metadata
    4476             :  * to influence the type of lock we acquire.
    4477             :  *
    4478             :  * There should be no lockmodes hardcoded into the subcommand functions. All
    4479             :  * lockmode decisions for ALTER TABLE are made here only. The one exception is
    4480             :  * ALTER TABLE RENAME which is treated as a different statement type T_RenameStmt
    4481             :  * and does not travel through this section of code and cannot be combined with
    4482             :  * any of the subcommands given here.
    4483             :  *
    4484             :  * Note that Hot Standby only knows about AccessExclusiveLocks on the primary
    4485             :  * so any changes that might affect SELECTs running on standbys need to use
    4486             :  * AccessExclusiveLocks even if you think a lesser lock would do, unless you
    4487             :  * have a solution for that also.
    4488             :  *
    4489             :  * Also note that pg_dump uses only an AccessShareLock, meaning that anything
    4490             :  * that takes a lock less than AccessExclusiveLock can change object definitions
    4491             :  * while pg_dump is running. Be careful to check that the appropriate data is
    4492             :  * derived by pg_dump using an MVCC snapshot, rather than syscache lookups,
    4493             :  * otherwise we might end up with an inconsistent dump that can't restore.
    4494             :  */
    4495             : LOCKMODE
    4496       31280 : AlterTableGetLockLevel(List *cmds)
    4497             : {
    4498             :     /*
    4499             :      * This only works if we read catalog tables using MVCC snapshots.
    4500             :      */
    4501             :     ListCell   *lcmd;
    4502       31280 :     LOCKMODE    lockmode = ShareUpdateExclusiveLock;
    4503             : 
    4504       64186 :     foreach(lcmd, cmds)
    4505             :     {
    4506       32906 :         AlterTableCmd *cmd = (AlterTableCmd *) lfirst(lcmd);
    4507       32906 :         LOCKMODE    cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock; /* default for compiler */
    4508             : 
    4509       32906 :         switch (cmd->subtype)
    4510             :         {
    4511             :                 /*
    4512             :                  * These subcommands rewrite the heap, so require full locks.

    4515             :                                  * to SELECT */
    4516             :             case AT_SetAccessMethod:    /* must rewrite heap */
    4517             :             case AT_SetTableSpace:  /* must rewrite heap */
    4518             :             case AT_AlterColumnType:    /* must rewrite heap */
    4519        3122 :                 cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;
    4520        3122 :                 break;

    4528         208 :             case AT_SetStorage: /* may add toast tables, see

    4538        1066 :             case AT_DropConstraint: /* as DROP INDEX */

    4551             :             case AT_EnableRule: /* may change SELECT rules */
    4552             :             case AT_DisableRule:    /* may change SELECT rules */

    4649             :                 /*

    4651             :                  * started before us will continue to see the old inheritance

    4653             :                  * new behaviour. No need to prevent reads or writes to the

    4681             :                 /*
    4682             :                  * These subcommands affect general strategies for performance
    4683             :                  * and maintenance, though don't change the semantic results
    4684             :                  * from normal data reads and writes. Delaying an ALTER TABLE
    4685             :                  * behind currently active writes only delays the point where
    4686             :                  * the new strategy begins to take effect, so there is no
    4687             :                  * benefit in waiting. In this case the minimum restriction
    4688             :                  * applies: we don't currently allow concurrent catalog
    4689             :                  * updates.

    4751             : 
    4752             : /*
    4753             :  * ATController provides top level control over the phases.
    4754             :  *
    4755             :  * parsetree is passed in to allow it to be passed to event triggers
    4756             :  * when requested.
    4757             :  */
    4758             : static void
    4759       31022 : ATController(AlterTableStmt *parsetree,
    4760             :              Relation rel, List *cmds, bool recurse, LOCKMODE lockmode,
    4761             :              AlterTableUtilityContext *context)
    4762             : {
    4763       31022 :     List       *wqueue = NIL;
    4764             :     ListCell   *lcmd;
    4765             : 
    4766             :     /* Phase 1: preliminary examination of commands, create work queue */
    4767       63392 :     foreach(lcmd, cmds)
    4768             :     {
    4769       32642 :         AlterTableCmd *cmd = (AlterTableCmd *) lfirst(lcmd);
    4770             : 
    4771       32642 :         ATPrepCmd(&wqueue, rel, cmd, recurse, false, lockmode, context);
    4772             :     }
    4773             : 
    4774             :     /* Close the relation, but keep lock until commit */
    4775       30750 :     relation_close(rel, NoLock);
    4776             : 
    4777             :     /* Phase 2: update system catalogs */
    4778       30750 :     ATRewriteCatalogs(&wqueue, lockmode, context);
    4779             : 
    4780             :     /* Phase 3: scan/rewrite tables as needed, and run afterStmts */
    4781       28480 :     ATRewriteTables(parsetree, &wqueue, lockmode, context);
    4782       28168 : }
    4783             : 
    4784             : /*
    4785             :  * ATPrepCmd
    4786             :  *
    4787             :  * Traffic cop for ALTER TABLE Phase 1 operations, including simple
    4788             :  * recursion and permission checks.
    4789             :  *
    4790             :  * Caller must have acquired appropriate lock type on relation already.
    4791             :  * This lock should be held until commit.
    4792             :  */
    4793             : static void
    4794       33258 : ATPrepCmd(List **wqueue, Relation rel, AlterTableCmd *cmd,
    4795             :           bool recurse, bool recursing, LOCKMODE lockmode,
    4796             :           AlterTableUtilityContext *context)
    4797             : {
    4798             :     AlteredTableInfo *tab;
    4799       33258 :     AlterTablePass pass = AT_PASS_UNSET;
    4800             : 
    4801             :     /* Find or create work queue entry for this table */
    4802       33258 :     tab = ATGetQueueEntry(wqueue, rel);
    4803             : 
    4804             :     /*
    4805             :      * Disallow any ALTER TABLE other than ALTER TABLE DETACH FINALIZE on
    4806             :      * partitions that are pending detach.
    4807             :      */
    4808       33258 :     if (rel->rd_rel->relispartition &&
    4809        2532 :         cmd->subtype != AT_DetachPartitionFinalize &&
    4810        1266 :         PartitionHasPendingDetach(RelationGetRelid(rel)))
    4811           2 :         ereport(ERROR,
    4812             :                 errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),
    4813             :                 errmsg("cannot alter partition \"%s\" with an incomplete detach",
    4814             :                        RelationGetRelationName(rel)),
    4815             :                 errhint("Use ALTER TABLE ... DETACH PARTITION ... FINALIZE to complete the pending detach operation."));
    4816             : 
    4817             :     /*
    4818             :      * Copy the original subcommand for each table, so we can scribble on it.
    4819             :      * This avoids conflicts when different child tables need to make
    4820             :      * different parse transformations (for example, the same column may have
    4821             :      * different column numbers in different children).
    4822             :      */
    4823       33256 :     cmd = copyObject(cmd);
    4824             : 
    4825             :     /*
    4826             :      * Do permissions and relkind checking, recursion to child tables if
    4827             :      * needed, and any additional phase-1 processing needed.  (But beware of
    4828             :      * adding any processing that looks at table details that another
    4829             :      * subcommand could change.  In some cases we reject multiple subcommands
    4830             :      * that could try to change the same state in contrary ways.)
    4831             :      */
    4832       33256 :     switch (cmd->subtype)
    4833             :     {
    4834        1946 :         case AT_AddColumn:      /* ADD COLUMN */
    4835        1946 :             ATSimplePermissions(cmd->subtype, rel,
    4836             :                                 ATT_TABLE | ATT_COMPOSITE_TYPE | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    4837        1946 :             ATPrepAddColumn(wqueue, rel, recurse, recursing, false, cmd,
    4838             :                             lockmode, context);
    4839             :             /* Recursion occurs during execution phase */
    4840        1934 :             pass = AT_PASS_ADD_COL;
    4841        1934 :             break;
    4842          24 :         case AT_AddColumnToView:    /* add column via CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW */
    4843          24 :             ATSimplePermissions(cmd->subtype, rel, ATT_VIEW);
    4844          24 :             ATPrepAddColumn(wqueue, rel, recurse, recursing, true, cmd,
    4845             :                             lockmode, context);
    4846             :             /* Recursion occurs during execution phase */
    4847          24 :             pass = AT_PASS_ADD_COL;
    4848          24 :             break;
    4849         566 :         case AT_ColumnDefault:  /* ALTER COLUMN DEFAULT */
    4850             : 
    4851             :             /*
    4852             :              * We allow defaults on views so that INSERT into a view can have
    4853             :              * default-ish behavior.  This works because the rewriter
    4854             :              * substitutes default values into INSERTs before it expands
    4855             :              * rules.
    4856             :              */
    4857         566 :             ATSimplePermissions(cmd->subtype, rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_VIEW | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);

    4859             :             /* No command-specific prep needed */
    4860         566 :             pass = cmd->def ? AT_PASS_ADD_OTHERCONSTR : AT_PASS_DROP;
    4861         566 :             break;
    4862          56 :         case AT_CookedColumnDefault:    /* add a pre-cooked default */

    4864             :             /* (so the permission check really isn't necessary) */

    4867          56 :             pass = AT_PASS_ADD_OTHERCONSTR;
    4868          56 :             break;
    4869         154 :         case AT_AddIdentity:

    4872         154 :             if (recurse)
    4873         148 :                 cmd->recurse = true;
    4874         154 :             pass = AT_PASS_ADD_OTHERCONSTR;
    4875         154 :             break;
    4876          62 :         case AT_SetIdentity:
    4877          62 :             ATSimplePermissions(cmd->subtype, rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_VIEW | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    4878             :             /* Set up recursion for phase 2; no other prep needed */
    4879          62 :             if (recurse)
    4880          56 :                 cmd->recurse = true;
    4881             :             /* This should run after AddIdentity, so do it in MISC pass */
    4882          62 :             pass = AT_PASS_MISC;
    4883          62 :             break;
    4884          56 :         case AT_DropIdentity:
    4885          56 :             ATSimplePermissions(cmd->subtype, rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_VIEW | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);

    4887          56 :             if (recurse)
    4888          50 :                 cmd->recurse = true;
    4889          56 :             pass = AT_PASS_DROP;
    4890          56 :             break;
    4891         238 :         case AT_DropNotNull:    /* ALTER COLUMN DROP NOT NULL */
    4892         238 :             ATSimplePermissions(cmd->subtype, rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    4893             :             /* Set up recursion for phase 2; no other prep needed */
    4894         232 :             if (recurse)
    4895         220 :                 cmd->recurse = true;
    4896         232 :             pass = AT_PASS_DROP;
    4897         232 :             break;
    4898         354 :         case AT_SetNotNull:     /* ALTER COLUMN SET NOT NULL */

    5172             : 
    5173             : /*
    5174             :  * ATRewriteCatalogs
    5175             :  *
    5176             :  * Traffic cop for ALTER TABLE Phase 2 operations.  Subcommands are
    5177             :  * dispatched in a "safe" execution order (designed to avoid unnecessary
    5178             :  * conflicts).
    5179             :  */
    5180             : static void
    5181       30750 : ATRewriteCatalogs(List **wqueue, LOCKMODE lockmode,
    5182             :                   AlterTableUtilityContext *context)
    5183             : {
    5184             :     ListCell   *ltab;
    5185             : 
    5186             :     /*
    5187             :      * We process all the tables "in parallel", one pass at a time.  This is
    5188             :      * needed because we may have to propagate work from one table to another
    5189             :      * (specifically, ALTER TYPE on a foreign key's PK has to dispatch the
    5190             :      * re-adding of the foreign key constraint to the other table).  Work can
    5191             :      * only be propagated into later passes, however.
    5192             :      */
    5193      389152 :     for (AlterTablePass pass = 0; pass < AT_NUM_PASSES; pass++)
    5194             :     {
    5195             :         /* Go through each table that needs to be processed */
    5196      732606 :         foreach(ltab, *wqueue)
    5197             :         {
    5198      374204 :             AlteredTableInfo *tab = (AlteredTableInfo *) lfirst(ltab);
    5199      374204 :             List       *subcmds = tab->subcmds[pass];
    5200             :             ListCell   *lcmd;
    5201             : 
    5202      374204 :             if (subcmds == NIL)
    5203      326900 :                 continue;
    5204             : 
    5205             :             /*
    5206             :              * Open the relation and store it in tab.  This allows subroutines
    5207             :              * close and reopen, if necessary.  Appropriate lock was obtained
    5208             :              * by phase 1, needn't get it again.
    5209             :              */
    5210       47304 :             tab->rel = relation_open(tab->relid, NoLock);
    5211             : 
    5212       95316 :             foreach(lcmd, subcmds)
    5213       50282 :                 ATExecCmd(wqueue, tab,
    5214       50282 :                           lfirst_node(AlterTableCmd, lcmd),
    5215             :                           lockmode, pass, context);
    5216             : 
    5217             :             /*
    5218             :              * After the ALTER TYPE or SET EXPRESSION pass, do cleanup work
    5219             :              * (this is not done in ATExecAlterColumnType since it should be
    5220             :              * done only once if multiple columns of a table are altered).
    5221             :              */
    5222       45034 :             if (pass == AT_PASS_ALTER_TYPE || pass == AT_PASS_SET_EXPRESSION)
    5223         944 :                 ATPostAlterTypeCleanup(wqueue, tab, lockmode);
    5224             : 
    5225       45034 :             if (tab->rel)
    5226             :             {
    5227       45034 :                 relation_close(tab->rel, NoLock);
    5228       45034 :                 tab->rel = NULL;
    5229             :             }
    5230             :         }
    5231             :     }
    5232             : 
    5233             :     /* Check to see if a toast table must be added. */
    5234       60564 :     foreach(ltab, *wqueue)
    5235             :     {
    5236       32084 :         AlteredTableInfo *tab = (AlteredTableInfo *) lfirst(ltab);
    5237             : 
    5238             :         /*
    5239             :          * If the table is source table of ATTACH PARTITION command, we did
    5240             :          * not modify anything about it that will change its toasting
    5241             :          * requirement, so no need to check.
    5242             :          */
    5243       32084 :         if (((tab->relkind == RELKIND_RELATION ||
    5244        6010 :               tab->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE) &&

    5247       28470 :             AlterTableCreateToastTable(tab->relid, (Datum) 0, lockmode);
    5248             :     }
    5249       28480 : }
    5250             : 
    5251             : /*
    5252             :  * ATExecCmd: dispatch a subcommand to appropriate execution routine
    5253             :  */
    5254             : static void
    5255       50282 : ATExecCmd(List **wqueue, AlteredTableInfo *tab,
    5256             :           AlterTableCmd *cmd, LOCKMODE lockmode, AlterTablePass cur_pass,
    5257             :           AlterTableUtilityContext *context)
    5258             : {
    5259       50282 :     ObjectAddress address = InvalidObjectAddress;

    5261             : 
    5262       50282 :     switch (cmd->subtype)

    5569             : 
    5570             : /*
    5571             :  * ATParseTransformCmd: perform parse transformation for one subcommand
    5572             :  *
    5573             :  * Returns the transformed subcommand tree, if there is one, else NULL.
    5574             :  *
    5575             :  * The parser may hand back additional AlterTableCmd(s) and/or other
    5576             :  * utility statements, either before or after the original subcommand.
    5577             :  * Other AlterTableCmds are scheduled into the appropriate slot of the
    5578             :  * AlteredTableInfo (they had better be for later passes than the current one).
    5579             :  * Utility statements that are supposed to happen before the AlterTableCmd
    5580             :  * are executed immediately.  Those that are supposed to happen afterwards
    5581             :  * are added to the tab->afterStmts list to be done at the very end.
    5582             :  */
    5583             : static AlterTableCmd *
    5584       16816 : ATParseTransformCmd(List **wqueue, AlteredTableInfo *tab, Relation rel,
    5585             :                     AlterTableCmd *cmd, bool recurse, LOCKMODE lockmode,
    5586             :                     AlterTablePass cur_pass, AlterTableUtilityContext *context)
    5587             : {
    5588       16816 :     AlterTableCmd *newcmd = NULL;
    5589       16816 :     AlterTableStmt *atstmt = makeNode(AlterTableStmt);
    5590             :     List       *beforeStmts;
    5591             :     List       *afterStmts;
    5592             :     ListCell   *lc;
    5593             : 
    5594             :     /* Gin up an AlterTableStmt with just this subcommand and this table */
    5595       16816 :     atstmt->relation =
    5596       16816 :         makeRangeVar(get_namespace_name(RelationGetNamespace(rel)),
    5597       16816 :                      pstrdup(RelationGetRelationName(rel)),
    5598             :                      -1);
    5599       16816 :     atstmt->relation->inh = recurse;
    5600       16816 :     atstmt->cmds = list_make1(cmd);
    5601       16816 :     atstmt->objtype = OBJECT_TABLE; /* needn't be picky here */
    5602       16816 :     atstmt->missing_ok = false;
    5603             : 
    5604             :     /* Transform the AlterTableStmt */
    5605       16816 :     atstmt = transformAlterTableStmt(RelationGetRelid(rel),
    5606             :                                      atstmt,
    5607             :                                      context->queryString,
    5608             :                                      &beforeStmts,
    5609             :                                      &afterStmts);
    5610             : 
    5611             :     /* Execute any statements that should happen before these subcommand(s) */
    5612       17176 :     foreach(lc, beforeStmts)
    5613             :     {
    5614         438 :         Node       *stmt = (Node *) lfirst(lc);
    5615             : 
    5616         438 :         ProcessUtilityForAlterTable(stmt, context);
    5617         426 :         CommandCounterIncrement();
    5618             :     }
    5619             : 
    5620             :     /* Examine the transformed subcommands and schedule them appropriately */
    5621       39562 :     foreach(lc, atstmt->cmds)
    5622             :     {
    5623       22824 :         AlterTableCmd *cmd2 = lfirst_node(AlterTableCmd, lc);
    5624             :         AlterTablePass pass;
    5625             : 
    5626             :         /*
    5627             :          * This switch need only cover the subcommand types that can be added
    5628             :          * by parse_utilcmd.c; otherwise, we'll use the default strategy of
    5629             :          * executing the subcommand immediately, as a substitute for the
    5630             :          * original subcommand.  (Note, however, that this does cause
    5631             :          * AT_AddConstraint subcommands to be rescheduled into later passes,
    5632             :          * which is important for index and foreign key constraints.)
    5633             :          *
    5634             :          * We assume we needn't do any phase-1 checks for added subcommands.
    5635             :          */
    5636       22824 :         switch (cmd2->subtype)
    5637             :         {
    5638        5780 :             case AT_SetAttNotNull:
    5639        5780 :                 ATSimpleRecursion(wqueue, rel, cmd2, recurse, lockmode, context);
    5640        5780 :                 pass = AT_PASS_COL_ATTRS;
    5641        5780 :                 break;
    5642        1002 :             case AT_AddIndex:
    5643             : 
    5644             :                 /*
    5645             :                  * A primary key on a inheritance parent needs supporting NOT
    5646             :                  * NULL constraint on its children; enqueue commands to create
    5647             :                  * those or mark them inherited if they already exist.
    5648             :                  */
    5649        1002 :                 ATPrepAddPrimaryKey(wqueue, rel, cmd2, lockmode, context);
    5650        1002 :                 pass = AT_PASS_ADD_INDEX;
    5651        1002 :                 break;
    5652        6674 :             case AT_AddIndexConstraint:
    5653             :                 /* as above */
    5654        6674 :                 ATPrepAddPrimaryKey(wqueue, rel, cmd2, lockmode, context);
    5655        6674 :                 pass = AT_PASS_ADD_INDEXCONSTR;
    5656        6674 :                 break;
    5657        3226 :             case AT_AddConstraint:
    5658             :                 /* Recursion occurs during execution phase */
    5659        3226 :                 if (recurse)
    5660        3184 :                     cmd2->recurse = true;
    5661        3226 :                 switch (castNode(Constraint, cmd2->def)->contype)
    5662             :                 {
    5663           0 :                     case CONSTR_PRIMARY:
    5664             :                     case CONSTR_UNIQUE:

    5666           0 :                         pass = AT_PASS_ADD_INDEXCONSTR;
    5667           0 :                         break;
    5668        3226 :                     default:
    5669        3226 :                         pass = AT_PASS_ADD_OTHERCONSTR;
    5670        3226 :                         break;
    5671             :                 }
    5672        3226 :                 break;
    5673           0 :             case AT_AlterColumnGenericOptions:
    5674             :                 /* This command never recurses */
    5675             :                 /* No command-specific prep needed */
    5676           0 :                 pass = AT_PASS_MISC;
    5677           0 :                 break;
    5678        6142 :             default:
    5679        6142 :                 pass = cur_pass;
    5680        6142 :                 break;
    5681             :         }
    5682             : 
    5683       22824 :         if (pass < cur_pass)
    5684             :         {
    5685             :             /* Cannot schedule into a pass we already finished */
    5686           0 :             elog(ERROR, "ALTER TABLE scheduling failure: too late for pass %d",
    5687             :                  pass);
    5688             :         }
    5689       22824 :         else if (pass > cur_pass)
    5690             :         {
    5691             :             /* OK, queue it up for later */
    5692       16682 :             tab->subcmds[pass] = lappend(tab->subcmds[pass], cmd2);
    5693             :         }
    5694             :         else
    5695             :         {
    5696             :             /*
    5697             :              * We should see at most one subcommand for the current pass,
    5698             :              * which is the transformed version of the original subcommand.
    5699             :              */
    5700        6142 :             if (newcmd == NULL && cmd->subtype == cmd2->subtype)
    5701             :             {
    5702             :                 /* Found the transformed version of our subcommand */
    5703        6142 :                 newcmd = cmd2;
    5704             :             }
    5705             :             else
    5706           0 :                 elog(ERROR, "ALTER TABLE scheduling failure: bogus item for pass %d",
    5707             :                      pass);
    5708             :         }
    5709             :     }
    5710             : 
    5711             :     /* Queue up any after-statements to happen at the end */
    5712       16738 :     tab->afterStmts = list_concat(tab->afterStmts, afterStmts);
    5713             : 
    5714       16738 :     return newcmd;
    5715             : }
    5716             : 
    5717             : /*
    5718             :  * ATRewriteTables: ALTER TABLE phase 3
    5719             :  */
    5720             : static void
    5721       28480 : ATRewriteTables(AlterTableStmt *parsetree, List **wqueue, LOCKMODE lockmode,
    5722             :                 AlterTableUtilityContext *context)
    5723             : {
    5724             :     ListCell   *ltab;
    5725             : 
    5726             :     /* Go through each table that needs to be checked or rewritten */
    5727       60308 :     foreach(ltab, *wqueue)
    5728             :     {
    5729       32072 :         AlteredTableInfo *tab = (AlteredTableInfo *) lfirst(ltab);
    5730             : 
    5731             :         /* Relations without storage may be ignored here */
    5732       32072 :         if (!RELKIND_HAS_STORAGE(tab->relkind))
    5733        5736 :             continue;
    5734             : 
    5735             :         /*
    5736             :          * If we change column data types, the operation has to be propagated
    5737             :          * to tables that use this table's rowtype as a column type.
    5738             :          * tab->newvals will also be non-NULL in the case where we're adding a
    5739             :          * column with a default.  We choose to forbid that case as well,
    5740             :          * since composite types might eventually support defaults.
    5741             :          *
    5742             :          * (Eventually we'll probably need to check for composite type
    5743             :          * dependencies even when we're just scanning the table without a
    5744             :          * rewrite, but at the moment a composite type does not enforce any
    5745             :          * constraints, so it's not necessary/appropriate to enforce them just
    5746             :          * during ALTER.)
    5747             :          */
    5748       26336 :         if (tab->newvals != NIL || tab->rewrite > 0)
    5749             :         {
    5750             :             Relation    rel;
    5751             : 
    5752        1432 :             rel = table_open(tab->relid, NoLock);
    5753        1432 :             find_composite_type_dependencies(rel->rd_rel->reltype, rel, NULL);
    5754        1420 :             table_close(rel, NoLock);
    5755             :         }
    5756             : 
    5757             :         /*
    5758             :          * We only need to rewrite the table if at least one column needs to
    5759             :          * be recomputed, or we are changing its persistence or access method.
    5760             :          *
    5761             :          * There are two reasons for requiring a rewrite when changing
    5762             :          * persistence: on one hand, we need to ensure that the buffers
    5763             :          * belonging to each of the two relations are marked with or without
    5764             :          * BM_PERMANENT properly.  On the other hand, since rewriting creates
    5765             :          * and assigns a new relfilenumber, we automatically create or drop an
    5766             :          * init fork for the relation as appropriate.
    5767             :          */
    5768       26324 :         if (tab->rewrite > 0 && tab->relkind != RELKIND_SEQUENCE)
    5769         826 :         {
    5770             :             /* Build a temporary relation and copy data */
    5771             :             Relation    OldHeap;
    5772             :             Oid         OIDNewHeap;
    5773             :             Oid         NewAccessMethod;
    5774             :             Oid         NewTableSpace;
    5775             :             char        persistence;
    5776             : 
    5777         864 :             OldHeap = table_open(tab->relid, NoLock);
    5778             : 
    5779             :             /*
    5780             :              * We don't support rewriting of system catalogs; there are too
    5781             :              * many corner cases and too little benefit.  In particular this
    5782             :              * is certainly not going to work for mapped catalogs.
    5783             :              */
    5784         864 :             if (IsSystemRelation(OldHeap))
    5785           0 :                 ereport(ERROR,
    5786             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
    5787             :                          errmsg("cannot rewrite system relation \"%s\"",
    5788             :                                 RelationGetRelationName(OldHeap))));
    5789             : 
    5790         864 :             if (RelationIsUsedAsCatalogTable(OldHeap))
    5791           2 :                 ereport(ERROR,
    5792             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
    5793             :                          errmsg("cannot rewrite table \"%s\" used as a catalog table",
    5794             :                                 RelationGetRelationName(OldHeap))));
    5795             : 
    5796             :             /*
    5797             :              * Don't allow rewrite on temp tables of other backends ... their
    5798             :              * local buffer manager is not going to cope.
    5799             :              */

    5801           0 :                 ereport(ERROR,

    5807             :              * requested a change)

    5831             : 
    5832             :             /*
    5833             :              * Fire off an Event Trigger now, before actually rewriting the
    5834             :              * table.
    5835             :              *
    5836             :              * We don't support Event Trigger for nested commands anywhere,
    5837             :              * here included, and parsetree is given NULL when coming from
    5838             :              * AlterTableInternal.
    5839             :              *
    5840             :              * And fire it only once.
    5841             :              */
    5842         862 :             if (parsetree)
    5843         862 :                 EventTriggerTableRewrite((Node *) parsetree,
    5844             :                                          tab->relid,
    5845             :                                          tab->rewrite);
    5846             : 
    5847             :             /*
    5848             :              * Create transient table that will receive the modified data.
    5849             :              *
    5850             :              * Ensure it is marked correctly as logged or unlogged.  We have
    5851             :              * to do this here so that buffers for the new relfilenumber will
    5852             :              * have the right persistence set, and at the same time ensure
    5853             :              * that the original filenumbers's buffers will get read in with
    5854             :              * the correct setting (i.e. the original one).  Otherwise a
    5855             :              * rollback after the rewrite would possibly result with buffers
    5856             :              * for the original filenumbers having the wrong persistence
    5857             :              * setting.
    5858             :              *
    5859             :              * NB: This relies on swap_relation_files() also swapping the
    5860             :              * persistence. That wouldn't work for pg_class, but that can't be
    5861             :              * unlogged anyway.
    5862             :              */
    5863         856 :             OIDNewHeap = make_new_heap(tab->relid, NewTableSpace, NewAccessMethod,
    5864             :                                        persistence, lockmode);
    5865             : 
    5866             :             /*
    5867             :              * Copy the heap data into the new table with the desired
    5868             :              * modifications, and test the current data within the table
    5869             :              * against new constraints generated by ALTER TABLE commands.
    5870             :              */
    5871         856 :             ATRewriteTable(tab, OIDNewHeap, lockmode);
    5872             : 
    5873             :             /*
    5874             :              * Swap the physical files of the old and new heaps, then rebuild
    5875             :              * indexes and discard the old heap.  We can use RecentXmin for
    5876             :              * the table's new relfrozenxid because we rewrote all the tuples
    5877             :              * in ATRewriteTable, so no older Xid remains in the table.  Also,
    5878             :              * we never try to swap toast tables by content, since we have no
    5879             :              * interest in letting this code work on system catalogs.
    5880             :              */
    5881         832 :             finish_heap_swap(tab->relid, OIDNewHeap,
    5882             :                              false, false, true,
    5883         832 :                              !OidIsValid(tab->newTableSpace),
    5884             :                              RecentXmin,
    5885             :                              ReadNextMultiXactId(),
    5886             :                              persistence);
    5887             : 
    5888         826 :             InvokeObjectPostAlterHook(RelationRelationId, tab->relid, 0);
    5889             :         }
    5890       25460 :         else if (tab->rewrite > 0 && tab->relkind == RELKIND_SEQUENCE)

    5892          12 :             if (tab->chgPersistence)

    5894             :         }

    5931             : 
    5932             :     /*
    5933             :      * Foreign key constraints are checked in a final pass, since (a) it's
    5934             :      * generally best to examine each one separately, and (b) it's at least
    5935             :      * theoretically possible that we have changed both relations of the
    5936             :      * foreign key, and we'd better have finished both rewrites before we try

    5938             :      */

    6626             : /*
    6627             :  * ATSimpleRecursion
    6628             :  *
    6629             :  * Simple table recursion sufficient for most ALTER TABLE operations.
    6630             :  * All direct and indirect children are processed in an unspecified order.
    6631             :  * Note that if a child inherits from the original table via multiple
    6632             :  * inheritance paths, it will be visited just once.
    6633             :  */
    6634             : static void
    6635       13550 : ATSimpleRecursion(List **wqueue, Relation rel,
    6636             :                   AlterTableCmd *cmd, bool recurse, LOCKMODE lockmode,
    6637             :                   AlterTableUtilityContext *context)
    6638             : {
    6639             :     /*
    6640             :      * Propagate to children, if desired and if there are (or might be) any
    6641             :      * children.
    6642             :      */
    6643       13550 :     if (recurse && rel->rd_rel->relhassubclass)
    6644             :     {
    6645         136 :         Oid         relid = RelationGetRelid(rel);
    6646             :         ListCell   *child;
    6647             :         List       *children;
    6648             : 
    6649         136 :         children = find_all_inheritors(relid, lockmode, NULL);
    6650             : 
    6651             :         /*
    6652             :          * find_all_inheritors does the recursive search of the inheritance
    6653             :          * hierarchy, so all we have to do is process all of the relids in the
    6654             :          * list that it returns.
    6655             :          */
    6656         582 :         foreach(child, children)
    6657             :         {

    6659             :             Relation    childrel;

    6662         136 :                 continue;

    6665         310 :             CheckTableNotInUse(childrel, "ALTER TABLE");

    6671             : 
    6672             : /*
    6673             :  * Obtain list of partitions of the given table, locking them all at the given
    6674             :  * lockmode and ensuring that they all pass CheckTableNotInUse.
    6675             :  *
    6676             :  * This function is a no-op if the given relation is not a partitioned table;
    6677             :  * in particular, nothing is done if it's a legacy inheritance parent.
    6678             :  */
    6679             : static void
    6680         790 : ATCheckPartitionsNotInUse(Relation rel, LOCKMODE lockmode)

    6702             : /*

    6733             : 
    6734             : 
    6735             : /*
    6736             :  * find_composite_type_dependencies
    6737             :  *
    6738             :  * Check to see if the type "typeOid" is being used as a column in some table
    6739             :  * (possibly nested several levels deep in composite types, arrays, etc!).
    6740             :  * Eventually, we'd like to propagate the check or rewrite operation
    6741             :  * into such tables, but for now, just error out if we find any.
    6742             :  *
    6743             :  * Caller should provide either the associated relation of a rowtype,
    6744             :  * or a type name (not both) for use in the error message, if any.
    6745             :  *
    6746             :  * Note that "typeOid" is not necessarily a composite type; it could also be
    6747             :  * another container type such as an array or range, or a domain over one of
    6748             :  * these things.  The name of this function is therefore somewhat historical,
    6749             :  * but it's not worth changing.
    6750             :  *
    6751             :  * We assume that functions and views depending on the type are not reasons
    6752             :  * to reject the ALTER.  (How safe is this really?)
    6753             :  */
    6754             : void
    6755        3764 : find_composite_type_dependencies(Oid typeOid, Relation origRelation,
    6756             :                                  const char *origTypeName)
    6757             : {
    6758             :     Relation    depRel;
    6759             :     ScanKeyData key[2];
    6760             :     SysScanDesc depScan;
    6761             :     HeapTuple   depTup;
    6762             : 
    6763             :     /* since this function recurses, it could be driven to stack overflow */
    6764        3764 :     check_stack_depth();
    6765             : 
    6766             :     /*
    6767             :      * We scan pg_depend to find those things that depend on the given type.
    6768             :      * (We assume we can ignore refobjsubid for a type.)
    6769             :      */
    6770        3764 :     depRel = table_open(DependRelationId, AccessShareLock);
    6771             : 
    6772        3764 :     ScanKeyInit(&key[0],
    6773             :                 Anum_pg_depend_refclassid,
    6774             :                 BTEqualStrategyNumber, F_OIDEQ,
    6775             :                 ObjectIdGetDatum(TypeRelationId));
    6776        3764 :     ScanKeyInit(&key[1],
    6777             :                 Anum_pg_depend_refobjid,
    6778             :                 BTEqualStrategyNumber, F_OIDEQ,
    6779             :                 ObjectIdGetDatum(typeOid));
    6780             : 
    6781        3764 :     depScan = systable_beginscan(depRel, DependReferenceIndexId, true,
    6782             :                                  NULL, 2, key);
    6783             : 
    6784        5832 :     while (HeapTupleIsValid(depTup = systable_getnext(depScan)))
    6785             :     {
    6786        2164 :         Form_pg_depend pg_depend = (Form_pg_depend) GETSTRUCT(depTup);
    6787             :         Relation    rel;
    6788             :         TupleDesc   tupleDesc;
    6789             :         Form_pg_attribute att;
    6790             : 
    6791             :         /* Check for directly dependent types */
    6792        2164 :         if (pg_depend->classid == TypeRelationId)
    6793             :         {
    6794             :             /*
    6795             :              * This must be an array, domain, or range containing the given
    6796             :              * type, so recursively check for uses of this type.  Note that
    6797             :              * any error message will mention the original type not the
    6798             :              * container; this is intentional.
    6799             :              */
    6800        1818 :             find_composite_type_dependencies(pg_depend->objid,
    6801             :                                              origRelation, origTypeName);
    6802        1794 :             continue;
    6803             :         }
    6804             : 
    6805             :         /* Else, ignore dependees that aren't relations */
    6806         346 :         if (pg_depend->classid != RelationRelationId)
    6807         122 :             continue;
    6808             : 
    6809         224 :         rel = relation_open(pg_depend->objid, AccessShareLock);
    6810         224 :         tupleDesc = RelationGetDescr(rel);
    6811             : 
    6812             :         /*
    6813             :          * If objsubid identifies a specific column, refer to that in error
    6814             :          * messages.  Otherwise, search to see if there's a user column of the
    6815             :          * type.  (We assume system columns are never of interesting types.)
    6816             :          * The search is needed because an index containing an expression
    6817             :          * column of the target type will just be recorded as a whole-relation
    6818             :          * dependency.  If we do not find a column of the type, the dependency
    6819             :          * must indicate that the type is transiently referenced in an index
    6820             :          * expression but not stored on disk, which we assume is OK, just as
    6821             :          * we do for references in views.  (It could also be that the target
    6822             :          * type is embedded in some container type that is stored in an index
    6823             :          * column, but the previous recursion should catch such cases.)
    6824             :          */
    6825         224 :         if (pg_depend->objsubid > 0 && pg_depend->objsubid <= tupleDesc->natts)
    6826          66 :             att = TupleDescAttr(tupleDesc, pg_depend->objsubid - 1);
    6827             :         else
    6828             :         {
    6829         158 :             att = NULL;
    6830         406 :             for (int attno = 1; attno <= tupleDesc->natts; attno++)
    6831             :             {
    6832         254 :                 att = TupleDescAttr(tupleDesc, attno - 1);
    6833         254 :                 if (att->atttypid == typeOid && !att->attisdropped)
    6834           6 :                     break;
    6835         248 :                 att = NULL;
    6836             :             }
    6837         158 :             if (att == NULL)
    6838             :             {
    6839             :                 /* No such column, so assume OK */
    6840         152 :                 relation_close(rel, AccessShareLock);
    6841         152 :                 continue;
    6842             :             }
    6843             :         }
    6844             : 
    6845             :         /*
    6846             :          * We definitely should reject if the relation has storage.  If it's
    6847             :          * partitioned, then perhaps we don't have to reject: if there are
    6848             :          * partitions then we'll fail when we find one, else there is no
    6849             :          * stored data to worry about.  However, it's possible that the type
    6850             :          * change would affect conclusions about whether the type is sortable
    6851             :          * or hashable and thus (if it's a partitioning column) break the
    6852             :          * partitioning rule.  For now, reject for partitioned rels too.
    6853             :          */
    6854          72 :         if (RELKIND_HAS_STORAGE(rel->rd_rel->relkind) ||
    6855           0 :             RELKIND_HAS_PARTITIONS(rel->rd_rel->relkind))
    6856             :         {
    6857          72 :             if (origTypeName)
    6858          30 :                 ereport(ERROR,
    6859             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
    6860             :                          errmsg("cannot alter type \"%s\" because column \"%s.%s\" uses it",
    6861             :                                 origTypeName,
    6862             :                                 RelationGetRelationName(rel),
    6863             :                                 NameStr(att->attname))));

    6872           6 :                 ereport(ERROR,
    6873             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
    6874             :                          errmsg("cannot alter foreign table \"%s\" because column \"%s.%s\" uses its row type",

    6877             :                                 NameStr(att->attname))));
