    6904             : 
    6905             : /*
    6906             :  * find_typed_table_dependencies
    6907             :  *
    6908             :  * Check to see if a composite type is being used as the type of a
    6909             :  * typed table.  Abort if any are found and behavior is RESTRICT.
    6910             :  * Else return the list of tables.
    6911             :  */
    6912             : static List *
    6913         214 : find_typed_table_dependencies(Oid typeOid, const char *typeName, DropBehavior behavior)

    6950             : 
    6951             : /*
    6952             :  * check_of_type
    6953             :  *
    6954             :  * Check whether a type is suitable for CREATE TABLE OF/ALTER TABLE OF.  If it
    6955             :  * isn't suitable, throw an error.  Currently, we require that the type
    6956             :  * originated with CREATE TYPE AS.  We could support any row type, but doing so
    6957             :  * would require handling a number of extra corner cases in the DDL commands.
    6958             :  * (Also, allowing domain-over-composite would open up a can of worms about
    6959             :  * whether and how the domain's constraints should apply to derived tables.)
    6960             :  */
    6961             : void
    6962         170 : check_of_type(HeapTuple typetuple)
    6963             : {
    6964         170 :     Form_pg_type typ = (Form_pg_type) GETSTRUCT(typetuple);
    6965         170 :     bool        typeOk = false;
    6966             : 
    6967         170 :     if (typ->typtype == TYPTYPE_COMPOSITE)
    6968             :     {
    6969             :         Relation    typeRelation;
    6970             : 
    6971         170 :         Assert(OidIsValid(typ->typrelid));
    6972         170 :         typeRelation = relation_open(typ->typrelid, AccessShareLock);
    6973         170 :         typeOk = (typeRelation->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_COMPOSITE_TYPE);
    6974             : 
    6975             :         /*
    6976             :          * Close the parent rel, but keep our AccessShareLock on it until xact
    6977             :          * commit.  That will prevent someone else from deleting or ALTERing
    6978             :          * the type before the typed table creation/conversion commits.
    6979             :          */
    6980         170 :         relation_close(typeRelation, NoLock);
    6981             :     }
    6982         170 :     if (!typeOk)
    6983           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
    6984             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
    6985             :                  errmsg("type %s is not a composite type",
    6986             :                         format_type_be(typ->oid))));
    6987         164 : }
    6988             : 
    6989             : 
    6990             : /*
    6991             :  * ALTER TABLE ADD COLUMN
    6992             :  *
    6993             :  * Adds an additional attribute to a relation making the assumption that
    6994             :  * CHECK, NOT NULL, and FOREIGN KEY constraints will be removed from the
    6995             :  * AT_AddColumn AlterTableCmd by parse_utilcmd.c and added as independent
    6996             :  * AlterTableCmd's.
    6997             :  *
    6998             :  * ADD COLUMN cannot use the normal ALTER TABLE recursion mechanism, because we
    6999             :  * have to decide at runtime whether to recurse or not depending on whether we
    7000             :  * actually add a column or merely merge with an existing column.  (We can't
    7001             :  * check this in a static pre-pass because it won't handle multiple inheritance
    7002             :  * situations correctly.)
    7003             :  */
    7004             : static void
    7005        1970 : ATPrepAddColumn(List **wqueue, Relation rel, bool recurse, bool recursing,
    7006             :                 bool is_view, AlterTableCmd *cmd, LOCKMODE lockmode,
    7007             :                 AlterTableUtilityContext *context)
    7008             : {
    7009        1970 :     if (rel->rd_rel->reloftype && !recursing)
    7010           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
    7011             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
    7012             :                  errmsg("cannot add column to typed table")));
    7013             : 
    7014        1964 :     if (rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_COMPOSITE_TYPE)
    7015          58 :         ATTypedTableRecursion(wqueue, rel, cmd, lockmode, context);
    7016             : 
    7017        1958 :     if (recurse && !is_view)
    7018        1858 :         cmd->recurse = true;
    7019        1958 : }
    7020             : 
    7021             : /*
    7022             :  * Add a column to a table.  The return value is the address of the
    7023             :  * new column in the parent relation.
    7024             :  *
    7025             :  * cmd is pass-by-ref so that we can replace it with the parse-transformed
    7026             :  * copy (but that happens only after we check for IF NOT EXISTS).
    7027             :  */
    7028             : static ObjectAddress
    7029        2576 : ATExecAddColumn(List **wqueue, AlteredTableInfo *tab, Relation rel,
    7030             :                 AlterTableCmd **cmd, bool recurse, bool recursing,
    7031             :                 LOCKMODE lockmode, AlterTablePass cur_pass,

    7033             : {
    7034        2576 :     Oid         myrelid = RelationGetRelid(rel);

    7050             :     /* At top level, permission check was done in ATPrepCmd, else do it */
    7051        2576 :     if (recursing)

    7053             : 
    7054        2576 :     if (rel->rd_rel->relispartition && !recursing)
    7055          12 :         ereport(ERROR,
    7056             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
    7057             :                  errmsg("cannot add column to a partition")));
    7058             : 
    7059        2564 :     attrdesc = table_open(AttributeRelationId, RowExclusiveLock);
    7060             : 
    7061             :     /*
    7062             :      * Are we adding the column to a recursion child?  If so, check whether to
    7063             :      * merge with an existing definition for the column.  If we do merge, we
    7064             :      * must not recurse.  Children will already have the column, and recursing
    7065             :      * into them would mess up attinhcount.
    7066             :      */
    7067        2564 :     if (colDef->inhcount > 0)
    7068             :     {

    7122             :     /* skip if the name already exists and if_not_exists is true */
    7123        2528 :     if (!check_for_column_name_collision(rel, colDef->colname, if_not_exists))
    7124             :     {
    7125          54 :         table_close(attrdesc, RowExclusiveLock);
    7126          54 :         return InvalidObjectAddress;
    7127             :     }
    7128             : 
    7129             :     /*
    7130             :      * Okay, we need to add the column, so go ahead and do parse
    7131             :      * transformation.  This can result in queueing up, or even immediately
    7132             :      * executing, subsidiary operations (such as creation of unique indexes);
    7133             :      * so we mustn't do it until we have made the if_not_exists check.
    7134             :      *
    7135             :      * When recursing, the command was already transformed and we needn't do
    7136             :      * so again.  Also, if context isn't given we can't transform.  (That
    7137             :      * currently happens only for AT_AddColumnToView; we expect that view.c
    7138             :      * passed us a ColumnDef that doesn't need work.)
    7139             :      */
    7140        2444 :     if (context != NULL && !recursing)
    7141             :     {
    7142        1832 :         *cmd = ATParseTransformCmd(wqueue, tab, rel, *cmd, recurse, lockmode,
    7143             :                                    cur_pass, context);
    7144        1832 :         Assert(*cmd != NULL);
    7145        1832 :         colDef = castNode(ColumnDef, (*cmd)->def);
    7146             :     }
    7147             : 
    7148             :     /*
    7149             :      * Regular inheritance children are independent enough not to inherit the
    7150             :      * identity column from parent hence cannot recursively add identity
    7151             :      * column if the table has inheritance children.
    7152             :      *
    7153             :      * Partitions, on the other hand, are integral part of a partitioned table
    7154             :      * and inherit identity column.  Hence propagate identity column down the
    7155             :      * partition hierarchy.
    7156             :      */
    7157        2444 :     if (colDef->identity &&
    7158          54 :         recurse &&
    7159         102 :         rel->rd_rel->relkind != RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE &&
    7160          48 :         find_inheritance_children(myrelid, NoLock) != NIL)
    7161           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
    7162             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_TABLE_DEFINITION),
    7163             :                  errmsg("cannot recursively add identity column to table that has child tables")));
    7164             : 
    7165        2438 :     pgclass = table_open(RelationRelationId, RowExclusiveLock);
    7166             : 
    7167        2438 :     reltup = SearchSysCacheCopy1(RELOID, ObjectIdGetDatum(myrelid));
    7168        2438 :     if (!HeapTupleIsValid(reltup))
    7169           0 :         elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for relation %u", myrelid);
    7170        2438 :     relkind = ((Form_pg_class) GETSTRUCT(reltup))->relkind;
    7171             : 
    7172             :     /* Determine the new attribute's number */
    7173        2438 :     newattnum = ((Form_pg_class) GETSTRUCT(reltup))->relnatts + 1;
    7174        2438 :     if (newattnum > MaxHeapAttributeNumber)
    7175           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    7176             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_TOO_MANY_COLUMNS),
    7177             :                  errmsg("tables can have at most %d columns",
    7178             :                         MaxHeapAttributeNumber)));
    7179             : 
    7180             :     /*
    7181             :      * Construct new attribute's pg_attribute entry.

    7183        2438 :     tupdesc = BuildDescForRelation(list_make1(colDef));
    7184             : 
    7185        2426 :     attribute = TupleDescAttr(tupdesc, 0);
    7186             : 
    7187             :     /* Fix up attribute number */
    7188        2426 :     attribute->attnum = newattnum;
    7189             :

    7192        2426 :                        list_make1_oid(rel->rd_rel->reltype),
    7193             :                        0);
    7194             : 
    7195        2396 :     InsertPgAttributeTuples(attrdesc, tupdesc, myrelid, NULL, NULL);
    7196             : 
    7197        2396 :     table_close(attrdesc, RowExclusiveLock);
    7198             : 
    7199             :     /*
    7200             :      * Update pg_class tuple as appropriate

    7202        2396 :     ((Form_pg_class) GETSTRUCT(reltup))->relnatts = newattnum;
    7203             : 
    7204        2396 :     CatalogTupleUpdate(pgclass, &reltup->t_self, reltup);
    7205             : 
    7206        2396 :     heap_freetuple(reltup);
    7207             : 
    7208             :     /* Post creation hook for new attribute */
    7209        2396 :     InvokeObjectPostCreateHook(RelationRelationId, myrelid, newattnum);
    7210             : 
    7211        2396 :     table_close(pgclass, RowExclusiveLock);
    7212             : 
    7213             :     /* Make the attribute's catalog entry visible */
    7214        2396 :     CommandCounterIncrement();
    7215             : 
    7216             :     /*
    7217             :      * Store the DEFAULT, if any, in the catalogs
    7218             :      */
    7219        2396 :     if (colDef->raw_default)
    7220             :     {
    7221             :         RawColumnDefault *rawEnt;
    7222             : 
    7223         690 :         rawEnt = (RawColumnDefault *) palloc(sizeof(RawColumnDefault));
    7224         690 :         rawEnt->attnum = attribute->attnum;
    7225         690 :         rawEnt->raw_default = copyObject(colDef->raw_default);
    7226             : 
    7227             :         /*
    7228             :          * Attempt to skip a complete table rewrite by storing the specified
    7229             :          * DEFAULT value outside of the heap.  This may be disabled inside
    7230             :          * AddRelationNewConstraints if the optimization cannot be applied.
    7231             :          */
    7232         690 :         rawEnt->missingMode = (!colDef->generated);
    7233             : 
    7234         690 :         rawEnt->generated = colDef->generated;
    7235             : 
    7236             :         /*
    7237             :          * This function is intended for CREATE TABLE, so it processes a
    7238             :          * _list_ of defaults, but we just do one.
    7239             :          */
    7240         690 :         AddRelationNewConstraints(rel, list_make1(rawEnt), NIL,
    7241             :                                   false, true, false, NULL);
    7242             : 
    7243             :         /* Make the additional catalog changes visible */
    7244         678 :         CommandCounterIncrement();
    7245             : 
    7246             :         /*
    7247             :          * Did the request for a missing value work? If not we'll have to do a
    7248             :          * rewrite
    7249             :          */
    7250         678 :         if (!rawEnt->missingMode)
    7251         102 :             tab->rewrite |= AT_REWRITE_DEFAULT_VAL;
    7252             :     }
    7253             : 
    7254             :     /*
    7255             :      * Tell Phase 3 to fill in the default expression, if there is one.
    7256             :      *
    7257             :      * If there is no default, Phase 3 doesn't have to do anything, because
    7258             :      * that effectively means that the default is NULL.  The heap tuple access
    7259             :      * routines always check for attnum > # of attributes in tuple, and return
    7260             :      * NULL if so, so without any modification of the tuple data we will get
    7261             :      * the effect of NULL values in the new column.
    7262             :      *
    7263             :      * An exception occurs when the new column is of a domain type: the domain
    7264             :      * might have a not-null constraint, or a check constraint that indirectly
    7265             :      * rejects nulls.  If there are any domain constraints then we construct
    7266             :      * an explicit NULL default value that will be passed through
    7267             :      * CoerceToDomain processing.  (This is a tad inefficient, since it causes
    7268             :      * rewriting the table which we really don't have to do, but the present
    7269             :      * design of domain processing doesn't offer any simple way of checking
    7270             :      * the constraints more directly.)
    7271             :      *
    7272             :      * Note: we use build_column_default, and not just the cooked default
    7273             :      * returned by AddRelationNewConstraints, so that the right thing happens
    7274             :      * when a datatype's default applies.
    7275             :      *
    7276             :      * Note: it might seem that this should happen at the end of Phase 2, so
    7277             :      * that the effects of subsequent subcommands can be taken into account.
    7278             :      * It's intentional that we do it now, though.  The new column should be
    7279             :      * filled according to what is said in the ADD COLUMN subcommand, so that
    7280             :      * the effects are the same as if this subcommand had been run by itself
    7281             :      * and the later subcommands had been issued in new ALTER TABLE commands.
    7282             :      *
    7283             :      * We can skip this entirely for relations without storage, since Phase 3
    7284             :      * is certainly not going to touch them.  System attributes don't have
    7285             :      * interesting defaults, either.
    7286             :      */
    7287        2384 :     if (RELKIND_HAS_STORAGE(relkind))
    7288             :     {
    7289             :         /*
    7290             :          * For an identity column, we can't use build_column_default(),
    7291             :          * because the sequence ownership isn't set yet.  So do it manually.
    7292             :          */
    7293        2038 :         if (colDef->identity)
    7294             :         {

    7648             : 
    7649             : /*
    7650             :  * Helper to set pg_attribute.attnotnull if it isn't set, and to tell phase 3
    7651             :  * to verify it; recurses to apply the same to children.
    7652             :  *
    7653             :  * When called to alter an existing table, 'wqueue' must be given so that we can
    7654             :  * queue a check that existing tuples pass the constraint.  When called from
    7655             :  * table creation, 'wqueue' should be passed as NULL.
    7656             :  *
    7657             :  * Returns true if the flag was set in any table, otherwise false.
    7658             :  */
    7659             : static bool
    7660       20868 : set_attnotnull(List **wqueue, Relation rel, AttrNumber attnum, bool recurse,
    7661             :                LOCKMODE lockmode)
    7662             : {
    7663             :     HeapTuple   tuple;
    7664             :     Form_pg_attribute attForm;
    7665       20868 :     bool        retval = false;
    7666             : 
    7667             :     /* Guard against stack overflow due to overly deep inheritance tree. */
    7668       20868 :     check_stack_depth();
    7669             : 
    7670       20868 :     tuple = SearchSysCacheCopyAttNum(RelationGetRelid(rel), attnum);
    7671       20868 :     if (!HeapTupleIsValid(tuple))
    7672           0 :         elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for attribute %d of relation %u",
    7673             :              attnum, RelationGetRelid(rel));
    7674       20868 :     attForm = (Form_pg_attribute) GETSTRUCT(tuple);
    7675       20868 :     if (!attForm->attnotnull)
    7676             :     {
    7677             :         Relation    attr_rel;
    7678             : 
    7679        1372 :         attr_rel = table_open(AttributeRelationId, RowExclusiveLock);
    7680             : 
    7681        1372 :         attForm->attnotnull = true;
    7682        1372 :         CatalogTupleUpdate(attr_rel, &tuple->t_self, tuple);
    7683             : 
    7684        1372 :         table_close(attr_rel, RowExclusiveLock);
    7685             :

    7688             :          * constraint already proves this.
    7689             :          */

    7723             :         }

    7728             : 
    7729             : /*
    7730             :  * ALTER TABLE ALTER COLUMN SET NOT NULL
    7731             :  *
    7732             :  * Add a not-null constraint to a single table and its children.  Returns
    7733             :  * the address of the constraint added to the parent relation, if one gets
    7734             :  * added, or InvalidObjectAddress otherwise.
    7735             :  *
    7736             :  * We must recurse to child tables during execution, rather than using
    7737             :  * ALTER TABLE's normal prep-time recursion.
    7738             :  */
    7739             : static ObjectAddress
    7740         478 : ATExecSetNotNull(List **wqueue, Relation rel, char *conName, char *colName,
    7741             :                  bool recurse, bool recursing, List **readyRels,
    7742             :                  LOCKMODE lockmode)
    7743             : {
    7744             :     HeapTuple   tuple;
    7745             :     Relation    constr_rel;
    7746             :     ScanKeyData skey;
    7747             :     SysScanDesc conscan;
    7748             :     AttrNumber  attnum;
    7749             :     ObjectAddress address;
    7750             :     Constraint *constraint;
    7751             :     CookedConstraint *ccon;
    7752             :     List       *cooked;
    7753         478 :     bool        is_no_inherit = false;
    7754         478 :     List       *ready = NIL;
    7755             : 
    7756             :     /* Guard against stack overflow due to overly deep inheritance tree. */
    7757         478 :     check_stack_depth();
    7758             : 
    7759             :     /*
    7760             :      * In cases of multiple inheritance, we might visit the same child more
    7761             :      * than once.  In the topmost call, set up a list that we fill with all
    7762             :      * visited relations, to skip those.
    7763             :      */
    7764         478 :     if (readyRels == NULL)
    7765             :     {
    7766         348 :         Assert(!recursing);
    7767         348 :         readyRels = &ready;
    7768             :     }
    7769         478 :     if (list_member_oid(*readyRels, RelationGetRelid(rel)))
    7770           6 :         return InvalidObjectAddress;
    7771         472 :     *readyRels = lappend_oid(*readyRels, RelationGetRelid(rel));
    7772             : 
    7773             :     /* At top level, permission check was done in ATPrepCmd, else do it */
    7774         472 :     if (recursing)
    7775             :     {
    7776         124 :         ATSimplePermissions(AT_AddConstraint, rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    7777         124 :         Assert(conName != NULL);
    7778             :     }
    7779             : 
    7780         472 :     attnum = get_attnum(RelationGetRelid(rel), colName);
    7781         472 :     if (attnum == InvalidAttrNumber)
    7782          18 :         ereport(ERROR,
    7783             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_COLUMN),
    7784             :                  errmsg("column \"%s\" of relation \"%s\" does not exist",
    7785             :                         colName, RelationGetRelationName(rel))));
    7786             : 
    7787             :     /* Prevent them from altering a system attribute */
    7788         454 :     if (attnum <= 0)
    7789           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    7790             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
    7791             :                  errmsg("cannot alter system column \"%s\"",
    7792             :                         colName)));
    7793             : 
    7794             :     /* See if there's already a constraint */

    8571             : /*
    8572             :  * ALTER TABLE ALTER COLUMN DROP EXPRESSION
    8573             :  */
    8574             : static void
    8575          44 : ATPrepDropExpression(Relation rel, AlterTableCmd *cmd, bool recurse, bool recursing, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    8576             : {
    8577             :     /*
    8578             :      * Reject ONLY if there are child tables.  We could implement this, but it
    8579             :      * is a bit complicated.  GENERATED clauses must be attached to the column
    8580             :      * definition and cannot be added later like DEFAULT, so if a child table
    8581             :      * has a generation expression that the parent does not have, the child
    8582             :      * column will necessarily be an attislocal column.  So to implement ONLY
    8583             :      * here, we'd need extra code to update attislocal of the direct child
    8584             :      * tables, somewhat similar to how DROP COLUMN does it, so that the
    8585             :      * resulting state can be properly dumped and restored.
    8586             :      */

    8588          12 :         find_inheritance_children(RelationGetRelid(rel), lockmode))

    9041             : /*
    9042             :  * ALTER TABLE DROP COLUMN
    9043             :  *
    9044             :  * DROP COLUMN cannot use the normal ALTER TABLE recursion mechanism,
    9045             :  * because we have to decide at runtime whether to recurse or not depending
    9046             :  * on whether attinhcount goes to zero or not.  (We can't check this in a
    9047             :  * static pre-pass because it won't handle multiple inheritance situations
    9048             :  * correctly.)
    9049             :  */

    9067             : /*
    9068             :  * Drops column 'colName' from relation 'rel' and returns the address of the
    9069             :  * dropped column.  The column is also dropped (or marked as no longer
    9070             :  * inherited from relation) from the relation's inheritance children, if any.
    9071             :  *
    9072             :  * In the recursive invocations for inheritance child relations, instead of
    9073             :  * dropping the column directly (if to be dropped at all), its object address
    9074             :  * is added to 'addrs', which must be non-NULL in such invocations.  All
    9075             :  * columns are dropped at the same time after all the children have been
    9076             :  * checked recursively.
    9077             :  */

    9266             : /*
    9267             :  * Prepare to add a primary key on an inheritance parent, by adding NOT NULL

    9322          74 :         newcmd->recurse = true;
    9323             : 
    9324         148 :         foreach(lc2, newconstrs)
    9325             :         {
    9326             :             /* ATPrepCmd copies newcmd, so we can scribble on it here */

    9337             : /*
    9338             :  * ALTER TABLE ADD INDEX
    9339             :  *
    9340             :  * There is no such command in the grammar, but parse_utilcmd.c converts
    9341             :  * UNIQUE and PRIMARY KEY constraints into AT_AddIndex subcommands.  This lets
    9342             :  * us schedule creation of the index at the appropriate time during ALTER.
    9343             :  *

    9345             :  */

    9359        1406 :     Assert(stmt->transformed);
    9360             :

    9584             : /*
    9585             :  * Generate the column-name portion of the constraint name for a new foreign
    9586             :  * key given the list of column names that reference the referenced
    9587             :  * table.  This will be passed to ChooseConstraintName along with the parent
    9588             :  * table name and the "fkey" suffix.
    9589             :  *
    9590             :  * We know that less than NAMEDATALEN characters will actually be used, so we
    9591             :  * can truncate the result once we've generated that many.
    9592             :  *
    9593             :  * XXX see also ChooseExtendedStatisticNameAddition and
    9594             :  * ChooseIndexNameAddition.
    9595             :  */
    9596             : static char *
    9597        1974 : ChooseForeignKeyConstraintNameAddition(List *colnames)
    9598             : {
    9599             :     char        buf[NAMEDATALEN * 2];
    9600        1974 :     int         buflen = 0;
    9601             :     ListCell   *lc;
    9602             : 
    9603        1974 :     buf[0] = '\0';
    9604        4346 :     foreach(lc, colnames)
    9605             :     {
    9606        2372 :         const char *name = strVal(lfirst(lc));
    9607             : 
    9608        2372 :         if (buflen > 0)
    9609         398 :             buf[buflen++] = '_';    /* insert _ between names */
    9610             : 
    9611             :         /*
    9612             :          * At this point we have buflen <= NAMEDATALEN.  name should be less
    9613             :          * than NAMEDATALEN already, but use strlcpy for paranoia.
    9614             :          */
    9615        2372 :         strlcpy(buf + buflen, name, NAMEDATALEN);
    9616        2372 :         buflen += strlen(buf + buflen);
    9617        2372 :         if (buflen >= NAMEDATALEN)
    9618           0 :             break;
    9619             :     }
    9620        1974 :     return pstrdup(buf);
    9621             : }
    9622             : 
    9623             : /*
    9624             :  * Add a check or not-null constraint to a single table and its children.
    9625             :  * Returns the address of the constraint added to the parent relation,
    9626             :  * if one gets added, or InvalidObjectAddress otherwise.
    9627             :  *
    9628             :  * Subroutine for ATExecAddConstraint.
    9629             :  *
    9630             :  * We must recurse to child tables during execution, rather than using
    9631             :  * ALTER TABLE's normal prep-time recursion.  The reason is that all the
    9632             :  * constraints *must* be given the same name, else they won't be seen as
    9633             :  * related later.  If the user didn't explicitly specify a name, then
    9634             :  * AddRelationNewConstraints would normally assign different names to the
    9635             :  * child constraints.  To fix that, we must capture the name assigned at
    9636             :  * the parent table and pass that down.
    9637             :  */
    9638             : static ObjectAddress
    9639        1900 : ATAddCheckNNConstraint(List **wqueue, AlteredTableInfo *tab, Relation rel,
    9640             :                        Constraint *constr, bool recurse, bool recursing,
    9641             :                        bool is_readd, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    9642             : {
    9643             :     List       *newcons;
    9644             :     ListCell   *lcon;
    9645             :     List       *children;
    9646             :     ListCell   *child;
    9647        1900 :     ObjectAddress address = InvalidObjectAddress;
    9648             : 
    9649             :     /* Guard against stack overflow due to overly deep inheritance tree. */
    9650        1900 :     check_stack_depth();
    9651             : 
    9652             :     /* At top level, permission check was done in ATPrepCmd, else do it */
    9653        1900 :     if (recursing)
    9654         474 :         ATSimplePermissions(AT_AddConstraint, rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    9655             : 
    9656             :     /*
    9657             :      * Call AddRelationNewConstraints to do the work, making sure it works on
    9658             :      * a copy of the Constraint so transformExpr can't modify the original. It
    9659             :      * returns a list of cooked constraints.
    9660             :      *
    9661             :      * If the constraint ends up getting merged with a pre-existing one, it's
    9662             :      * omitted from the returned list, which is what we want: we do not need
    9663             :      * to do any validation work.  That can only happen at child tables,
    9664             :      * though, since we disallow merging at the top level.
    9665             :      */
    9666        1900 :     newcons = AddRelationNewConstraints(rel, NIL,
    9667        1900 :                                         list_make1(copyObject(constr)),
    9668        1900 :                                         recursing || is_readd,  /* allow_merge */
    9669        1900 :                                         !recursing, /* is_local */
    9670             :                                         is_readd,   /* is_internal */
    9671        1900 :                                         NULL);  /* queryString not available
    9672             :                                                  * here */
    9673             : 
    9674             :     /* we don't expect more than one constraint here */
    9675        1828 :     Assert(list_length(newcons) <= 1);
    9676             : 
    9677             :     /* Add each to-be-validated constraint to Phase 3's queue */
    9678        3542 :     foreach(lcon, newcons)
    9679             :     {
    9680        1714 :         CookedConstraint *ccon = (CookedConstraint *) lfirst(lcon);

    9682        1714 :         if (!ccon->skip_validation && ccon->contype != CONSTR_NOTNULL)

    9694             :         /* Save the actually assigned name if it was defaulted */

    9696         542 :             constr->conname = ccon->name;
    9697             : 
    9698             :         /*

    9703         542 :             set_attnotnull(wqueue, rel, ccon->attnum,
    9704         542 :                            !ccon->is_no_inherit, lockmode);

    9706        1714 :         ObjectAddressSet(address, ConstraintRelationId, ccon->conoid);
    9707             :     }
    9708             : 
    9709             :     /* At this point we must have a locked-down name to use */
    9710        1828 :     Assert(newcons == NIL || constr->conname != NULL);
    9711             : 
    9712             :     /* Advance command counter in case same table is visited multiple times */
    9713        1828 :     CommandCounterIncrement();
    9714             : 
    9715             :     /*
    9716             :      * If the constraint got merged with an existing constraint, we're done.
    9717             :      * We mustn't recurse to child tables in this case, because they've
    9718             :      * already got the constraint, and visiting them again would lead to an
    9719             :      * incorrect value for coninhcount.

    9721        1828 :     if (newcons == NIL)

    9723             : 
    9724             :     /*
    9725             :      * If adding a NO INHERIT constraint, no need to find our children.
    9726             :      */
    9727        1714 :     if (constr->is_no_inherit)
    9728          72 :         return address;
    9729             : 
    9730             :     /*

    9732             :      * routines, we have to do this one level of recursion at a time; we can't
    9733             :      * use find_all_inheritors to do it in one pass.
    9734             :      */
    9735             :     children =
    9736        1642 :         find_inheritance_children(RelationGetRelid(rel), lockmode);
    9737             : 
    9738             :     /*

    9744           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
    9745             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_TABLE_DEFINITION),
    9746             :                  errmsg("constraint must be added to child tables too")));

    9749             :      * The constraint must appear as inherited in children, so create a
    9750             :      * modified constraint object to use.

    9752        1636 :     constr = copyObject(constr);

    9754        2104 :     foreach(child, children)
    9755             :     {

    9780             : 
    9781             : /*
    9782             :  * Add a foreign-key constraint to a single table; return the new constraint's
    9783             :  * address.
    9784             :  *
    9785             :  * Subroutine for ATExecAddConstraint.  Must already hold exclusive
    9786             :  * lock on the rel, and have done appropriate validity checks for it.
    9787             :  * We do permissions checks here, however.
    9788             :  *
    9789             :  * When the referenced or referencing tables (or both) are partitioned,
    9790             :  * multiple pg_constraint rows are required -- one for each partitioned table
    9791             :  * and each partition on each side (fortunately, not one for every combination
    9792             :  * thereof).  We also need action triggers on each leaf partition on the
    9793             :  * referenced side, and check triggers on each leaf partition on the
    9794             :  * referencing side.
    9795             :  */
    9796             : static ObjectAddress
    9797        2104 : ATAddForeignKeyConstraint(List **wqueue, AlteredTableInfo *tab, Relation rel,
    9798             :                           Constraint *fkconstraint,
    9799             :                           bool recurse, bool recursing, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    9800             : {
    9801             :     Relation    pkrel;
    9802        2104 :     int16       pkattnum[INDEX_MAX_KEYS] = {0};
    9803        2104 :     int16       fkattnum[INDEX_MAX_KEYS] = {0};
    9804        2104 :     Oid         pktypoid[INDEX_MAX_KEYS] = {0};
    9805        2104 :     Oid         fktypoid[INDEX_MAX_KEYS] = {0};
    9806        2104 :     Oid         opclasses[INDEX_MAX_KEYS] = {0};
    9807        2104 :     Oid         pfeqoperators[INDEX_MAX_KEYS] = {0};
    9808        2104 :     Oid         ppeqoperators[INDEX_MAX_KEYS] = {0};
    9809        2104 :     Oid         ffeqoperators[INDEX_MAX_KEYS] = {0};
    9810        2104 :     int16       fkdelsetcols[INDEX_MAX_KEYS] = {0};
    9811             :     int         i;
    9812             :     int         numfks,
    9813             :                 numpks,
    9814             :                 numfkdelsetcols;
    9815             :     Oid         indexOid;
    9816             :     bool        old_check_ok;
    9817             :     ObjectAddress address;
    9818        2104 :     ListCell   *old_pfeqop_item = list_head(fkconstraint->old_conpfeqop);
    9819             : 
    9820             :     /*
    9821             :      * Grab ShareRowExclusiveLock on the pk table, so that someone doesn't
    9822             :      * delete rows out from under us.
    9823             :      */

   10100             :              * permit intra-opfamily changes, but that adds subtle complexity

   10103             :              */

   10106             :                                     old_pfeqop_item);
   10107             :         }
   10108        2156 :         if (old_check_ok)
   10109             :         {
   10110             :             Oid         old_fktype;
   10111             :             Oid         new_fktype;
   10112             :             CoercionPathType old_pathtype;
   10113             :             CoercionPathType new_pathtype;
   10114             :             Oid         old_castfunc;
   10115             :             Oid         new_castfunc;
   10116           6 :             Form_pg_attribute attr = TupleDescAttr(tab->oldDesc,
   10117             :                                                    fkattnum[i] - 1);
   10118             : 
   10119             :             /*
   10120             :              * Identify coercion pathways from each of the old and new FK-side
   10121             :              * column types to the right (foreign) operand type of the pfeqop.
   10122             :              * We may assume that pg_constraint.conkey is not changing.
   10123             :              */
   10124           6 :             old_fktype = attr->atttypid;
   10125           6 :             new_fktype = fktype;
   10126           6 :             old_pathtype = findFkeyCast(pfeqop_right, old_fktype,
   10127             :                                         &old_castfunc);
   10128           6 :             new_pathtype = findFkeyCast(pfeqop_right, new_fktype,
   10129             :                                         &new_castfunc);
   10130             : 
   10131             :             /*
   10132             :              * Upon a change to the cast from the FK column to its pfeqop
   10133             :              * operand, revalidate the constraint.  For this evaluation, a
   10134             :              * binary coercion cast is equivalent to no cast at all.  While
   10135             :              * type implementors should design implicit casts with an eye
   10136             :              * toward consistency of operations like equality, we cannot
   10137             :              * assume here that they have done so.
   10138             :              *
   10139             :              * A function with a polymorphic argument could change behavior
   10140             :              * arbitrarily in response to get_fn_expr_argtype().  Therefore,
   10141             :              * when the cast destination is polymorphic, we only avoid
   10142             :              * revalidation if the input type has not changed at all.  Given
   10143             :              * just the core data types and operator classes, this requirement
   10144             :              * prevents no would-be optimizations.
   10145             :              *
   10146             :              * If the cast converts from a base type to a domain thereon, then
   10147             :              * that domain type must be the opcintype of the unique index.
   10148             :              * Necessarily, the primary key column must then be of the domain
   10149             :              * type.  Since the constraint was previously valid, all values on
   10150             :              * the foreign side necessarily exist on the primary side and in
   10151             :              * turn conform to the domain.  Consequently, we need not treat
   10152             :              * domains specially here.
   10153             :              *
   10154             :              * Since we require that all collations share the same notion of
   10155             :              * equality (which they do, because texteq reduces to bitwise
   10156             :              * equality), we don't compare collation here.
   10157             :              *
   10158             :              * We need not directly consider the PK type.  It's necessarily
   10159             :              * binary coercible to the opcintype of the unique index column,
   10160             :              * and ri_triggers.c will only deal with PK datums in terms of
   10161             :              * that opcintype.  Changing the opcintype also changes pfeqop.
   10162             :              */
   10163           6 :             old_check_ok = (new_pathtype == old_pathtype &&
   10164          12 :                             new_castfunc == old_castfunc &&
   10165           6 :                             (!IsPolymorphicType(pfeqop_right) ||
   10166             :                              new_fktype == old_fktype));
   10167             :         }
   10168             : 
   10169        2156 :         pfeqoperators[i] = pfeqop;
   10170        2156 :         ppeqoperators[i] = ppeqop;
   10171        2156 :         ffeqoperators[i] = ffeqop;
   10172             :     }
   10173             : 
   10174             :     /*
   10175             :      * Create all the constraint and trigger objects, recursing to partitions
   10176             :      * as necessary.  First handle the referenced side.
   10177             :      */

   10209             :      * Done.  Close pk table, but keep lock until we've committed.

   10212             :

   10214             : }
   10215             : 
   10216             : /*
   10217             :  * validateFkOnDeleteSetColumns
   10218             :  *      Verifies that columns used in ON DELETE SET NULL/DEFAULT (...)
   10219             :  *      column lists are valid.
   10220             :  */
   10221             : void
   10222        2054 : validateFkOnDeleteSetColumns(int numfks, const int16 *fkattnums,
   10223             :                              int numfksetcols, const int16 *fksetcolsattnums,
   10224             :                              List *fksetcols)
   10225             : {
   10226        2078 :     for (int i = 0; i < numfksetcols; i++)
   10227             :     {
   10228          30 :         int16       setcol_attnum = fksetcolsattnums[i];
   10229          30 :         bool        seen = false;
   10230             : 
   10231          54 :         for (int j = 0; j < numfks; j++)
   10232             :         {
   10233          48 :             if (fkattnums[j] == setcol_attnum)
   10234             :             {
   10235          24 :                 seen = true;
   10236          24 :                 break;
   10237             :             }
   10238             :         }
   10239             : 
   10240          30 :         if (!seen)
   10241             :         {
   10242           6 :             char       *col = strVal(list_nth(fksetcols, i));
   10243             : 
   10244           6 :             ereport(ERROR,
   10245             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_COLUMN_REFERENCE),
   10246             :                      errmsg("column \"%s\" referenced in ON DELETE SET action must be part of foreign key", col)));
   10247             :         }
   10248             :     }
   10249        2048 : }
   10250             : 
   10251             : /*
   10252             :  * addFkRecurseReferenced
   10253             :  *      subroutine for ATAddForeignKeyConstraint; recurses on the referenced
   10254             :  *      side of the constraint
   10255             :  *
   10256             :  * Create pg_constraint rows for the referenced side of the constraint,
   10257             :  * referencing the parent of the referencing side; also create action triggers
   10258             :  * on leaf partitions.  If the table is partitioned, recurse to handle each
   10259             :  * partition.
   10260             :  *
   10261             :  * wqueue is the ALTER TABLE work queue; can be NULL when not running as part
   10262             :  * of an ALTER TABLE sequence.
   10263             :  * fkconstraint is the constraint being added.
   10264             :  * rel is the root referencing relation.
   10265             :  * pkrel is the referenced relation; might be a partition, if recursing.
   10266             :  * indexOid is the OID of the index (on pkrel) implementing this constraint.
   10267             :  * parentConstr is the OID of a parent constraint; InvalidOid if this is a
   10268             :  * top-level constraint.
   10269             :  * numfks is the number of columns in the foreign key
   10270             :  * pkattnum is the attnum array of referenced attributes.
   10271             :  * fkattnum is the attnum array of referencing attributes.
   10272             :  * numfkdelsetcols is the number of columns in the ON DELETE SET NULL/DEFAULT
   10273             :  *      (...) clause
   10274             :  * fkdelsetcols is the attnum array of the columns in the ON DELETE SET
   10275             :  *      NULL/DEFAULT clause
   10276             :  * pf/pp/ffeqoperators are OID array of operators between columns.
   10277             :  * old_check_ok signals that this constraint replaces an existing one that
   10278             :  * was already validated (thus this one doesn't need validation).
   10279             :  * parentDelTrigger and parentUpdTrigger, when being recursively called on
   10280             :  * a partition, are the OIDs of the parent action triggers for DELETE and
   10281             :  * UPDATE respectively.
   10282             :  */
   10283             : static ObjectAddress
   10284        2450 : addFkRecurseReferenced(List **wqueue, Constraint *fkconstraint, Relation rel,

   10287             :                        int16 *pkattnum, int16 *fkattnum, Oid *pfeqoperators,

   10386             :      * contains no referenced values.)

   10388        2450 :     if (OidIsValid(parentConstr))
   10389             :     {
   10390             :         ObjectAddress referenced;
   10391             :

   10393         666 :         recordDependencyOn(&address, &referenced, DEPENDENCY_INTERNAL);
   10394             :     }
   10395             : 
   10396             :     /* make new constraint visible, in case we add more */
   10397        2450 :     CommandCounterIncrement();

   10399             :     /*
   10400             :      * Create the action triggers that enforce the constraint.
   10401             :      */
   10402        2450 :     createForeignKeyActionTriggers(rel, RelationGetRelid(pkrel),
   10403             :                                    fkconstraint,
   10404             :                                    constrOid, indexOid,
   10405             :                                    parentDelTrigger, parentUpdTrigger,
   10406             :                                    &deleteTriggerOid, &updateTriggerOid);
   10407             : 
   10408             :     /*
   10409             :      * If the referenced table is partitioned, recurse on ourselves to handle
   10410             :      * each partition.  We need one pg_constraint row created for each
   10411             :      * partition in addition to the pg_constraint row for the parent table.

   10467             : 
   10468             : /*
   10469             :  * addFkRecurseReferencing
   10470             :  *      subroutine for ATAddForeignKeyConstraint and CloneFkReferencing
   10471             :  *
   10472             :  * If the referencing relation is a plain relation, create the necessary check
   10473             :  * triggers that implement the constraint, and set up for Phase 3 constraint
   10474             :  * verification.  If the referencing relation is a partitioned table, then
   10475             :  * we create a pg_constraint row for it and recurse on this routine for each
   10476             :  * partition.
   10477             :  *
   10478             :  * We assume that the referenced relation is locked against concurrent
   10479             :  * deletions.  If it's a partitioned relation, every partition must be so
   10480             :  * locked.
   10481             :  *
   10482             :  * wqueue is the ALTER TABLE work queue; can be NULL when not running as part
   10483             :  * of an ALTER TABLE sequence.
   10484             :  * fkconstraint is the constraint being added.
   10485             :  * rel is the referencing relation; might be a partition, if recursing.
   10486             :  * pkrel is the root referenced relation.
   10487             :  * indexOid is the OID of the index (on pkrel) implementing this constraint.
   10488             :  * parentConstr is the OID of the parent constraint (there is always one).
   10489             :  * numfks is the number of columns in the foreign key
   10490             :  * pkattnum is the attnum array of referenced attributes.
   10491             :  * fkattnum is the attnum array of referencing attributes.
   10492             :  * pf/pp/ffeqoperators are OID array of operators between columns.
   10493             :  * numfkdelsetcols is the number of columns in the ON DELETE SET NULL/DEFAULT
   10494             :  *      (...) clause
   10495             :  * fkdelsetcols is the attnum array of the columns in the ON DELETE SET
   10496             :  *      NULL/DEFAULT clause
   10497             :  * old_check_ok signals that this constraint replaces an existing one that
   10498             :  *      was already validated (thus this one doesn't need validation).
   10499             :  * lockmode is the lockmode to acquire on partitions when recursing.
   10500             :  * parentInsTrigger and parentUpdTrigger, when being recursively called on
   10501             :  * a partition, are the OIDs of the parent check triggers for INSERT and
   10502             :  * UPDATE respectively.
   10503             :  */
   10504             : static void
   10505        2494 : addFkRecurseReferencing(List **wqueue, Constraint *fkconstraint, Relation rel,
   10506             :                         Relation pkrel, Oid indexOid, Oid parentConstr,
   10507             :                         int numfks, int16 *pkattnum, int16 *fkattnum,
   10508             :                         Oid *pfeqoperators, Oid *ppeqoperators, Oid *ffeqoperators,
   10509             :                         int numfkdelsetcols, int16 *fkdelsetcols,
   10510             :                         bool old_check_ok, LOCKMODE lockmode,
   10511             :                         Oid parentInsTrigger, Oid parentUpdTrigger)
   10512             : {
   10513             :     Oid         insertTriggerOid,
   10514             :                 updateTriggerOid;
   10515             : 
   10516        2494 :     Assert(OidIsValid(parentConstr));
   10517             : 
   10518        2494 :     if (rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_FOREIGN_TABLE)
   10519           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   10520             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
   10521             :                  errmsg("foreign key constraints are not supported on foreign tables")));
   10522             : 
   10523             :     /*
   10524             :      * Add the check triggers to it and, if necessary, schedule it to be
   10525             :      * checked in Phase 3.
   10526             :      *
   10527             :      * If the relation is partitioned, drill down to do it to its partitions.
   10528             :      */
   10529        2494 :     createForeignKeyCheckTriggers(RelationGetRelid(rel),
   10530             :                                   RelationGetRelid(pkrel),

   10537        2494 :     if (rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_RELATION)
   10538             :     {
   10539             :         /*
   10540             :          * Tell Phase 3 to check that the constraint is satisfied by existing
   10541             :          * rows. We can skip this during table creation, when requested

   10545             :          */
   10546        2100 :         if (wqueue && !old_check_ok && !fkconstraint->skip_validation)
   10547             :         {
   10548             :             NewConstraint *newcon;

   10551         658 :             tab = ATGetQueueEntry(wqueue, rel);

   10557         658 :             newcon->refindid = indexOid;

   10559         658 :             newcon->qual = (Node *) fkconstraint;
   10560             : 
   10561         658 :             tab->constraints = lappend(tab->constraints, newcon);
   10562             :         }
   10563             :     }
   10564         394 :     else if (rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE)
   10565             :     {
   10566         394 :         PartitionDesc pd = RelationGetPartitionDesc(rel, true);
   10567             :         Relation    trigrel;
   10568             : 
   10569             :         /*
   10570             :          * Triggers of the foreign keys will be manipulated a bunch of times
   10571             :          * in the loop below.  To avoid repeatedly opening/closing the trigger

   10577             :         /*

   10584         364 :             Oid         partitionId = pd->oids[i];

   10604             :             /* Check whether an existing constraint can be repurposed */
   10605         364 :             partFKs = copyObject(RelationGetFKeyList(partition));

   10611          30 :                 fk = lfirst_node(ForeignKeyCacheInfo, cell);

   10613             :                                                  partitionId,

   10678             : 
   10679             :             /*
   10680             :              * Give this constraint partition-type dependencies on the parent
   10681             :              * constraint as well as the table.

   10683         352 :             ObjectAddressSet(address, ConstraintRelationId, constrOid);
   10684         352 :             ObjectAddressSet(referenced, ConstraintRelationId, parentConstr);
   10685         352 :             recordDependencyOn(&address, &referenced, DEPENDENCY_PARTITION_PRI);

   10688             : 
   10689             :             /* Make all this visible before recursing */
   10690         352 :             CommandCounterIncrement();

   10692             :             /* call ourselves to finalize the creation and we're done */
   10693         352 :             addFkRecurseReferencing(wqueue, fkconstraint, partition, pkrel,
   10694             :                                     indexOid,
   10695             :                                     constrOid,
   10696             :                                     numfks,
   10697             :                                     pkattnum,
   10698             :                                     mapped_fkattnum,
   10699             :                                     pfeqoperators,

   10714        2494 : }
   10715             : 
   10716             : /*
   10717             :  * CloneForeignKeyConstraints
   10718             :  *      Clone foreign keys from a partitioned table to a newly acquired
   10719             :  *      partition.
   10720             :  *
   10721             :  * partitionRel is a partition of parentRel, so we can be certain that it has
   10722             :  * the same columns with the same datatypes.  The columns may be in different
   10723             :  * order, though.
   10724             :  *
   10725             :  * wqueue must be passed to set up phase 3 constraint checking, unless the
   10726             :  * referencing-side partition is known to be empty (such as in CREATE TABLE /
   10727             :  * PARTITION OF).
   10728             :  */
   10729             : static void
   10730        8874 : CloneForeignKeyConstraints(List **wqueue, Relation parentRel,
   10731             :                            Relation partitionRel)
   10732             : {
   10733             :     /* This only works for declarative partitioning */
   10734        8874 :     Assert(parentRel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE);
   10735             : 
   10736             :     /*
   10737             :      * Clone constraints for which the parent is on the referenced side.
   10738             :      */
   10739        8874 :     CloneFkReferenced(parentRel, partitionRel);
   10740             : 
   10741             :     /*
   10742             :      * Now clone constraints where the parent is on the referencing side.
   10743             :      */
   10744        8874 :     CloneFkReferencing(wqueue, parentRel, partitionRel);
   10745        8874 : }
   10746             : 
   10747             : /*
   10748             :  * CloneFkReferenced
   10749             :  *      Subroutine for CloneForeignKeyConstraints
   10750             :  *
   10751             :  * Find all the FKs that have the parent relation on the referenced side;
   10752             :  * clone those constraints to the given partition.  This is to be called
   10753             :  * when the partition is being created or attached.
   10754             :  *
   10755             :  * This ignores self-referencing FKs; those are handled by CloneFkReferencing.
   10756             :  *
   10757             :  * This recurses to partitions, if the relation being attached is partitioned.
   10758             :  * Recursion is done by calling addFkRecurseReferenced.
   10759             :  */
   10760             : static void
   10761        8874 : CloneFkReferenced(Relation parentRel, Relation partitionRel)
   10762             : {
   10763             :     Relation    pg_constraint;
   10764             :     AttrMap    *attmap;
   10765             :     ListCell   *cell;
   10766             :     SysScanDesc scan;
   10767             :     ScanKeyData key[2];
   10768             :     HeapTuple   tuple;
   10769        8874 :     List       *clone = NIL;
   10770             :     Relation    trigrel;
   10771             : 
   10772             :     /*
   10773             :      * Search for any constraints where this partition's parent is in the
   10774             :      * referenced side.  However, we must not clone any constraint whose
   10775             :      * parent constraint is also going to be cloned, to avoid duplicates.  So
   10776             :      * do it in two steps: first construct the list of constraints to clone,
   10777             :      * then go over that list cloning those whose parents are not in the list.
   10778             :      * (We must not rely on the parent being seen first, since the catalog
   10779             :      * scan could return children first.)
   10780             :      */
   10781        8874 :     pg_constraint = table_open(ConstraintRelationId, RowShareLock);
   10782        8874 :     ScanKeyInit(&key[0],
   10783             :                 Anum_pg_constraint_confrelid, BTEqualStrategyNumber,
   10784             :                 F_OIDEQ, ObjectIdGetDatum(RelationGetRelid(parentRel)));
   10785        8874 :     ScanKeyInit(&key[1],
   10786             :                 Anum_pg_constraint_contype, BTEqualStrategyNumber,
   10787             :                 F_CHAREQ, CharGetDatum(CONSTRAINT_FOREIGN));
   10788             :     /* This is a seqscan, as we don't have a usable index ... */
   10789        8874 :     scan = systable_beginscan(pg_constraint, InvalidOid, true,
   10790             :                               NULL, 2, key);
   10791        9174 :     while ((tuple = systable_getnext(scan)) != NULL)
   10792             :     {
   10793         300 :         Form_pg_constraint constrForm = (Form_pg_constraint) GETSTRUCT(tuple);
   10794             : 
   10795         300 :         clone = lappend_oid(clone, constrForm->oid);
   10796             :     }
   10797        8874 :     systable_endscan(scan);
   10798        8874 :     table_close(pg_constraint, RowShareLock);
   10799             : 
   10800             :     /*

   10802             :      * the loop below.  To avoid repeatedly opening/closing the trigger

   10804             :      * below.

   10952             : /*
   10953             :  * CloneFkReferencing
   10954             :  *      Subroutine for CloneForeignKeyConstraints
   10955             :  *
   10956             :  * For each FK constraint of the parent relation in the given list, find an
   10957             :  * equivalent constraint in its partition relation that can be reparented;
   10958             :  * if one cannot be found, create a new constraint in the partition as its
   10959             :  * child.
   10960             :  *
   10961             :  * If wqueue is given, it is used to set up phase-3 verification for each
   10962             :  * cloned constraint; if omitted, we assume that such verification is not
   10963             :  * needed (example: the partition is being created anew).
   10964             :  */

   10966        8874 : CloneFkReferencing(List **wqueue, Relation parentRel, Relation partRel)

   11222             : 
   11223             : /*
   11224             :  * When the parent of a partition receives [the referencing side of] a foreign
   11225             :  * key, we must propagate that foreign key to the partition.  However, the
   11226             :  * partition might already have an equivalent foreign key; this routine
   11227             :  * compares the given ForeignKeyCacheInfo (in the partition) to the FK defined
   11228             :  * by the other parameters.  If they are equivalent, create the link between
   11229             :  * the two constraints and return true.
   11230             :  *
   11231             :  * If the given FK does not match the one defined by rest of the params,
   11232             :  * return false.
   11233             :  */
   11234             : static bool
   11235         180 : tryAttachPartitionForeignKey(ForeignKeyCacheInfo *fk,
   11236             :                              Oid partRelid,
   11237             :                              Oid parentConstrOid,
   11238             :                              int numfks,
   11239             :                              AttrNumber *mapped_conkey,
   11240             :                              AttrNumber *confkey,
   11241             :                              Oid *conpfeqop,
   11242             :                              Oid parentInsTrigger,
   11243             :                              Oid parentUpdTrigger,
   11244             :                              Relation trigrel)
   11245             : {
   11246             :     HeapTuple   parentConstrTup;
   11247             :     Form_pg_constraint parentConstr;
   11248             :     HeapTuple   partcontup;
   11249             :     Form_pg_constraint partConstr;
   11250             :     ScanKeyData key;
   11251             :     SysScanDesc scan;
   11252             :     HeapTuple   trigtup;
   11253             :     Oid         insertTriggerOid,
   11254             :                 updateTriggerOid;
   11255             :

   11494             : /*
   11495             :  * ALTER TABLE ALTER CONSTRAINT
   11496             :  *
   11497             :  * Update the attributes of a constraint.
   11498             :  *
   11499             :  * Currently only works for Foreign Key constraints.
   11500             :  *
   11501             :  * If the constraint is modified, returns its address; otherwise, return
   11502             :  * InvalidObjectAddress.
   11503             :  */

   11505          66 : ATExecAlterConstraint(Relation rel, AlterTableCmd *cmd, bool recurse,

   11556             :     /*
   11557             :      * If it's not the topmost constraint, raise an error.
   11558             :      *
   11559             :      * Altering a non-topmost constraint leaves some triggers untouched, since
   11560             :      * they are not directly connected to this constraint; also, pg_dump would
   11561             :      * ignore the deferrability status of the individual constraint, since it

   11629             : 
   11630             : /*
   11631             :  * Recursive subroutine of ATExecAlterConstraint.  Returns true if the
   11632             :  * constraint is altered.
   11633             :  *
   11634             :  * *otherrelids is appended OIDs of relations containing affected triggers.
   11635             :  *
   11636             :  * Note that we must recurse even when the values are correct, in case
   11637             :  * indirect descendants have had their constraints altered locally.
   11638             :  * (This could be avoided if we forbade altering constraints in partitions
   11639             :  * but existing releases don't do that.)
   11640             :  */
   11641             : static bool
   11642         120 : ATExecAlterConstrRecurse(Constraint *cmdcon, Relation conrel, Relation tgrel,
   11643             :                          Relation rel, HeapTuple contuple, List **otherrelids,
   11644             :                          LOCKMODE lockmode)
   11645             : {
   11646             :     Form_pg_constraint currcon;
   11647             :     Oid         conoid;
   11648             :     Oid         refrelid;

   11650             : 
   11651         120 :     currcon = (Form_pg_constraint) GETSTRUCT(contuple);
   11652         120 :     conoid = currcon->oid;
   11653         120 :     refrelid = currcon->confrelid;
   11654             : 
   11655             :     /*
   11656             :      * Update pg_constraint with the flags from cmdcon.
   11657             :      *
   11658             :      * If called to modify a constraint that's already in the desired state,
   11659             :      * silently do nothing.
   11660             :      */
   11661         120 :     if (currcon->condeferrable != cmdcon->deferrable ||
   11662           6 :         currcon->condeferred != cmdcon->initdeferred)
   11663             :     {
   11664             :         HeapTuple   copyTuple;

   11672         120 :         copy_con->condeferrable = cmdcon->deferrable;
   11673         120 :         copy_con->condeferred = cmdcon->initdeferred;
   11674         120 :         CatalogTupleUpdate(conrel, &copyTuple->t_self, copyTuple);
   11675             : 
   11676         120 :         InvokeObjectPostAlterHook(ConstraintRelationId,
   11677             :                                   conoid, 0);
   11678             : 
   11679         120 :         heap_freetuple(copyTuple);
   11680         120 :         changed = true;
   11681             : 
   11682             :         /* Make new constraint flags visible to others */
   11683         120 :         CacheInvalidateRelcache(rel);
   11684             : 
   11685             :         /*
   11686             :          * Now we need to update the multiple entries in pg_trigger that
   11687             :          * implement the constraint.
   11688             :          */
   11689         120 :         ScanKeyInit(&tgkey,

   11694             :                                     NULL, 1, &tgkey);
   11695         468 :         while (HeapTupleIsValid(tgtuple = systable_getnext(tgscan)))

   11697         348 :             Form_pg_trigger tgform = (Form_pg_trigger) GETSTRUCT(tgtuple);

   11699             :             HeapTuple   tgCopyTuple;
   11700             :

   11709             :                                                       tgform->tgrelid);
   11710             : 
   11711             :             /*
   11712             :              * Update deferrability of RI_FKey_noaction_del,

   11715             :              * and CreateFKCheckTrigger.

   11717         348 :             if (tgform->tgfoid != F_RI_FKEY_NOACTION_DEL &&

   11722             : 
   11723         330 :             tgCopyTuple = heap_copytuple(tgtuple);
   11724         330 :             copy_tg = (Form_pg_trigger) GETSTRUCT(tgCopyTuple);

   11727         330 :             copy_tg->tginitdeferred = cmdcon->initdeferred;
   11728         330 :             CatalogTupleUpdate(tgrel, &tgCopyTuple->t_self, tgCopyTuple);
   11729             : 
   11730         330 :             InvokeObjectPostAlterHook(TriggerRelationId, tgform->oid, 0);
   11731             : 
   11732         330 :             heap_freetuple(tgCopyTuple);
   11733             :         }
   11734             : 
   11735         120 :         systable_endscan(tgscan);
   11736             :     }
   11737             : 
   11738             :     /*
   11739             :      * If the table at either end of the constraint is partitioned, we need to
   11740             :      * recurse and handle every constraint that is a child of this one.
   11741             :      *
   11742             :      * (This assumes that the recurse flag is forcibly set for partitioned
   11743             :      * tables, and not set for legacy inheritance, though we don't check for
   11744             :      * that here.)
   11745             :      */

   11747          96 :         get_rel_relkind(refrelid) == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE)

   11777             : 
   11778             : /*
   11779             :  * ALTER TABLE VALIDATE CONSTRAINT
   11780             :  *
   11781             :  * XXX The reason we handle recursion here rather than at Phase 1 is because
   11782             :  * there's no good way to skip recursing when handling foreign keys: there is
   11783             :  * no need to lock children in that case, yet we wouldn't be able to avoid
   11784             :  * doing so at that level.
   11785             :  *
   11786             :  * Return value is the address of the validated constraint.  If the constraint
   11787             :  * was already validated, InvalidObjectAddress is returned.
   11788             :  */

   11790         436 : ATExecValidateConstraint(List **wqueue, Relation rel, char *constrName,
   11791             :                          bool recurse, bool recursing, LOCKMODE lockmode)

   11968             : /*
   11969             :  * transformColumnNameList - transform list of column names
   11970             :  *
   11971             :  * Lookup each name and return its attnum and, optionally, type OID
   11972             :  *
   11973             :  * Note: the name of this function suggests that it's general-purpose,
   11974             :  * but actually it's only used to look up names appearing in foreign-key

   12018             : /*
   12019             :  * transformFkeyGetPrimaryKey -
   12020             :  *
   12021             :  *  Look up the names, attnums, and types of the primary key attributes
   12022             :  *  for the pkrel.  Also return the index OID and index opclasses of the
   12023             :  *  index supporting the primary key.
   12024             :  *

   12026             :  *  return value is the number of attributes in the primary key.

   12029             :  */
   12030             : static int
   12031         936 : transformFkeyGetPrimaryKey(Relation pkrel, Oid *indexOid,
   12032             :                            List **attnamelist,

   12117             : /*
   12118             :  * transformFkeyCheckAttrs -
   12119             :  *
   12120             :  *  Validate that the 'attnums' columns in the 'pkrel' relation are valid to
   12121             :  *  reference as part of a foreign key constraint.
   12122             :  *
   12123             :  *  Returns the OID of the unique index supporting the constraint and
   12124             :  *  populates the caller-provided 'opclasses' array with the opclasses
   12125             :  *  associated with the index columns.
   12126             :  *
   12127             :  *  Raises an ERROR on validation failure.
   12128             :  */
   12129             : static Oid
   12130        1082 : transformFkeyCheckAttrs(Relation pkrel,
   12131             :                         int numattrs, int16 *attnums,
   12132             :                         Oid *opclasses)
   12133             : {
   12134        1082 :     Oid         indexoid = InvalidOid;
   12135        1082 :     bool        found = false;
   12136        1082 :     bool        found_deferrable = false;

   12138             :     ListCell   *indexoidscan;
   12139             :     int         i,
   12140             :                 j;
   12141             : 
   12142             :     /*
   12143             :      * Reject duplicate appearances of columns in the referenced-columns list.
   12144             :      * Such a case is forbidden by the SQL standard, and even if we thought it
   12145             :      * useful to allow it, there would be ambiguity about how to match the
   12146             :      * list to unique indexes (in particular, it'd be unclear which index
   12147             :      * opclass goes with which FK column).
   12148             :      */
   12149        2448 :     for (i = 0; i < numattrs; i++)
   12150             :     {
   12151        1692 :         for (j = i + 1; j < numattrs; j++)
   12152             :         {
   12153         326 :             if (attnums[i] == attnums[j])
   12154           0 :                 ereport(ERROR,
   12155             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_FOREIGN_KEY),
   12156             :                          errmsg("foreign key referenced-columns list must not contain duplicates")));
   12157             :         }
   12158             :     }
   12159             : 
   12160             :     /*
   12161             :      * Get the list of index OIDs for the table from the relcache, and look up
   12162             :      * each one in the pg_index syscache, and match unique indexes to the list
   12163             :      * of attnums we are given.
   12164             :      */
   12165        1082 :     indexoidlist = RelationGetIndexList(pkrel);
   12166             : 
   12167        1262 :     foreach(indexoidscan, indexoidlist)
   12168             :     {
   12169             :         HeapTuple   indexTuple;

   12171             : 
   12172        1250 :         indexoid = lfirst_oid(indexoidscan);
   12173        1250 :         indexTuple = SearchSysCache1(INDEXRELID, ObjectIdGetDatum(indexoid));
   12174        1250 :         if (!HeapTupleIsValid(indexTuple))
   12175           0 :             elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for index %u", indexoid);
   12176        1250 :         indexStruct = (Form_pg_index) GETSTRUCT(indexTuple);
   12177             : 
   12178             :         /*
   12179             :          * Must have the right number of columns; must be unique and not a
   12180             :          * partial index; forget it if there are any expressions, too. Invalid
   12181             :          * indexes are out as well.
   12182             :          */
   12183        1250 :         if (indexStruct->indnkeyatts == numattrs &&
   12184        1142 :             indexStruct->indisunique &&
   12185        2256 :             indexStruct->indisvalid &&
   12186        2256 :             heap_attisnull(indexTuple, Anum_pg_index_indpred, NULL) &&
   12187        1128 :             heap_attisnull(indexTuple, Anum_pg_index_indexprs, NULL))
   12188             :         {
   12189             :             Datum       indclassDatum;
