   12193        1128 :             indclassDatum = SysCacheGetAttrNotNull(INDEXRELID, indexTuple,
   12194             :                                                    Anum_pg_index_indclass);
   12195        1128 :             indclass = (oidvector *) DatumGetPointer(indclassDatum);
   12196             : 
   12197             :             /*
   12198             :              * The given attnum list may match the index columns in any order.
   12199             :              * Check for a match, and extract the appropriate opclasses while
   12200             :              * we're at it.
   12201             :              *
   12202             :              * We know that attnums[] is duplicate-free per the test at the
   12203             :              * start of this function, and we checked above that the number of
   12204             :              * index columns agrees, so if we find a match for each attnums[]
   12205             :              * entry then we must have a one-to-one match in some order.
   12206             :              */
   12207        2482 :             for (i = 0; i < numattrs; i++)
   12208             :             {
   12209        1412 :                 found = false;
   12210        1796 :                 for (j = 0; j < numattrs; j++)
   12211             :                 {
   12212        1738 :                     if (attnums[i] == indexStruct->indkey.values[j])
   12213             :                     {
   12214        1354 :                         opclasses[i] = indclass->values[j];
   12215        1354 :                         found = true;
   12216        1354 :                         break;
   12217             :                     }
   12218             :                 }
   12219        1412 :                 if (!found)
   12220          58 :                     break;
   12221             :             }
   12222             : 
   12223             :             /*
   12224             :              * Refuse to use a deferrable unique/primary key.  This is per SQL
   12225             :              * spec, and there would be a lot of interesting semantic problems
   12226             :              * if we tried to allow it.
   12227             :              */
   12228        1128 :             if (found && !indexStruct->indimmediate)
   12229             :             {

   12231             :                  * Remember that we found an otherwise matching index, so that
   12232             :                  * we can generate a more appropriate error message.

   12236             :             }

   12241             :     }

   12246           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
   12247             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),

   12262             : /*
   12263             :  * findFkeyCast -
   12264             :  *
   12265             :  *  Wrapper around find_coercion_pathway() for ATAddForeignKeyConstraint().
   12266             :  *  Caller has equal regard for binary coercibility and for an exact match.
   12267             : */
   12268             : static CoercionPathType
   12269          12 : findFkeyCast(Oid targetTypeId, Oid sourceTypeId, Oid *funcid)
   12270             : {

   12291             : /*
   12292             :  * Permissions checks on the referenced table for ADD FOREIGN KEY
   12293             :  *
   12294             :  * Note: we have already checked that the user owns the referencing table,
   12295             :  * else we'd have failed much earlier; no additional checks are needed for it.
   12296             :  */
   12297             : static void
   12298        2006 : checkFkeyPermissions(Relation rel, int16 *attnums, int natts)
   12299             : {

   12303             : 
   12304             :     /* Okay if we have relation-level REFERENCES permission */
   12305        2006 :     aclresult = pg_class_aclcheck(RelationGetRelid(rel), roleid,
   12306             :                                   ACL_REFERENCES);
   12307        2006 :     if (aclresult == ACLCHECK_OK)
   12308        2006 :         return;
   12309             :     /* Else we must have REFERENCES on each column */
   12310           0 :     for (i = 0; i < natts; i++)
   12311             :     {
   12312           0 :         aclresult = pg_attribute_aclcheck(RelationGetRelid(rel), attnums[i],
   12313             :                                           roleid, ACL_REFERENCES);

   12320             : /*
   12321             :  * Scan the existing rows in a table to verify they meet a proposed FK
   12322             :  * constraint.
   12323             :  *
   12324             :  * Caller must have opened and locked both relations appropriately.
   12325             :  */

   12327         950 : validateForeignKeyConstraint(char *conname,
   12328             :                              Relation rel,
   12329             :                              Relation pkrel,

   12338             :     MemoryContext perTupCxt;
   12339             :

   12341             :             (errmsg_internal("validating foreign key constraint \"%s\"", conname)));
   12342             : 
   12343             :     /*
   12344             :      * Build a trigger call structure; we'll need it either way.
   12345             :      */
   12346         950 :     trig.tgoid = InvalidOid;
   12347         950 :     trig.tgname = conname;

   12354         950 :     trig.tginitdeferred = false;
   12355             :     /* we needn't fill in remaining fields */

   12359             :      * indicates we must proceed with the fire-the-trigger method.
   12360             :      */
   12361         950 :     if (RI_Initial_Check(&trig, rel, pkrel))
   12362         876 :         return;
   12363             : 
   12364             :     /*

   12415             : 
   12416             : /*
   12417             :  * CreateFKCheckTrigger
   12418             :  *      Creates the insert (on_insert=true) or update "check" trigger that
   12419             :  *      implements a given foreign key
   12420             :  *
   12421             :  * Returns the OID of the so created trigger.
   12422             :  */
   12423             : static Oid
   12424        4988 : CreateFKCheckTrigger(Oid myRelOid, Oid refRelOid, Constraint *fkconstraint,
   12425             :                      Oid constraintOid, Oid indexOid, Oid parentTrigOid,
   12426             :                      bool on_insert)
   12427             : {
   12428             :     ObjectAddress trigAddress;
   12429             :     CreateTrigStmt *fk_trigger;
   12430             : 
   12431             :     /*
   12432             :      * Note: for a self-referential FK (referencing and referenced tables are
   12433             :      * the same), it is important that the ON UPDATE action fires before the
   12434             :      * CHECK action, since both triggers will fire on the same row during an
   12435             :      * UPDATE event; otherwise the CHECK trigger will be checking a non-final
   12436             :      * state of the row.  Triggers fire in name order, so we ensure this by
   12437             :      * using names like "RI_ConstraintTrigger_a_NNNN" for the action triggers
   12438             :      * and "RI_ConstraintTrigger_c_NNNN" for the check triggers.
   12439             :      */
   12440        4988 :     fk_trigger = makeNode(CreateTrigStmt);
   12441        4988 :     fk_trigger->replace = false;
   12442        4988 :     fk_trigger->isconstraint = true;
   12443        4988 :     fk_trigger->trigname = "RI_ConstraintTrigger_c";
   12444        4988 :     fk_trigger->relation = NULL;
   12445             : 
   12446             :     /* Either ON INSERT or ON UPDATE */
   12447        4988 :     if (on_insert)
   12448             :     {
   12449        2494 :         fk_trigger->funcname = SystemFuncName("RI_FKey_check_ins");
   12450        2494 :         fk_trigger->events = TRIGGER_TYPE_INSERT;
   12451             :     }
   12452             :     else
   12453             :     {
   12454        2494 :         fk_trigger->funcname = SystemFuncName("RI_FKey_check_upd");
   12455        2494 :         fk_trigger->events = TRIGGER_TYPE_UPDATE;
   12456             :     }
   12457             : 
   12458        4988 :     fk_trigger->args = NIL;
   12459        4988 :     fk_trigger->row = true;
   12460        4988 :     fk_trigger->timing = TRIGGER_TYPE_AFTER;
   12461        4988 :     fk_trigger->columns = NIL;
   12462        4988 :     fk_trigger->whenClause = NULL;
   12463        4988 :     fk_trigger->transitionRels = NIL;
   12464        4988 :     fk_trigger->deferrable = fkconstraint->deferrable;
   12465        4988 :     fk_trigger->initdeferred = fkconstraint->initdeferred;
   12466        4988 :     fk_trigger->constrrel = NULL;
   12467             : 
   12468        4988 :     trigAddress = CreateTrigger(fk_trigger, NULL, myRelOid, refRelOid,
   12469             :                                 constraintOid, indexOid, InvalidOid,
   12470             :                                 parentTrigOid, NULL, true, false);
   12471             : 
   12472             :     /* Make changes-so-far visible */
   12473        4988 :     CommandCounterIncrement();
   12474             : 
   12475        4988 :     return trigAddress.objectId;
   12476             : }

   12636             : /*
   12637             :  * ALTER TABLE DROP CONSTRAINT
   12638             :  *
   12639             :  * Like DROP COLUMN, we can't use the normal ALTER TABLE recursion mechanism.
   12640             :  */
   12641             : static void
   12642         784 : ATExecDropConstraint(Relation rel, const char *constrName,
   12643             :                      DropBehavior behavior, bool recurse,
   12644             :                      bool missing_ok, LOCKMODE lockmode)
   12645             : {
   12646             :     Relation    conrel;
   12647             :     SysScanDesc scan;
   12648             :     ScanKeyData skey[3];
   12649             :     HeapTuple   tuple;
   12650         784 :     bool        found = false;
   12651             : 
   12652         784 :     conrel = table_open(ConstraintRelationId, RowExclusiveLock);
   12653             : 
   12654             :     /*
   12655             :      * Find and drop the target constraint
   12656             :      */
   12657         784 :     ScanKeyInit(&skey[0],
   12658             :                 Anum_pg_constraint_conrelid,
   12659             :                 BTEqualStrategyNumber, F_OIDEQ,
   12660             :                 ObjectIdGetDatum(RelationGetRelid(rel)));
   12661         784 :     ScanKeyInit(&skey[1],
   12662             :                 Anum_pg_constraint_contypid,
   12663             :                 BTEqualStrategyNumber, F_OIDEQ,
   12664             :                 ObjectIdGetDatum(InvalidOid));
   12665         784 :     ScanKeyInit(&skey[2],
   12666             :                 Anum_pg_constraint_conname,
   12667             :                 BTEqualStrategyNumber, F_NAMEEQ,
   12668             :                 CStringGetDatum(constrName));
   12669         784 :     scan = systable_beginscan(conrel, ConstraintRelidTypidNameIndexId,
   12670             :                               true, NULL, 3, skey);
   12671             : 
   12672             :     /* There can be at most one matching row */
   12673         784 :     if (HeapTupleIsValid(tuple = systable_getnext(scan)))
   12674             :     {
   12675         748 :         List       *readyRels = NIL;
   12676             : 
   12677         748 :         dropconstraint_internal(rel, tuple, behavior, recurse, false,
   12678             :                                 missing_ok, &readyRels, lockmode);
   12679         574 :         found = true;
   12680             :     }
   12681             : 
   12682         610 :     systable_endscan(scan);
   12683             : 
   12684         610 :     if (!found)
   12685             :     {
   12686          36 :         if (!missing_ok)
   12687          24 :             ereport(ERROR,
   12688             :                     errcode(ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_OBJECT),
   12689             :                     errmsg("constraint \"%s\" of relation \"%s\" does not exist",
   12690             :                            constrName, RelationGetRelationName(rel)));
   12691             :         else
   12692          12 :             ereport(NOTICE,
   12693             :                     errmsg("constraint \"%s\" of relation \"%s\" does not exist, skipping",
   12694             :                            constrName, RelationGetRelationName(rel)));
   12695             :     }
   12696             : 
   12697         586 :     table_close(conrel, RowExclusiveLock);
   12698         586 : }
   12699             : 
   12700             : /*
   12701             :  * Remove a constraint, using its pg_constraint tuple
   12702             :  *
   12703             :  * Implementation for ALTER TABLE DROP CONSTRAINT and ALTER TABLE ALTER COLUMN
   12704             :  * DROP NOT NULL.
   12705             :  *
   12706             :  * Returns the address of the constraint being removed.
   12707             :  */
   12708             : static ObjectAddress
   12709        1124 : dropconstraint_internal(Relation rel, HeapTuple constraintTup, DropBehavior behavior,

   13127             : 
   13128             : /*
   13129             :  * ALTER COLUMN TYPE
   13130             :  *
   13131             :  * Unlike other subcommand types, we do parse transformation for ALTER COLUMN
   13132             :  * TYPE during phase 1 --- the AlterTableCmd passed in here is already
   13133             :  * transformed (and must be, because we rely on some transformed fields).
   13134             :  *
   13135             :  * The point of this is that the execution of all ALTER COLUMN TYPEs for a
   13136             :  * table will be done "in parallel" during phase 3, so all the USING
   13137             :  * expressions should be parsed assuming the original column types.  Also,
   13138             :  * this allows a USING expression to refer to a field that will be dropped.
   13139             :  *
   13140             :  * To make this work safely, AT_PASS_DROP then AT_PASS_ALTER_TYPE must be
   13141             :  * the first two execution steps in phase 2; they must not see the effects
   13142             :  * of any other subcommand types, since the USING expressions are parsed
   13143             :  * against the unmodified table's state.
   13144             :  */
   13145             : static void
   13146        1106 : ATPrepAlterColumnType(List **wqueue,
   13147             :                       AlteredTableInfo *tab, Relation rel,
   13148             :                       bool recurse, bool recursing,
   13149             :                       AlterTableCmd *cmd, LOCKMODE lockmode,
   13150             :                       AlterTableUtilityContext *context)
   13151             : {
   13152        1106 :     char       *colName = cmd->name;
   13153        1106 :     ColumnDef  *def = (ColumnDef *) cmd->def;
   13154        1106 :     TypeName   *typeName = def->typeName;
   13155        1106 :     Node       *transform = def->cooked_default;
   13156             :     HeapTuple   tuple;
   13157             :     Form_pg_attribute attTup;
   13158             :     AttrNumber  attnum;
   13159             :     Oid         targettype;
   13160             :     int32       targettypmod;
   13161             :     Oid         targetcollid;
   13162             :     NewColumnValue *newval;
   13163        1106 :     ParseState *pstate = make_parsestate(NULL);
   13164             :     AclResult   aclresult;
   13165             :     bool        is_expr;
   13166             : 
   13167        1106 :     if (rel->rd_rel->reloftype && !recursing)
   13168           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
   13169             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
   13170             :                  errmsg("cannot alter column type of typed table")));
   13171             : 
   13172             :     /* lookup the attribute so we can check inheritance status */
   13173        1100 :     tuple = SearchSysCacheAttName(RelationGetRelid(rel), colName);
   13174        1100 :     if (!HeapTupleIsValid(tuple))
   13175           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   13176             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_COLUMN),
   13177             :                  errmsg("column \"%s\" of relation \"%s\" does not exist",
   13178             :                         colName, RelationGetRelationName(rel))));
   13179        1100 :     attTup = (Form_pg_attribute) GETSTRUCT(tuple);
   13180        1100 :     attnum = attTup->attnum;
   13181             : 
   13182             :     /* Can't alter a system attribute */
   13183        1100 :     if (attnum <= 0)
   13184           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   13185             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
   13186             :                  errmsg("cannot alter system column \"%s\"",
   13187             :                         colName)));
   13188             : 
   13189             :     /*
   13190             :      * Don't alter inherited columns.  At outer level, there had better not be
   13191             :      * any inherited definition; when recursing, we assume this was checked at
   13192             :      * the parent level (see below).
   13193             :      */
   13194        1100 :     if (attTup->attinhcount > 0 && !recursing)
   13195           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
   13196             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_TABLE_DEFINITION),
   13197             :                  errmsg("cannot alter inherited column \"%s\"",

   13411             : 
   13412             : /*
   13413             :  * When the data type of a column is changed, a rewrite might not be required
   13414             :  * if the new type is sufficiently identical to the old one, and the USING
   13415             :  * clause isn't trying to insert some other value.  It's safe to skip the
   13416             :  * rewrite in these cases:
   13417             :  *
   13418             :  * - the old type is binary coercible to the new type
   13419             :  * - the new type is an unconstrained domain over the old type
   13420             :  * - {NEW,OLD} or {OLD,NEW} is {timestamptz,timestamp} and the timezone is UTC
   13421             :  *
   13422             :  * In the case of a constrained domain, we could get by with scanning the
   13423             :  * table and checking the constraint rather than actually rewriting it, but we
   13424             :  * don't currently try to do that.
   13425             :  */
   13426             : static bool
   13427         898 : ATColumnChangeRequiresRewrite(Node *expr, AttrNumber varattno)
   13428             : {
   13429         898 :     Assert(expr != NULL);
   13430             : 
   13431             :     for (;;)
   13432             :     {
   13433             :         /* only one varno, so no need to check that */
   13434        1002 :         if (IsA(expr, Var) && ((Var *) expr)->varattno == varattno)
   13435         164 :             return false;
   13436         838 :         else if (IsA(expr, RelabelType))
   13437          92 :             expr = (Node *) ((RelabelType *) expr)->arg;
   13438         746 :         else if (IsA(expr, CoerceToDomain))
   13439             :         {
   13440           0 :             CoerceToDomain *d = (CoerceToDomain *) expr;
   13441             : 
   13442           0 :             if (DomainHasConstraints(d->resulttype))
   13443           0 :                 return true;
   13444           0 :             expr = (Node *) d->arg;
   13445             :         }
   13446         746 :         else if (IsA(expr, FuncExpr))
   13447             :         {
   13448         546 :             FuncExpr   *f = (FuncExpr *) expr;
   13449             : 
   13450         546 :             switch (f->funcid)
   13451             :             {
   13452          18 :                 case F_TIMESTAMPTZ_TIMESTAMP:
   13453             :                 case F_TIMESTAMP_TIMESTAMPTZ:
   13454          18 :                     if (TimestampTimestampTzRequiresRewrite())
   13455           6 :                         return true;
   13456             :                     else
   13457          12 :                         expr = linitial(f->args);
   13458          12 :                     break;
   13459         528 :                 default:
   13460         528 :                     return true;
   13461             :             }
   13462             :         }
   13463             :         else
   13464         200 :             return true;
   13465             :     }
   13466             : }
   13467             : 
   13468             : /*
   13469             :  * ALTER COLUMN .. SET DATA TYPE
   13470             :  *
   13471             :  * Return the address of the modified column.
   13472             :  */
   13473             : static ObjectAddress

   13540             :     /*
   13541             :      * If there is a default expression for the column, get it and ensure we
   13542             :      * can coerce it to the new datatype.  (We must do this before changing
   13543             :      * the column type, because build_column_default itself will try to
   13544             :      * coerce, and will not issue the error message we want if it fails.)
   13545             :      *
   13546             :      * We remove any implicit coercion steps at the top level of the old
   13547             :      * default expression; this has been agreed to satisfy the principle of
   13548             :      * least surprise.  (The conversion to the new column type should act like
   13549             :      * it started from what the user sees as the stored expression, and the
   13550             :      * implicit coercions aren't going to be shown.)
   13551             :      */

   13676             :

   13678             :                                            1,
   13679             :                                            &one,
   13680             :                                            0,
   13681           6 :                                            attTup->attlen,

   13785             : /*

   14041             : /*
   14042             :  * Subroutine for ATExecAlterColumnType: remember that a constraint needs
   14043             :  * to be rebuilt (which we might already know).
   14044             :  */
   14045             : static void
   14046         524 : RememberConstraintForRebuilding(Oid conoid, AlteredTableInfo *tab)
   14047             : {
   14048             :     /*
   14049             :      * This de-duplication check is critical for two independent reasons: we
   14050             :      * mustn't try to recreate the same constraint twice, and if a constraint
   14051             :      * depends on more than one column whose type is to be altered, we must
   14052             :      * capture its definition string before applying any of the column type
   14053             :      * changes.  ruleutils.c will get confused if we ask again later.
   14054             :      */
   14055         524 :     if (!list_member_oid(tab->changedConstraintOids, conoid))
   14056             :     {
   14057             :         /* OK, capture the constraint's existing definition string */
   14058         434 :         char       *defstring = pg_get_constraintdef_command(conoid);
   14059             :         Oid         indoid;
   14060             : 
   14061         434 :         tab->changedConstraintOids = lappend_oid(tab->changedConstraintOids,
   14062             :                                                  conoid);
   14063         434 :         tab->changedConstraintDefs = lappend(tab->changedConstraintDefs,
   14064             :                                              defstring);
   14065             : 
   14066             :         /*
   14067             :          * For the index of a constraint, if any, remember if it is used for
   14068             :          * the table's replica identity or if it is a clustered index, so that
   14069             :          * ATPostAlterTypeCleanup() can queue up commands necessary to restore
   14070             :          * those properties.

   14081             : /*
   14082             :  * Subroutine for ATExecAlterColumnType: remember that an index needs

   14084             :  */
   14085             : static void
   14086         232 : RememberIndexForRebuilding(Oid indoid, AlteredTableInfo *tab)
   14087             : {
   14088             :     /*
   14089             :      * This de-duplication check is critical for two independent reasons: we
   14090             :      * mustn't try to recreate the same index twice, and if an index depends
   14091             :      * on more than one column whose type is to be altered, we must capture
   14092             :      * its definition string before applying any of the column type changes.

   14095         232 :     if (!list_member_oid(tab->changedIndexOids, indoid))
   14096             :     {
   14097             :         /*
   14098             :          * Before adding it as an index-to-rebuild, we'd better see if it
   14099             :          * belongs to a constraint, and if so rebuild the constraint instead.
   14100             :          * Typically this check fails, because constraint indexes normally
   14101             :          * have only dependencies on their constraint.  But it's possible for
   14102             :          * such an index to also have direct dependencies on table columns,
   14103             :          * for example with a partial exclusion constraint.
   14104             :          */
   14105         224 :         Oid         conoid = get_index_constraint(indoid);
   14106             : 
   14107         224 :         if (OidIsValid(conoid))
   14108             :         {

   14110             :         }
   14111             :         else
   14112             :         {
   14113             :             /* OK, capture the index's existing definition string */
   14114         212 :             char       *defstring = pg_get_indexdef_string(indoid);

   14117             :                                                 indoid);

   14121             :             /*
   14122             :              * Remember if this index is used for the table's replica identity

   14124             :              * can queue up commands necessary to restore those properties.

   14127         212 :             RememberClusterOnForRebuilding(indoid, tab);

   14132             : /*
   14133             :  * Subroutine for ATExecAlterColumnType: remember that a statistics object
   14134             :  * needs to be rebuilt (which we might already know).
   14135             :  */
   14136             : static void
   14137          14 : RememberStatisticsForRebuilding(Oid stxoid, AlteredTableInfo *tab)
   14138             : {
   14139             :     /*
   14140             :      * This de-duplication check is critical for two independent reasons: we
   14141             :      * mustn't try to recreate the same statistics object twice, and if the
   14142             :      * statistics object depends on more than one column whose type is to be
   14143             :      * altered, we must capture its definition string before applying any of
   14144             :      * the type changes. ruleutils.c will get confused if we ask again later.

   14147             :     {

   14152             :                                                  stxoid);

   14154             :                                              defstring);

   14156          14 : }
   14157             : 
   14158             : /*
   14159             :  * Cleanup after we've finished all the ALTER TYPE or SET EXPRESSION
   14160             :  * operations for a particular relation.  We have to drop and recreate all the
   14161             :  * indexes and constraints that depend on the altered columns.  We do the
   14162             :  * actual dropping here, but re-creation is managed by adding work queue
   14163             :  * entries to do those steps later.
   14164             :  */
   14165             : static void
   14166         944 : ATPostAlterTypeCleanup(List **wqueue, AlteredTableInfo *tab, LOCKMODE lockmode)
   14167             : {
   14168             :     ObjectAddress obj;
   14169             :     ObjectAddresses *objects;
   14170             :     ListCell   *def_item;
   14171             :     ListCell   *oid_item;
   14172             : 
   14173             :     /*
   14174             :      * Collect all the constraints and indexes to drop so we can process them
   14175             :      * in a single call.  That way we don't have to worry about dependencies
   14176             :      * among them.
   14177             :      */
   14178         944 :     objects = new_object_addresses();
   14179             : 
   14180             :     /*
   14181             :      * Re-parse the index and constraint definitions, and attach them to the
   14182             :      * appropriate work queue entries.  We do this before dropping because in
   14183             :      * the case of a FOREIGN KEY constraint, we might not yet have exclusive
   14184             :      * lock on the table the constraint is attached to, and we need to get
   14185             :      * that before reparsing/dropping.
   14186             :      *
   14187             :      * We can't rely on the output of deparsing to tell us which relation to
   14188             :      * operate on, because concurrent activity might have made the name
   14189             :      * resolve differently.  Instead, we've got to use the OID of the
   14190             :      * constraint or index we're processing to figure out which relation to
   14191             :      * operate on.
   14192             :      */
   14193        1378 :     forboth(oid_item, tab->changedConstraintOids,
   14194             :             def_item, tab->changedConstraintDefs)
   14195             :     {
   14196         434 :         Oid         oldId = lfirst_oid(oid_item);
   14197             :         HeapTuple   tup;
   14198             :         Form_pg_constraint con;
   14199             :         Oid         relid;
   14200             :         Oid         confrelid;
   14201             :         char        contype;
   14202             :         bool        conislocal;
   14203             : 
   14204         434 :         tup = SearchSysCache1(CONSTROID, ObjectIdGetDatum(oldId));
   14205         434 :         if (!HeapTupleIsValid(tup)) /* should not happen */
   14206           0 :             elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for constraint %u", oldId);
   14207         434 :         con = (Form_pg_constraint) GETSTRUCT(tup);
   14208         434 :         if (OidIsValid(con->conrelid))
   14209         420 :             relid = con->conrelid;
   14210             :         else
   14211             :         {
   14212             :             /* must be a domain constraint */
   14213          14 :             relid = get_typ_typrelid(getBaseType(con->contypid));
   14214          14 :             if (!OidIsValid(relid))
   14215           0 :                 elog(ERROR, "could not identify relation associated with constraint %u", oldId);
   14216             :         }
   14217         434 :         confrelid = con->confrelid;
   14218         434 :         contype = con->contype;
   14219         434 :         conislocal = con->conislocal;
   14220         434 :         ReleaseSysCache(tup);
   14221             : 
   14222         434 :         ObjectAddressSet(obj, ConstraintRelationId, oldId);
   14223         434 :         add_exact_object_address(&obj, objects);
   14224             : 
   14225             :         /*

   14326             : /*
   14327             :  * Parse the previously-saved definition string for a constraint, index or
   14328             :  * statistics object against the newly-established column data type(s), and
   14329             :  * queue up the resulting command parsetrees for execution.
   14330             :  *
   14331             :  * This might fail if, for example, you have a WHERE clause that uses an
   14332             :  * operator that's not available for the new column type.
   14333             :  */
   14334             : static void
   14335         644 : ATPostAlterTypeParse(Oid oldId, Oid oldRelId, Oid refRelId, char *cmd,
   14336             :                      List **wqueue, LOCKMODE lockmode, bool rewrite)

   14343             :     /*
   14344             :      * We expect that we will get only ALTER TABLE and CREATE INDEX

   14346             :      * parse_analyze_*() or the rewriter, but instead we need to pass them
   14347             :      * through parse_utilcmd.c to make them ready for execution.

   14388             :      * Attach each generated command to the proper place in the work queue.

   14540             : /*
   14541             :  * Subroutine for ATPostAlterTypeParse() to recreate any existing comment
   14542             :  * for a table or domain constraint that is being rebuilt.
   14543             :  *

   14590             : /*
   14591             :  * Subroutine for ATPostAlterTypeParse().  Calls out to CheckIndexCompatible()

   14593             :  */
   14594             : static void
   14595         102 : TryReuseIndex(Oid oldId, IndexStmt *stmt)
   14596             : {
   14597         102 :     if (CheckIndexCompatible(oldId,

   14605             :         /* If it's a partitioned index, there is no storage to share. */

   14607             :         {

   14615             : 
   14616             : /*
   14617             :  * Subroutine for ATPostAlterTypeParse().
   14618             :  *
   14619             :  * Stash the old P-F equality operator into the Constraint node, for possible
   14620             :  * use by ATAddForeignKeyConstraint() in determining whether revalidation of
   14621             :  * this constraint can be skipped.
   14622             :  */
   14623             : static void
   14624           6 : TryReuseForeignKey(Oid oldId, Constraint *con)
   14625             : {
   14626             :     HeapTuple   tup;
   14627             :     Datum       adatum;
   14628             :     ArrayType  *arr;
   14629             :     Oid        *rawarr;

   14633           6 :     Assert(con->contype == CONSTR_FOREIGN);
   14634           6 :     Assert(con->old_conpfeqop == NIL);   /* already prepared this node */
   14635             : 
   14636           6 :     tup = SearchSysCache1(CONSTROID, ObjectIdGetDatum(oldId));
   14637           6 :     if (!HeapTupleIsValid(tup)) /* should not happen */
   14638           0 :         elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for constraint %u", oldId);
   14639             : 
   14640           6 :     adatum = SysCacheGetAttrNotNull(CONSTROID, tup,
   14641             :                                     Anum_pg_constraint_conpfeqop);
   14642           6 :     arr = DatumGetArrayTypeP(adatum);   /* ensure not toasted */
   14643           6 :     numkeys = ARR_DIMS(arr)[0];
   14644             :     /* test follows the one in ri_FetchConstraintInfo() */
   14645           6 :     if (ARR_NDIM(arr) != 1 ||
   14646           6 :         ARR_HASNULL(arr) ||
   14647           6 :         ARR_ELEMTYPE(arr) != OIDOID)

   14655           6 :     ReleaseSysCache(tup);
   14656           6 : }
   14657             : 
   14658             : /*
   14659             :  * ALTER COLUMN .. OPTIONS ( ... )
   14660             :  *
   14661             :  * Returns the address of the modified column
   14662             :  */
   14663             : static ObjectAddress
   14664         164 : ATExecAlterColumnGenericOptions(Relation rel,
   14665             :                                 const char *colName,
   14666             :                                 List *options,
   14667             :                                 LOCKMODE lockmode)
   14668             : {
   14669             :     Relation    ftrel;
   14670             :     Relation    attrel;
   14671             :     ForeignServer *server;
   14672             :     ForeignDataWrapper *fdw;
   14673             :     HeapTuple   tuple;
   14674             :     HeapTuple   newtuple;
   14675             :     bool        isnull;
   14676             :     Datum       repl_val[Natts_pg_attribute];
   14677             :     bool        repl_null[Natts_pg_attribute];
   14678             :     bool        repl_repl[Natts_pg_attribute];
   14679             :     Datum       datum;
   14680             :     Form_pg_foreign_table fttableform;
   14681             :     Form_pg_attribute atttableform;

   14685         164 :     if (options == NIL)
   14686           0 :         return InvalidObjectAddress;
   14687             : 
   14688             :     /* First, determine FDW validator associated to the foreign table. */
   14689         164 :     ftrel = table_open(ForeignTableRelationId, AccessShareLock);

   14692           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   14693             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_OBJECT),

   14706           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   14707             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_COLUMN),
   14708             :                  errmsg("column \"%s\" of relation \"%s\" does not exist",
   14709             :                         colName, RelationGetRelationName(rel))));
   14710             : 
   14711             :     /* Prevent them from altering a system attribute */

   14715           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
   14716             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
   14717             :                  errmsg("cannot alter system column \"%s\"", colName)));
   14718             : 
   14719             : 
   14720             :     /* Initialize buffers for new tuple values */
   14721         158 :     memset(repl_val, 0, sizeof(repl_val));

   14767             : 
   14768             : /*
   14769             :  * ALTER TABLE OWNER
   14770             :  *
   14771             :  * recursing is true if we are recursing from a table to its indexes,
   14772             :  * sequences, or toast table.  We don't allow the ownership of those things to
   14773             :  * be changed separately from the parent table.  Also, we can skip permission
   14774             :  * checks (this is necessary not just an optimization, else we'd fail to
   14775             :  * handle toast tables properly).
   14776             :  *
   14777             :  * recursing is also true if ALTER TYPE OWNER is calling us to fix up a
   14778             :  * free-standing composite type.
   14779             :  */
   14780             : void
   14781        1942 : ATExecChangeOwner(Oid relationOid, Oid newOwnerId, bool recursing, LOCKMODE lockmode)
   14782             : {
   14783             :     Relation    target_rel;
   14784             :     Relation    class_rel;
   14785             :     HeapTuple   tuple;
   14786             :     Form_pg_class tuple_class;
   14787             : 
   14788             :     /*
   14789             :      * Get exclusive lock till end of transaction on the target table. Use
   14790             :      * relation_open so that we can work on indexes and sequences.
   14791             :      */
   14792        1942 :     target_rel = relation_open(relationOid, lockmode);
   14793             : 
   14794             :     /* Get its pg_class tuple, too */
   14795        1942 :     class_rel = table_open(RelationRelationId, RowExclusiveLock);
   14796             : 
   14797        1942 :     tuple = SearchSysCache1(RELOID, ObjectIdGetDatum(relationOid));
   14798        1942 :     if (!HeapTupleIsValid(tuple))
   14799           0 :         elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for relation %u", relationOid);
   14800        1942 :     tuple_class = (Form_pg_class) GETSTRUCT(tuple);
   14801             : 
   14802             :     /* Can we change the ownership of this tuple? */
   14803        1942 :     switch (tuple_class->relkind)
   14804             :     {
   14805        1704 :         case RELKIND_RELATION:
   14806             :         case RELKIND_VIEW:
   14807             :         case RELKIND_MATVIEW:
   14808             :         case RELKIND_FOREIGN_TABLE:
   14809             :         case RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE:
   14810             :             /* ok to change owner */
   14811        1704 :             break;
   14812          84 :         case RELKIND_INDEX:
   14813          84 :             if (!recursing)
   14814             :             {
   14815             :                 /*
   14816             :                  * Because ALTER INDEX OWNER used to be allowed, and in fact
   14817             :                  * is generated by old versions of pg_dump, we give a warning
   14818             :                  * and do nothing rather than erroring out.  Also, to avoid
   14819             :                  * unnecessary chatter while restoring those old dumps, say
   14820             :                  * nothing at all if the command would be a no-op anyway.
   14821             :                  */
   14822           0 :                 if (tuple_class->relowner != newOwnerId)
   14823           0 :                     ereport(WARNING,
   14824             :                             (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
   14825             :                              errmsg("cannot change owner of index \"%s\"",
   14826             :                                     NameStr(tuple_class->relname)),
   14827             :                              errhint("Change the ownership of the index's table instead.")));
   14828             :                 /* quick hack to exit via the no-op path */
   14829           0 :                 newOwnerId = tuple_class->relowner;
   14830             :             }
   14831          84 :             break;
   14832          20 :         case RELKIND_PARTITIONED_INDEX:
   14833          20 :             if (recursing)
   14834          20 :                 break;
   14835           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
   14836             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
   14837             :                      errmsg("cannot change owner of index \"%s\"",
   14838             :                             NameStr(tuple_class->relname)),
   14839             :                      errhint("Change the ownership of the index's table instead.")));
   14840             :             break;
   14841          92 :         case RELKIND_SEQUENCE:
   14842          92 :             if (!recursing &&
   14843          62 :                 tuple_class->relowner != newOwnerId)
   14844             :             {
   14845             :                 /* if it's an owned sequence, disallow changing it by itself */
   14846             :                 Oid         tableId;
   14847             :                 int32       colId;
   14848             : 
   14849           0 :                 if (sequenceIsOwned(relationOid, DEPENDENCY_AUTO, &tableId, &colId) ||
   14850           0 :                     sequenceIsOwned(relationOid, DEPENDENCY_INTERNAL, &tableId, &colId))
   14851           0 :                     ereport(ERROR,
   14852             :                             (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
   14853             :                              errmsg("cannot change owner of sequence \"%s\"",
   14854             :                                     NameStr(tuple_class->relname)),
   14855             :                              errdetail("Sequence \"%s\" is linked to table \"%s\".",
   14856             :                                        NameStr(tuple_class->relname),
   14857             :                                        get_rel_name(tableId))));
   14858             :             }
   14859          92 :             break;
   14860           6 :         case RELKIND_COMPOSITE_TYPE:
   14861           6 :             if (recursing)
   14862           6 :                 break;
   14863           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
   14864             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),

   14866             :                             NameStr(tuple_class->relname)),
   14867             :             /* translator: %s is an SQL ALTER command */
   14868             :                      errhint("Use %s instead.",
   14869             :                              "ALTER TYPE")));
   14870             :             break;
   14871          36 :         case RELKIND_TOASTVALUE:
   14872          36 :             if (recursing)
   14873          36 :                 break;
   14874             :             /* FALL THRU */
   14875             :         default:
   14876           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
   14877             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),

   14879             :                             NameStr(tuple_class->relname)),
   14880             :                      errdetail_relkind_not_supported(tuple_class->relkind)));
   14881             :     }
   14882             : 
   14883             :     /*
   14884             :      * If the new owner is the same as the existing owner, consider the
   14885             :      * command to have succeeded.  This is for dump restoration purposes.
   14886             :      */

   14888             :     {
   14889             :         Datum       repl_val[Natts_pg_class];

   14891             :         bool        repl_repl[Natts_pg_class];

   14896             : 
   14897             :         /* skip permission checks when recursing to index or toast table */

   14899             :         {
   14900             :             /* Superusers can always do it */
   14901         274 :             if (!superuser())
   14902             :             {
   14903          42 :                 Oid         namespaceOid = tuple_class->relnamespace;
   14904             :                 AclResult   aclresult;

   14921             :         }
   14922             : 
   14923         438 :         memset(repl_null, false, sizeof(repl_null));
   14924         438 :         memset(repl_repl, false, sizeof(repl_repl));
   14925             : 
   14926         438 :         repl_repl[Anum_pg_class_relowner - 1] = true;
   14927         438 :         repl_val[Anum_pg_class_relowner - 1] = ObjectIdGetDatum(newOwnerId);

   14929             :         /*

   14948         438 :         heap_freetuple(newtuple);

   14950             :         /*

   15015             : /*
   15016             :  * change_owner_fix_column_acls
   15017             :  *
   15018             :  * Helper function for ATExecChangeOwner.  Scan the columns of the table
   15019             :  * and fix any non-null column ACLs to reflect the new owner.

   15079             : /*
   15080             :  * change_owner_recurse_to_sequences
   15081             :  *
   15082             :  * Helper function for ATExecChangeOwner.  Examines pg_depend searching
   15083             :  * for sequences that are dependent on serial columns, and changes their
   15084             :  * ownership.
   15085             :  */
   15086             : static void
   15087         438 : change_owner_recurse_to_sequences(Oid relationOid, Oid newOwnerId, LOCKMODE lockmode)
   15088             : {
   15089             :     Relation    depRel;
   15090             :     SysScanDesc scan;
   15091             :     ScanKeyData key[2];
   15092             :     HeapTuple   tup;
   15093             : 
   15094             :     /*
   15095             :      * SERIAL sequences are those having an auto dependency on one of the
   15096             :      * table's columns (we don't care *which* column, exactly).
   15097             :      */
   15098         438 :     depRel = table_open(DependRelationId, AccessShareLock);
   15099             : 
   15100         438 :     ScanKeyInit(&key[0],
   15101             :                 Anum_pg_depend_refclassid,
   15102             :                 BTEqualStrategyNumber, F_OIDEQ,
   15103             :                 ObjectIdGetDatum(RelationRelationId));
   15104         438 :     ScanKeyInit(&key[1],
   15105             :                 Anum_pg_depend_refobjid,
   15106             :                 BTEqualStrategyNumber, F_OIDEQ,
   15107             :                 ObjectIdGetDatum(relationOid));
   15108             :     /* we leave refobjsubid unspecified */
   15109             : 
   15110         438 :     scan = systable_beginscan(depRel, DependReferenceIndexId, true,
   15111             :                               NULL, 2, key);
   15112             : 
   15113        1216 :     while (HeapTupleIsValid(tup = systable_getnext(scan)))
   15114             :     {
   15115         778 :         Form_pg_depend depForm = (Form_pg_depend) GETSTRUCT(tup);
   15116             :         Relation    seqRel;
   15117             : 
   15118             :         /* skip dependencies other than auto dependencies on columns */
   15119         778 :         if (depForm->refobjsubid == 0 ||
   15120         268 :             depForm->classid != RelationRelationId ||
   15121         122 :             depForm->objsubid != 0 ||
   15122         122 :             !(depForm->deptype == DEPENDENCY_AUTO || depForm->deptype == DEPENDENCY_INTERNAL))
   15123         656 :             continue;
   15124             : 
   15125             :         /* Use relation_open just in case it's an index */
   15126         122 :         seqRel = relation_open(depForm->objid, lockmode);
   15127             : 
   15128             :         /* skip non-sequence relations */
   15129         122 :         if (RelationGetForm(seqRel)->relkind != RELKIND_SEQUENCE)
   15130             :         {
   15131             :             /* No need to keep the lock */
   15132         104 :             relation_close(seqRel, lockmode);
   15133         104 :             continue;
   15134             :         }
   15135             : 
   15136             :         /* We don't need to close the sequence while we alter it. */
   15137          18 :         ATExecChangeOwner(depForm->objid, newOwnerId, true, lockmode);
   15138             : 
   15139             :         /* Now we can close it.  Keep the lock till end of transaction. */
   15140          18 :         relation_close(seqRel, NoLock);
   15141             :     }
   15142             : 
   15143         438 :     systable_endscan(scan);
   15144             : 
   15145         438 :     relation_close(depRel, AccessShareLock);
   15146         438 : }

   15447             : /*
   15448             :  * Execute ALTER TABLE SET TABLESPACE for cases where there is no tuple

   15452         162 : ATExecSetTableSpace(Oid tableOid, Oid newTableSpace, LOCKMODE lockmode)

   15537             : /*
   15538             :  * Special handling of ALTER TABLE SET TABLESPACE for relations with no
   15539             :  * storage that have an interest in preserving tablespace.
   15540             :  *
   15541             :  * Since these have no storage the tablespace can be updated with a simple
   15542             :  * metadata only operation to update the tablespace.
   15543             :  */
   15544             : static void
   15545          36 : ATExecSetTableSpaceNoStorage(Relation rel, Oid newTableSpace)
   15546             : {
   15547             :     /*
   15548             :      * Shouldn't be called on relations having storage; these are processed in
   15549             :      * phase 3.

   15552             : 
   15553             :     /* check if relation can be moved to its new tablespace */

   15555             :     {
   15556           0 :         InvokeObjectPostAlterHook(RelationRelationId,
   15557             :                                   RelationGetRelid(rel),
   15558             :                                   0);
   15559           0 :         return;
   15560             :     }

   15564             : 
   15565          30 :     InvokeObjectPostAlterHook(RelationRelationId, RelationGetRelid(rel), 0);
   15566             : 
   15567             :     /* Make sure the reltablespace change is visible */
   15568          30 :     CommandCounterIncrement();

   15570             : 
   15571             : /*
   15572             :  * Alter Table ALL ... SET TABLESPACE
   15573             :  *
   15574             :  * Allows a user to move all objects of some type in a given tablespace in the
   15575             :  * current database to another tablespace.  Objects can be chosen based on the
   15576             :  * owner of the object also, to allow users to move only their objects.
   15577             :  * The user must have CREATE rights on the new tablespace, as usual.   The main
   15578             :  * permissions handling is done by the lower-level table move function.
   15579             :  *
   15580             :  * All to-be-moved objects are locked first. If NOWAIT is specified and the
   15581             :  * lock can't be acquired then we ereport(ERROR).
   15582             :  */
   15583             : Oid
   15584          30 : AlterTableMoveAll(AlterTableMoveAllStmt *stmt)
   15585             : {
   15586          30 :     List       *relations = NIL;
   15587             :     ListCell   *l;
   15588             :     ScanKeyData key[1];
   15589             :     Relation    rel;
   15590             :     TableScanDesc scan;
   15591             :     HeapTuple   tuple;
   15592             :     Oid         orig_tablespaceoid;
   15593             :     Oid         new_tablespaceoid;
   15594          30 :     List       *role_oids = roleSpecsToIds(stmt->roles);
   15595             : 
   15596             :     /* Ensure we were not asked to move something we can't */
   15597          30 :     if (stmt->objtype != OBJECT_TABLE && stmt->objtype != OBJECT_INDEX &&
   15598          12 :         stmt->objtype != OBJECT_MATVIEW)
   15599           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   15600             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_PARAMETER_VALUE),
   15601             :                  errmsg("only tables, indexes, and materialized views exist in tablespaces")));
   15602             : 
   15603             :     /* Get the orig and new tablespace OIDs */
   15604          30 :     orig_tablespaceoid = get_tablespace_oid(stmt->orig_tablespacename, false);
   15605          30 :     new_tablespaceoid = get_tablespace_oid(stmt->new_tablespacename, false);
   15606             : 
   15607             :     /* Can't move shared relations in to or out of pg_global */
   15608             :     /* This is also checked by ATExecSetTableSpace, but nice to stop earlier */
   15609          30 :     if (orig_tablespaceoid == GLOBALTABLESPACE_OID ||
   15610             :         new_tablespaceoid == GLOBALTABLESPACE_OID)
   15611           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   15612             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_PARAMETER_VALUE),
   15613             :                  errmsg("cannot move relations in to or out of pg_global tablespace")));
   15614             : 
   15615             :     /*
   15616             :      * Must have CREATE rights on the new tablespace, unless it is the
   15617             :      * database default tablespace (which all users implicitly have CREATE
   15618             :      * rights on).
   15619             :      */
   15620          30 :     if (OidIsValid(new_tablespaceoid) && new_tablespaceoid != MyDatabaseTableSpace)
   15621             :     {
   15622             :         AclResult   aclresult;
   15623             : 
   15624           0 :         aclresult = object_aclcheck(TableSpaceRelationId, new_tablespaceoid, GetUserId(),
   15625             :                                     ACL_CREATE);
   15626           0 :         if (aclresult != ACLCHECK_OK)
   15627           0 :             aclcheck_error(aclresult, OBJECT_TABLESPACE,
   15628           0 :                            get_tablespace_name(new_tablespaceoid));
   15629             :     }
   15630             : 
   15631             :     /*
   15632             :      * Now that the checks are done, check if we should set either to
   15633             :      * InvalidOid because it is our database's default tablespace.
   15634             :      */
   15635          30 :     if (orig_tablespaceoid == MyDatabaseTableSpace)
   15636           0 :         orig_tablespaceoid = InvalidOid;
   15637             : 
   15638          30 :     if (new_tablespaceoid == MyDatabaseTableSpace)
   15639          30 :         new_tablespaceoid = InvalidOid;
   15640             : 
   15641             :     /* no-op */
   15642          30 :     if (orig_tablespaceoid == new_tablespaceoid)
   15643           0 :         return new_tablespaceoid;
   15644             : 
   15645             :     /*
   15646             :      * Walk the list of objects in the tablespace and move them. This will
   15647             :      * only find objects in our database, of course.
   15648             :      */
   15649          30 :     ScanKeyInit(&key[0],
   15650             :                 Anum_pg_class_reltablespace,
   15651             :                 BTEqualStrategyNumber, F_OIDEQ,
   15652             :                 ObjectIdGetDatum(orig_tablespaceoid));
   15653             : 
   15654          30 :     rel = table_open(RelationRelationId, AccessShareLock);
   15655          30 :     scan = table_beginscan_catalog(rel, 1, key);
   15656         132 :     while ((tuple = heap_getnext(scan, ForwardScanDirection)) != NULL)
   15657             :     {
   15658         102 :         Form_pg_class relForm = (Form_pg_class) GETSTRUCT(tuple);
   15659         102 :         Oid         relOid = relForm->oid;
   15660             : 
   15661             :         /*
   15662             :          * Do not move objects in pg_catalog as part of this, if an admin
   15663             :          * really wishes to do so, they can issue the individual ALTER
   15664             :          * commands directly.

   15667             :          * (TOAST will be moved with the main table).

   15719          12 :         ereport(NOTICE,

   15725             :     /* Everything is locked, loop through and move all of the relations. */

   15745             : static void
   15746          62 : index_copy_data(Relation rel, RelFileLocator newrlocator)
   15747             : {
   15748             :     SMgrRelation dstrel;

   15750             :     /*
   15751             :      * Since we copy the file directly without looking at the shared buffers,
   15752             :      * we'd better first flush out any pages of the source relation that are
   15753             :      * in shared buffers.  We assume no new changes will be made while we are

   15830             : /*
   15831             :  * ALTER TABLE INHERIT
   15832             :  *
   15833             :  * Add a parent to the child's parents. This verifies that all the columns and
   15834             :  * check constraints of the parent appear in the child and that they have the
   15835             :  * same data types and expressions.
   15836             :  */
   15837             : static void
   15838         320 : ATPrepAddInherit(Relation child_rel)

   15841           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
   15842             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),

   15844             :

   15846           6 :         ereport(ERROR,

   15851           6 :         ereport(ERROR,

   15853             :                  errmsg("cannot change inheritance of partitioned table")));
   15854         302 : }
   15855             : 
   15856             : /*
   15857             :  * Return the address of the new parent relation.
   15858             :  */
   15859             : static ObjectAddress
   15860         302 : ATExecAddInherit(Relation child_rel, RangeVar *parent, LOCKMODE lockmode)
   15861             : {
   15862             :     Relation    parent_rel;
   15863             :     List       *children;
   15864             :     ObjectAddress address;
   15865             :     const char *trigger_name;
   15866             : 
   15867             :     /*
   15868             :      * A self-exclusive lock is needed here.  See the similar case in
   15869             :      * MergeAttributes() for a full explanation.
   15870             :      */
   15871         302 :     parent_rel = table_openrv(parent, ShareUpdateExclusiveLock);
   15872             : 
   15873             :     /*
   15874             :      * Must be owner of both parent and child -- child was checked by
   15875             :      * ATSimplePermissions call in ATPrepCmd
   15876             :      */
   15877         302 :     ATSimplePermissions(AT_AddInherit, parent_rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
   15878             : 
   15879             :     /* Permanent rels cannot inherit from temporary ones */
   15880         302 :     if (parent_rel->rd_rel->relpersistence == RELPERSISTENCE_TEMP &&
   15881           6 :         child_rel->rd_rel->relpersistence != RELPERSISTENCE_TEMP)
   15882           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   15883             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
   15884             :                  errmsg("cannot inherit from temporary relation \"%s\"",
   15885             :                         RelationGetRelationName(parent_rel))));
   15886             : 
   15887             :     /* If parent rel is temp, it must belong to this session */
   15888         302 :     if (parent_rel->rd_rel->relpersistence == RELPERSISTENCE_TEMP &&
   15889           6 :         !parent_rel->rd_islocaltemp)
   15890           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   15891             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
   15892             :                  errmsg("cannot inherit from temporary relation of another session")));
   15893             : 
   15894             :     /* Ditto for the child */
   15895         302 :     if (child_rel->rd_rel->relpersistence == RELPERSISTENCE_TEMP &&
   15896           6 :         !child_rel->rd_islocaltemp)
   15897           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   15898             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
   15899             :                  errmsg("cannot inherit to temporary relation of another session")));
   15900             : 
   15901             :     /* Prevent partitioned tables from becoming inheritance parents */
   15902         302 :     if (parent_rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE)
   15903           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
   15904             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
   15905             :                  errmsg("cannot inherit from partitioned table \"%s\"",
   15906             :                         parent->relname)));
   15907             : 
   15908             :     /* Likewise for partitions */
   15909         296 :     if (parent_rel->rd_rel->relispartition)
   15910           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
   15911             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
   15912             :                  errmsg("cannot inherit from a partition")));
   15913             : 
   15914             :     /*
   15915             :      * Prevent circularity by seeing if proposed parent inherits from child.
   15916             :      * (In particular, this disallows making a rel inherit from itself.)
   15917             :      *
   15918             :      * This is not completely bulletproof because of race conditions: in
   15919             :      * multi-level inheritance trees, someone else could concurrently be
   15920             :      * making another inheritance link that closes the loop but does not join
   15921             :      * either of the rels we have locked.  Preventing that seems to require
   15922             :      * exclusive locks on the entire inheritance tree, which is a cure worse
   15923             :      * than the disease.  find_all_inheritors() will cope with circularity
   15924             :      * anyway, so don't sweat it too much.
   15925             :      *
   15926             :      * We use weakest lock we can on child's children, namely AccessShareLock.
   15927             :      */
   15928         290 :     children = find_all_inheritors(RelationGetRelid(child_rel),
   15929             :                                    AccessShareLock, NULL);
   15930             : 
   15931         290 :     if (list_member_oid(children, RelationGetRelid(parent_rel)))
   15932          12 :         ereport(ERROR,
   15933             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_DUPLICATE_TABLE),
   15934             :                  errmsg("circular inheritance not allowed"),
   15935             :                  errdetail("\"%s\" is already a child of \"%s\".",
   15936             :                            parent->relname,
   15937             :                            RelationGetRelationName(child_rel))));
   15938             : 
   15939             :     /*
   15940             :      * If child_rel has row-level triggers with transition tables, we
   15941             :      * currently don't allow it to become an inheritance child.  See also
   15942             :      * prohibitions in ATExecAttachPartition() and CreateTrigger().
   15943             :      */
   15944         278 :     trigger_name = FindTriggerIncompatibleWithInheritance(child_rel->trigdesc);
   15945         278 :     if (trigger_name != NULL)
   15946           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
   15947             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
   15948             :                  errmsg("trigger \"%s\" prevents table \"%s\" from becoming an inheritance child",
   15949             :                         trigger_name, RelationGetRelationName(child_rel)),
   15950             :                  errdetail("ROW triggers with transition tables are not supported in inheritance hierarchies.")));
   15951             : 
   15952             :     /* OK to create inheritance */
   15953         272 :     CreateInheritance(child_rel, parent_rel, false);
   15954             : 
   15955             :     /*
   15956             :      * If parent_rel has a primary key, then child_rel has not-null
   15957             :      * constraints that make these columns as non nullable.  Make those
   15958             :      * constraints as inherited.
   15959             :      */
   15960         224 :     ATInheritAdjustNotNulls(parent_rel, child_rel, 1);
   15961             : 
   15962         218 :     ObjectAddressSet(address, RelationRelationId,
   15963             :                      RelationGetRelid(parent_rel));

   15965             :     /* keep our lock on the parent relation until commit */
   15966         218 :     table_close(parent_rel, NoLock);
   15967             :

   15969             : }
   15970             : 
   15971             : /*
   15972             :  * CreateInheritance
   15973             :  *      Catalog manipulation portion of creating inheritance between a child
   15974             :  *      table and a parent table.
   15975             :  *
   15976             :  * Common to ATExecAddInherit() and ATExecAttachPartition().
   15977             :  */
   15978             : static void
   15979        2228 : CreateInheritance(Relation child_rel, Relation parent_rel, bool ispartition)
   15980             : {
   15981             :     Relation    catalogRelation;
   15982             :     SysScanDesc scan;
   15983             :     ScanKeyData key;
   15984             :     HeapTuple   inheritsTuple;
   15985             :     int32       inhseqno;
   15986             : 
   15987             :     /* Note: get RowExclusiveLock because we will write pg_inherits below. */
   15988        2228 :     catalogRelation = table_open(InheritsRelationId, RowExclusiveLock);
   15989             : 
   15990             :     /*
   15991             :      * Check for duplicates in the list of parents, and determine the highest
   15992             :      * inhseqno already present; we'll use the next one for the new parent.
   15993             :      * Also, if proposed child is a partition, it cannot already be
   15994             :      * inheriting.
   15995             :      *
   15996             :      * Note: we do not reject the case where the child already inherits from
   15997             :      * the parent indirectly; CREATE TABLE doesn't reject comparable cases.
   15998             :      */
   15999        2228 :     ScanKeyInit(&key,
   16000             :                 Anum_pg_inherits_inhrelid,
   16001             :                 BTEqualStrategyNumber, F_OIDEQ,
   16002             :                 ObjectIdGetDatum(RelationGetRelid(child_rel)));
   16003        2228 :     scan = systable_beginscan(catalogRelation, InheritsRelidSeqnoIndexId,
   16004             :                               true, NULL, 1, &key);
   16005             : 
   16006             :     /* inhseqno sequences start at 1 */
   16007        2228 :     inhseqno = 0;
   16008        2274 :     while (HeapTupleIsValid(inheritsTuple = systable_getnext(scan)))
   16009             :     {
   16010          52 :         Form_pg_inherits inh = (Form_pg_inherits) GETSTRUCT(inheritsTuple);
   16011             : 
   16012          52 :         if (inh->inhparent == RelationGetRelid(parent_rel))
   16013           6 :             ereport(ERROR,
   16014             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_DUPLICATE_TABLE),
   16015             :                      errmsg("relation \"%s\" would be inherited from more than once",
   16016             :                             RelationGetRelationName(parent_rel))));
   16017             : 
   16018          46 :         if (inh->inhseqno > inhseqno)
   16019          46 :             inhseqno = inh->inhseqno;
   16020             :     }
   16021        2222 :     systable_endscan(scan);
   16022             : 
   16023             :     /* Match up the columns and bump attinhcount as needed */
   16024        2222 :     MergeAttributesIntoExisting(child_rel, parent_rel, ispartition);
   16025             : 
   16026             :     /* Match up the constraints and bump coninhcount as needed */
   16027        2144 :     MergeConstraintsIntoExisting(child_rel, parent_rel);
   16028             : 
   16029             :     /*
   16030             :      * OK, it looks valid.  Make the catalog entries that show inheritance.
   16031             :      */
   16032        2108 :     StoreCatalogInheritance1(RelationGetRelid(child_rel),
   16033             :                              RelationGetRelid(parent_rel),
   16034             :                              inhseqno + 1,
   16035             :                              catalogRelation,

   16040        2108 :     table_close(catalogRelation, RowExclusiveLock);

   16042             : 
   16043             : /*
   16044             :  * Obtain the source-text form of the constraint expression for a check
   16045             :  * constraint, given its pg_constraint tuple
   16046             :  */
   16047             : static char *
   16048         132 : decompile_conbin(HeapTuple contup, TupleDesc tupdesc)
   16049             : {
   16050             :     Form_pg_constraint con;
   16051             :     bool        isnull;
   16052             :     Datum       attr;
   16053             :     Datum       expr;
   16054             : 
   16055         132 :     con = (Form_pg_constraint) GETSTRUCT(contup);
   16056         132 :     attr = heap_getattr(contup, Anum_pg_constraint_conbin, tupdesc, &isnull);
   16057         132 :     if (isnull)
   16058           0 :         elog(ERROR, "null conbin for constraint %u", con->oid);
   16059             : 
   16060         132 :     expr = DirectFunctionCall2(pg_get_expr, attr,
   16061             :                                ObjectIdGetDatum(con->conrelid));
   16062         132 :     return TextDatumGetCString(expr);
   16063             : }
   16064             : 
   16065             : /*
   16066             :  * Determine whether two check constraints are functionally equivalent
   16067             :  *
   16068             :  * The test we apply is to see whether they reverse-compile to the same
   16069             :  * source string.  This insulates us from issues like whether attributes
   16070             :  * have the same physical column numbers in parent and child relations.
   16071             :  */
   16072             : static bool
   16073          66 : constraints_equivalent(HeapTuple a, HeapTuple b, TupleDesc tupleDesc)
   16074             : {
   16075          66 :     Form_pg_constraint acon = (Form_pg_constraint) GETSTRUCT(a);
   16076          66 :     Form_pg_constraint bcon = (Form_pg_constraint) GETSTRUCT(b);
   16077             : 
   16078          66 :     if (acon->condeferrable != bcon->condeferrable ||
   16079          66 :         acon->condeferred != bcon->condeferred ||
   16080          66 :         strcmp(decompile_conbin(a, tupleDesc),
   16081          66 :                decompile_conbin(b, tupleDesc)) != 0)
   16082           6 :         return false;
   16083             :     else
   16084          60 :         return true;
   16085             : }
   16086             : 
   16087             : /*
   16088             :  * Check columns in child table match up with columns in parent, and increment
   16089             :  * their attinhcount.
   16090             :  *
   16091             :  * Called by CreateInheritance
   16092             :  *
   16093             :  * Currently all parent columns must be found in child. Missing columns are an
   16094             :  * error.  One day we might consider creating new columns like CREATE TABLE
   16095             :  * does.  However, that is widely unpopular --- in the common use case of
   16096             :  * partitioned tables it's a foot-gun.
   16097             :  *
   16098             :  * The data type must match exactly. If the parent column is NOT NULL then
   16099             :  * the child must be as well. Defaults are not compared, however.
   16100             :  */
   16101             : static void
   16102        2222 : MergeAttributesIntoExisting(Relation child_rel, Relation parent_rel, bool ispartition)
   16103             : {
   16104             :     Relation    attrrel;
   16105             :     TupleDesc   parent_desc;
   16106             : 
   16107        2222 :     attrrel = table_open(AttributeRelationId, RowExclusiveLock);
   16108        2222 :     parent_desc = RelationGetDescr(parent_rel);
   16109             : 
   16110        7214 :     for (AttrNumber parent_attno = 1; parent_attno <= parent_desc->natts; parent_attno++)
   16111             :     {
   16112        5070 :         Form_pg_attribute parent_att = TupleDescAttr(parent_desc, parent_attno - 1);
   16113        5070 :         char       *parent_attname = NameStr(parent_att->attname);
   16114             :         HeapTuple   tuple;
   16115             : 
   16116             :         /* Ignore dropped columns in the parent. */
   16117        5070 :         if (parent_att->attisdropped)
   16118         296 :             continue;
   16119             : 
   16120             :         /* Find same column in child (matching on column name). */
   16121        4774 :         tuple = SearchSysCacheCopyAttName(RelationGetRelid(child_rel), parent_attname);
   16122        4774 :         if (HeapTupleIsValid(tuple))
   16123             :         {
   16124        4762 :             Form_pg_attribute child_att = (Form_pg_attribute) GETSTRUCT(tuple);
   16125             : 
   16126        4762 :             if (parent_att->atttypid != child_att->atttypid ||
   16127        4756 :                 parent_att->atttypmod != child_att->atttypmod)
   16128          12 :                 ereport(ERROR,
   16129             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_DATATYPE_MISMATCH),
   16130             :                          errmsg("child table \"%s\" has different type for column \"%s\"",
   16131             :                                 RelationGetRelationName(child_rel), parent_attname)));
   16132             : 
   16133        4750 :             if (parent_att->attcollation != child_att->attcollation)
   16134           6 :                 ereport(ERROR,
   16135             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_COLLATION_MISMATCH),

   16137             :                                 RelationGetRelationName(child_rel), parent_attname)));
   16138             : 
   16139             :             /*
   16140             :              * If the parent has a not-null constraint that's not NO INHERIT,
   16141             :              * make sure the child has one too.
   16142             :              *
   16143             :              * Other constraints are checked elsewhere.

   16213             : 
   16214             : /*
   16215             :  * Check constraints in child table match up with constraints in parent,
   16216             :  * and increment their coninhcount.
   16217             :  *
   16218             :  * Constraints that are marked ONLY in the parent are ignored.
   16219             :  *
   16220             :  * Called by CreateInheritance
   16221             :  *
   16222             :  * Currently all constraints in parent must be present in the child. One day we
   16223             :  * may consider adding new constraints like CREATE TABLE does.
   16224             :  *
   16225             :  * XXX This is O(N^2) which may be an issue with tables with hundreds of
   16226             :  * constraints. As long as tables have more like 10 constraints it shouldn't be
   16227             :  * a problem though. Even 100 constraints ought not be the end of the world.
   16228             :  *
   16229             :  * XXX See MergeWithExistingConstraint too if you change this code.
   16230             :  */
   16231             : static void
   16232        2144 : MergeConstraintsIntoExisting(Relation child_rel, Relation parent_rel)
   16233             : {

   16311             :              * If the CHECK child constraint is "no inherit" then cannot
   16312             :              * merge.
